number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2014
												This isn't the easiest game to describe, let alone review.Some nitpicky people will even try to tell you it's not a game at all, since there's no way to die/fail/lose.There's only one level, only one thing you work towards, and then it's over. A mere 3 hours in (for me personally).That can't be good, can it?It is. It so is.The player controls Kaitlin Greenbriar who, after a year of travelling abroad, has Gone Home.Her homecoming isn't quite as she'd planned it though, since nobody appears to be there to greet her.What follows is an exploration of a large house, its history, what your family has been up to in the year that you weren't there, and why nobody is there.This exploration is done very literally, you roam through the house in a first person perspective and look at things that you find. Almost everything can be picked up and analysed, most of it won't progress the game along (should you choose you can spend half an hour looking at a pack of toilet paper from all angles). What this accomplishes is that the house you wander around in feels very real. It's not laid out like a videogame level (mostly anyway), it actually feels like a home.Some objects spark memories, either Kaitlin's or those of her younger sister, Samantha. The protagonist's are displayed along the bottom of the screen, but Samantha's are fully voiced, generally taking the form of diary entries. The voice acting is believable, emotional, endearing.The game tells you a story, primarily Samantha's, of how Kaitlin being away has impacted her life, what she's been up to, how she handled moving to a new house, how she's making new friends. Endearing is a word I've used already in this review, several times maybe even, but that's what the game makes you do. You care about Samantha, and every diary excerpt you uncover makes you care a little bit more.By the time you've finally made your way to the last room to explore (game progress is generally non-linear except for two or three segments where you have to know a trick that is only explained in Samantha's diary entries to gain entry to a new part of the house) you'll be hooked and want to know the conclusion.And I loved the conclusion. The entire game builds up to it so well, both foreshadowing and alluding, and it's amazing feat of storytelling.Treat yourself and play this game, but expect to be told a story and explore a house, not to have your reflexes challenged.Definitely, passionately and endearingly recommended.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												My first review of Gone Home was entirely positive. I supposed I focused mostly on the parents and the challenges they faced. It was a pleasant break from stealth-based horror titles and combat-centric games--a mundane mystery: where is everyone and why is the house empty?  Everything changed on my second playthrough scouring the house for every possible bit of information and with commentary enabled.  I started to see the cracks and little things that previously amused now annoy and/or disappoint.  I'd like to be clear on a few points before we begin again:  I've no problems with games that have zero combat, minimal gameplay, simple stories, independent-tier graphics, Spoilers Ahead.  I mean it, the first point gives away the ending...Let's jump into this headfirst:  Gone Home's central plot involves Kaitlin Greenbriar (the player) arriving at the family's new home (inheritted by her father, Terrance, from his Uncle Oscar) only to find that everyone's missing.  Samantha Greenbriar (the sister) provides occasional voice-overs as the player explores the house and discovers (through her sister's diary) that Samantha left with her lover, Lonnie, after their (Sam & Kate's) parents previously left on an anniversary vacation.The complications that created this situation:1 - Samantha becomes friends with Lonnie during their high school years and soon falls for her.  With biases towards sexual preferences being what they were in the 1990s, the pair face difficulty at school and further problems arise.  Samantha and Lonnie's relationship is conducted secretly until a forced exposure (truancy, low grades) to her parents.  They give Samantha the "just a phase" speech before placing her on restriction.2 - Lonnie Desoto comes from a military family, so naturally she prepares for a career in military service.  This places a wedge between her and Samantha as any thoughts to the future are accompanied with healthy amounts of doubt.3 - Terrence Greenbriar (the father) found success as a writer, but was dropped by his publisher after the second novel bombed.  After finding some unusual letters, I took a closer look at Oscar Masan (Terrence's uncle) and the suspicions began to pile up.  Oscar sexually abused Terrence.  This has been confirmed--long before I stumbled onto it--on the developer's Twitter profile.  Terrence's novels are attempts to find closure, but are also forcing him to relive the abuse (likely much worse in memory) and sleeping in the house where the assaults took place certainly isn't helping.4 - Meanwhile, Janice Greenbriar (the mother) has been growing more and more distant from Terrence and closer to her coworker, Richard Something.  Everything comes to a head when the parents leave on their vacation; whether Terrence has told Janice about his past abuse or if Richard's sudden engagement and marriage invitation forced her to remember her husband remains to be seen.  In their absence, Samantha has an opportunity to spend one more night with Lonnie before she ships out.  The night passes and Samantha wakes up alone.  Later she realizes Lonnie left her several messages indicating that she's changed her plans to enlist (...in spite of having a ship date?  That's desertion, madam.) and wants to spend her life with Samantha.So that's the story, why has my recommendation changed?I was unaware of Terrence's abuse during my first playthrough.  I was convinced that Janice had given up her affair with Richard in order to rekindle her marriage.  Now it seems that the only options for them are Janice helping Terrence find closure or Janice adjusting to rejection and mending any bridges burned with her spouse.  The story's become darker with every subsequent look.  Oh, well sideplots shouldn't affect the overall impression, right?  Sure, keep telling yourself that.Present for some of the commentary was Corin Tucker...yeah, don't worry I didn't know who she was either.  Apparently, getting involved with feminism sells albums when the musician lacks the ability necessary.  Don't get me wrong:  the score was fine, but the insert tracks were devoid of melody or meaning.  Corin Tucker's contribution to the commentary is largely self-promotion and the fiction that feminism is about equality for everyone.Not once during the commentary did anyone mention the parents.  Their story was what drew me in the most, but it seems those two characters are simply window dressing.  The backstory of Terrence and Oscar should have been at least mentioned  in the commentary.  Either the developers sold out during the game's promotion or they were dishonest from the start.I haven't enjoyed writing this re-review.  It's been phenomenally disappointing to realize this game is not a positive message to everyone seeking love.  Would reactions to this game be the same if it were teenage boys instead of the two girls?  I doubt it.  Honest representations of alternative relationships are hard enough to find in games without added political propaganda.  I'll end this here while I still remember the good things Gone Home had to offer.The Good:- an honest portrayal of an alternative relationship without unnecessary melodrama- mystery elements without stealth sequences- solid minimal score- excellent atmosphereThe Bad:- annoying choices for insert music, but at least they're optional- overpriced for the length of the game- limited graphics options and some performance issuesThe Ugly:- deliberate propaganda at times- restricts user access (One journal entry written by Samantha describes some very tame intimate contact between her and Lonnie and Kaitlin forces the player to drop the letter and refuses to pick it up again.  The developer points this out as if it were something to be proud of and not heavy-handed at all.  It implies female-female sexuality is in some way sacred compared to other relationships.)- crashes on ending credits if the player attempts to skip

content:
Posted: May 5, 2014
												Sadly, I find myself not really sharing the same impressions of most of the professional critique.I have to say that in the last few years I've seen a lot of games like this one, and the problem is that they shouldn't have been games at all in my opinion. The story is ok(less great than what I was expecting from the reviews, though) but the problem is that you have to play through it. In this game, even walking from a room to another is a pain, the character walks unnaturally slow, I don't know why they chose to do so, maybe to add suspense, but it didn't work, at least not for me. You may think that this is something like a point and click game, but there's not one single decent puzzle in the entire game, making it really simple to complete. Sometimes you will have to find a combination for a certain lock, a code that you will easilly find written somewere, nothing that will need you to use the brain to be discovered, and those will be the hardest challenges in the game. Simply put, PLAYING this game is boring, and that will ruin the experience, no matter how great is the story. Probably it could be more entertaining watching someone else's playthroug on youtube, leaving him the boring part and enjoying the story better. This is something that the developers have to understand about this kind of games...if you don't have any clue about a gameplay to put on a good story, make a movie or something like that, not a game.

												Gone Home is a first-person walking simulator from the same team that brought you the Minerva's Den DLC for Bioshock 2. You play as a girl who just got back from Europe. She enters her parents house at the dead of night only to find it completely abandoned. The only clue of your family's whereabouts is a note on the door from your sister asking you not to look for her.First off, let's get the positives out of the way. The house looks pretty good. There's tons of clues, little notes to read, objects to interact with etc.It looks very believable, almost as if people actually live there unlike most video game mansions you find. I almost felt nostalgic while exploring it. It reminded me of the times when you were kid home alone at night and you were so scared of your own house, then you turn on the lights and wonder why you were even afraid to begin with. It's very silly to think about, but that's what I thought about the first few minutes of the game. There's plenty to just mess around like inserting casette tapes in a radio. So much to discover in your first playthrough. In fact, this sole element was what made me really get into the game for a while. There's a lot to discover about the family which sadly takes the backseat from the main plot. It's almost a flaw seeing better plot points being almost completely dismissed in favor for an average love story that really has nothing interesting about it.Unfortunately, those are the only aspects I can give this game credit for. Gone Home has very little gameplay to it. You need find three specific codes which is pretty much the only thing you need to make progress. Alternatively, you can skip it and beat the game in 47 seconds.  I even find it hard to classify this as a point and click as even though it somewhat resembles the genre, it doesn't involve the brainteasers and puzzles its known for. There's no depth to be found here. If you know what you're doing and with the right settings, you can easily beat the game in seconds. It's not that I have anything against the so-called "walking simulator" type of games as I love The Vanishing of Ethan Carter, but even then Gone Home just feels empty and shallow. I understand that the game wants to tell a story. Fair enough, but if there's nothing interesting going on and I discover everything that needs to be discovered on my first playthrough then what's the point? The note on the door you find within seconds of starting up the game has all the answers you really need. A normal playthrough will only take you one hour. It's almost insultingly short compared to any other visual novel or walking simulator I've ever played.So if there's no real gameplay, Gone Home needs to fall back on its story. That aspect is obviously the focus so I'll cut it some slack and say that if the story was good, this game would have gotten a pass. The way it depicts said story is awful though. Once again, I have to remind you that it's a mystery game with no mystery. You find out through voice recordings which is basically an excuse to have the game take place in 90's so the whole thing can be narrated that your sister is in love with another woman. First off, this begs the question, why couldn't this narrative be told through environmental storytelling? That's what the game seems to be designed for and the development team even succeeded in certain area's with their previous project on Bioshock. It would certainly make me think more highly of this game, but that's not how it's done and as a result, it feels more like an audiobook than anything else. The story itself isn't anything to write home about either. Some argue how earthshattering it is to feature a lovestory between two women and how it breaks norms, barriers or something. While it's true that this is mostly uncharted territories for video games (not that lesbians are never depicted in video games), there are millions of books and made for TV movies structured exactly the same way. Replace a few names here and there and you've got Gone Home Part Deux. There's nothing new here at all. Not to mention that the characters are so bland that they might as well have been anything else. They could have been a straight couple in a different decade and the story honestly wouldn't have made a difference. At first, I thought the timeperiod was going to be used to show how homosexuals were treated back then, but it does not take that direction. The prejudice from the parents isn't serious enough  to make me feel anything about these characters which creates a second problem. Their romance is so perfect and happy that you have to wonder what the conflict was supposed to be or why they even bothered telling this story, because as it is, it did nothing for me and considering how it doesn't tackle a lot of problems LGBT-people deal with on a daily basis like prejudice or maybe show us flashes from how much worse it was back then from a historical point of view, it probably won't do a lot for them either.If the developers didn't think that Gone Home was worth the 20 dollars asking price and it was free to play, then I would just deem the game a failure and move on, but this is not the case. They certainly must have thought highly about this game when I can find books or even films for less than half the price with the exact same story. Did I mention it took me one hour to beat this game? That's why I advise you not to buy it. Please understand this. I'm not complaining that it is not a "real video game". Some of my favorite games are essentially visual novels though admitedly still more of a reliance on knowledge and skill. I'm also not saying that it is bad to have women and/or LGBT-characters as your main characters in games nor am I saying that it has to feature combat or something, but this is not the way to do it. Writers take note: when you write a character who is homosexual, don't make that their only personality trait as if that even counts for a personality trait. Most people are you know, people with a developed character. There are much better story driven games on many platforms including Steam.

content:
Posted: August 27, 2014
												So very disapointed with this I must admit. My intial Impressions led me to believe this to be an entirely diffrent game much more like the popular "Amnesia" perhaps or an older game I used to play for the playstation one called "The Necromican" but the more I played I couldn't help but think this game had been misrepresented somewhat. There is very little to no mystery to  this supposed disappearance, the first couple of "clues" I discoverd made it too obvious I thought so I played on thinking to myself there had to be more, that this story is just leading me into a false sense of security, about to take me into this mystery that I was looking forward too but before I knew it I was already at the epilogue. I enjoyed the Exploration in it and the mechanics I can't really fault. It was a disapointment but I look forward to see what the studio will do next i still maintain the opinion that had this game been what was advertised it would have hit the spot for me. Final thoughts. This is not a bad game just misrepresented or rather that is how I felt. It was worth the sale price I payed for it but certainly not the current asking price, it is in my opinion that anyone thinking of buying this should wait until it comes down in price. At the end of the day this is just my opinion of this game based on my experiances while playing, it may differ or will be completely diffrent from others experiances of this game.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I was really, really disappointed by this game. I literally thought the end of the game was the end of the "intro" to the game, and I kept googling how to get to the next part of the game. The entire game was less than 2 hours long. In addition to being extremely short, the game is hardly even a game. There are literally no choices you can make right or wrong in the game. You can't mess it up, you can't die, you can't do anything wrong. If you just click on every interactable items (and there aren't all that many), then you finish the game. The story behind it was interesting enough, but again, I want to be able to fight something, or do a puzzle, or at least choose between two options at some point. I don't really understand the player's role in this game.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2014
												-- 5/10, mostly because of price.- Contains one tiny spoiler.If you heard that Gone Home is severely overpriced and overrated and you're still thinking about buying a copy, whoever told you that is right and deserves a gold star. ('You Tried')Gone Home is a game that you will finish in roughly two hours, even if you backtrack and look at absolutely everything as I did, listen to everything, and pay close attention to every detail. For the time that you play it, if you enjoy a good storyline, you will enjoy Gone Home.However.Gone Home is not worth $20. Luckily, I bought it when it was on sale for $5.It is a 'love story' that ends too quickly and is not ended well. However, the experience building up to the ending is worthwhile and if you have a heart, you'll likely become at least a little bit attached to the main character. (No, not the character you're playing of course! Rather, her teenaged sister who is having one too many problems.)The ending was not what I expected and to be honest, I believe my expectation would have suited the game more! (If you played it, I think we all expected the same thing in the attic.)To sum it up, Gone Home is a short fairly enjoyable experience but along with that, it is also overpriced and in my honest opinion, not immersive enough to play through a second time unless you missed the *SPOILER* sex note *SPOILER* like I did the first go around.

Posted: September 9, 2014
												It's an interesting concept, that's for sure, its kind of original in some regards, but as a game, I really wouldn't recommend it at all.Maybe if you are still in school  and want to make games for a living as an adult, then this would be a good thing to check out, but recommending this so that you can have something to "play", nu-uh.I feel it's kinda pretentious, but that may be influenced by how some parts of the internet exploded with praise for this "game" and it even recieved the VGX award for PC game of the year, beating The Stanley Parable and Papers Please. Why did it win that award? I have no idea, maybe it just tackled a certain subject in the game and thus critics praised it for how cutting edge and forward the game is.If you feel mixed about my review, then by all means buy it and see for yourself. The asking price is way too high considering how many superb indie games are on steam for less than this (Shovel Knight, The Stanley Parable, The Binding of Isaac, to name a few) and how short this experience is.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 25, 2014
Grade: 60/100Difficulty: Can you navigate with WASD and click a mouse? Can you read beyond a 4th grade level?Pros: There are lots of details, and I am jealous of anyone who owns THAT many books and records. There are also some nice 90's references for those of us who grew up in that decade.Cons: The atmosphere makes you feel like something is going to jump out at you at any moment -- but nothing ever does. There is the occasional thunder and a few of the lights flicker a little. But otherwise it's just you and your snooping about the house. Listening to any of the cassette tapes you find is something you do at your own risk. The vocals will make your ears bleed.Replayable: No, because the story is not worth it. In fact, the story is what ruined this game for me. It focuses heavily on the younger sister, who is just your average unhappy teenager who falls in with the ever-in-trouble rebel at school -- and ultimately leads to terrible life decisions and a hugely anticlimactic ending. Do not waste your money on this game unless it is at least 75% off -- you will feel cheated otherwise.

content:
Posted: September 5, 2014
												First off, this game isn't for everyone. It has no action or puzzles and in a sense is basically a walking simulator. For those of you who do not like interactive story games, DO NOT buy this game! For those of you who do, continue reading below. I will also warn whomever is reading this that this review will be quite lengthy, but will hopefully help you decide whether or not this game is for you.I do not play many indie games, so when I saw this game for sale on Steam I thought I would give it a try. You play as a girl named Katie who comes home from a year long trip in Europe to find her house empty. The basis of the game is to "explore" the house and to find out what happened to your family. I say explore rather sarcastically, because even though you have to hunt for clues around the house, the game is very linear and you are forced to follow a set path. The game itself is also VERY short. I took my time to explore the house and I still clocked in at only about 2 hours at the end of the game. You can look it up online but you can literally beat this game in less than one minute if you know what to look for. So for a $20 price tag, this game is akin to highway robbery and even at a discounted price it is tough to justify.Now the story itself I mildly enjoyed. First off, the "main" story revolves around your sister Sam, who turns out to be a lesbian very early on in the story. I personally don't mind the LGBT themes in movies and games, as long as they are not shoehorned in (which usually indicates some sort of agenda versus good storytelling). This game kinda toed the line in that regard, as I actually started to laugh as they made the not so subtle reveal. There are also other storylines that are put in the game for some reason but are not fully fleshed out, leaving the player to wonder why they were ever in the game in the first place. The most prominent example are the whole "exercism" and "psycho house" themes. Now while I realize the developers have said that there is no violence or horror in this game and it is just about exploration, it seems counter-intuitive to create a dark and forboding environment if they were not going to fully utilize it. I really did like how a lot of the story was told by the clues left around the house like letters and notes, and piecing the story together for yourself. I'll also mention that while some of the nostalgia themes from the 1990's were appreciated (I personally enjoyed the numerous X-Files references), the fact that this game is set in that time period really has no effect on the story whatsoever. To sum it all up, I liked this game. However, the underdeveloped story and characters and the extremely short playtime are too big of faults to overlook. Add in the fact that there is no replayablility to this game and the $20 price tag and you have a recipe for disaster. I am glad I did not pay full price for this game and I can guarantee you this review would be drastically different if I had. If you see this game on sale for a dollar or two, I'd say give it a try, but at the end of the day you really aren't missing anything by passing it up.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 9, 2014
												I feel bad giving this game a "Not Recommended". Maybe this isn't the game for me. I can appreciate the attention to detail and the atmospheric conditions, and what the game is trying to represent and convey, but the experience was disappointing to me - I felt no real connection with the story, it came across a little 'rich kids problems' given the setting of the house, this seems trivial but when you are being immersed into an environment, you can't help but notice the pure scale of the house and how it relates to how the main character of the journal lives and feels. I was disappointed there was no real character development of Katie at all really - a few scraps here and there, but never beyond surface level, and even for Sam I just couldn't make that progression in creating an emotional bond with this character (and trust me, it is by no means that I am ignorant to the situation she is in, as I have parallels in my own life I can draw from). Why was there such a build up to an occult/horror undertone and then to drop it completely? The initial feeling of tenseness soon dropped to 'is it over yet?'It didn't help that the game feels poorly optimised, and it was rare that the game played entirely smoothly.There are many interactive story titles breaking the mould in terms of storytelling and immersion - I just felt this didn't quite hit the mark. I would have been shocked to buy this for €20 though - there are books with far more depth in storytelling for half that price, and that's the only thing I can compare this to - an interactive book that has good intentions, and flickers of somthing great, but fails to really capture my heart and mind.

content:
Posted: April 13
												If you're a daydreamer who loves to here stories about  teenagers coming-of-age and realising they're lesbians through discarded notes left all around the house just waiting to be found , then yeah this is a good game.No idea why, but there's was an eerie, sinister atmosphere that always made me feel like something was about to jump out at me. Maybe it's the fact that the house is abandoned, maybe it's the violent storm going on outside, maybe it's the trees banging it against the window or maybe it's just the background music.The voice acting is flawless, however. It's like they took it from a movie. It's very sentimental and progressive and effeminate.But I would recommend.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This story is not about the main character. It is about the main character's sister. That doesn't even remotely change how moving and intriguing the story is. I was feeling pensive. I often enjoy a good story when I'm left to think for a long time, and pulling an all-nighter is an awfully long time to be thinking. I was told that this game had a very good story, and so, I thought I'd give it a try.Even though the sleepiness was trying its best to lure me to bed, I couldn't stop playing this game. I was sucked in. I had to keep exploring. I had to keep solving the mystery. I had to know how it ended. I rarely feel such a strong relation to a character. I knew how she felt. I knew *almost* exactly how she felt ... about school, about parents, and about society. The game sent some major "feels" through me, and I'd be lying if I said I didn't allow some tears here and there. I wish I could say more, but I don't want to destroy the mystery for anyone.It's a short game, and perhaps not worth the full price, but if it's ever on sale, GO FOR IT if you like a good story.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												This game is a series of clues to a mystery that doesn't actually exist. The early game tricks you into further exploration by promising an interesting story, but ultimately there is nothing going on in this house. People are sad, the house is normal, everything is mundane.Gone Home is an amazing atmospheric storytelling device with spectacular voice acting, level design, and pacing for what unfortunately turns out to be a very boring story about a girl's unhappy family that have just stepped out for a bit.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												I really liked this game at first. I LOVED it at first. But, now, I don't think I do anymore. It had a pretty compelling story when I first started. BUT, I actually thought this was a horror game when I started. Then, I found out it's a love story and I was still onboard for it but after I found this out the whole story was predictable. You knew everything that was gonna happen. Also, it's really short. I have beaten the game 3 times to find all the creepy aspects of it and only have 3.4 hours. So, there isn't much gameplay here; in a length sense and game play. The game play is just you walking around the house trying to find out where your sister is. Okay, good enough. But, you find out in the first 5-10 minutes where your sister is. It is way to predictible. I really wanted to recommend this game but...it's just too predictible and there isn't much here. I can't wait to see what else comes from this company but their first game just didn't do it for me.

												I really liked this game but i wouldn't recommend it. The story is great and unfolds slowly. Although sometimes it looks scary or there are scary-ish elements, it's not. It's exploration and minor easy puzzles (figure out lock combinations) and that's pretty much it. For me, spending money on this was like spending money to go watch a movie at a theater; I was entertained for a few hours. If you're looking for replay factory and imporving your skills or character and general heart-racing excitment, this is not for you. If you want to take part of a sort of interactive story book, stop by. This made me laugh a little and yell out at my roommates a little bit of the drama as it unfolded but I realize that it's not everyone's cup of tea. Probably not most people's cup of tea actually.Great game. Not for most people.

												This game is a series of clues to a mystery that doesn't actually exist. The early game tricks you into further exploration by promising an interesting story, but ultimately there is nothing going on in this house. People are sad, the house is normal, everything is mundane.Gone Home is an amazing atmospheric storytelling device with spectacular voice acting, level design, and pacing for what unfortunately turns out to be a very boring story about a girl's unhappy family that have just stepped out for a bit.

Posted: December 22, 2015
												The game is in the year 1995, in 1995 my dad had a cellphone at work, he was a janitor it wasn't that uncommon to have phones, and no one in this family that lives in a mansion and can afford to let their kid go on holiday for a year to Europe has one? Or notepads  made of paper for leaving messages in the hallway like a normal person? It felt like a bit of a stretch that there was no actual message from anyone waiting for her telling her anything about anything when the game starts, they where after all expecting her home, suspension of disbelief I guess...Also turn the thunder off for ****s sake... it got annoying after the 5th one let alone the 50th or 500th, I actually though it took away from the playing experience.Other then that an okay walking and read and look game if you into that kinda thing, nothing special though. Play it if you bored and don't feel like reading an actual book. I'd give it a neutral if I could, but since I can't it gets a no.I took my time and looked at everything and I'd played for 2.8 hours when I finished, it can probably be finished alot quicker if you don't lift, click and read everything. content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Gone Home puts you in the shoes of Kaitlin, a girl who has just come back from a long trip in Europe to find that nobody is home. As you approach the door you find a cryptic note written by your sister, Sam, saying that she has gone and to not come looking for her. The game involves you wandering around a mansion which your family moved into while you were away looking for clues as to her whereabouts.I really enjoyed playing Gone Home. I found the story to be compelling and it was a lot of fun interacting with the different objects around the house.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
												TL;dr: this isn't a survival/horror. It's a commentary on social issues that happens to be in a spooky house.I really liked this game in the beginning. The house, the environment feels rich and authentic. It, simply put, was spooky in a way I hadn't experienced since playing the 7th Guest. Which is awesome. The detail of the items, the feel of the home as a 'freshly moved in' place is extraordinarily well done. Everything is believable and thought out. Little details everywhere reinforce the multiple characters and stories in Gone Home. For the small team that put this together, they should be proud of their work; it is an excellent environment for exploration.As for the story and the game itself.. well... as the game progressed, and the "plot" played out, the whole experience.. thinned out. Suddenly I wasn't alone in a spooky house, I was alone being fed snippets of a story that did not relate directly to me, as a player.Towards the end, it slowly dawned on me that this was not a survival/horror (which, to be fair, I supposed it is not marketed as?) It felt like I started off in a genuinely spooky movie, but ended up in a Lifetime Original. It just felt like I had come in expecting one thing, and about three quarters the way through I realized that the spookiness and eerieness of the game were just incidental. Which totally sapped the suspense out of the rest of the game.That said, I have nothing against the main story (or message, if you will) of this game. I think it addresses important issues, and is genuine and feels real. But in the context of this game, it just feels out of place. Maybe I've played too many games and feel entitled to a certian consistency in gameplay? It is, after all, the developer's right to take a game in any direction they like.I feel like the dev team started with a great idea, wasn't sure how to wrap it all together, and chose to make a social statement rather than continue to work in the direction they started in. But, that's MY feelings, and MY opinion.I would recommend this game if it was marketed differently, but as it is, gives off the vibe of a survival/horror, but turns out to be something else entirely.--bp

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Gone Home is a brilliant game delving into the natural story telling of just being left to your own devices in an empty house. While I could speak all about the incredible, heart touch, story and absolutely speak to how it has touched my own life experiences, I can't help but also speak to the amazing detail that went into all the other stories other than the main one focused on your sister. The mother and father both have intricate stories that are just as amazing and as detailed.Other than that the gameplay it more of that of the point and click type but in a FPS control scheme. It's not for everyone and if you aren't the type of person who is naturally curious then I highly doubt this gameplay will keep you intrigued or wanting to play. If you are then this game is going to feel like a drug to your senses and will reward you for taking that extra second to look in corners.Overall I'd recommend this game to those whom would find exploring an old house filled with stories fun, and to those whom would like a deep story.

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2014
												You are not the protagonist, and Gone Home is not your story. In most games, the players write their own stories: their actions and struggles define the game plot. Not so in Gone Home: this game asks you to explore the stories of other people (your family, mostly, including the psycho great-uncle Oscar). Your impact on these people is zero, because during the game, they're not home. Also, their stories are hidden: you need to find it in odds and ends strewn around the house, and even if you find them all, there'll be a lot left to the imagination (provided you have any).If you're a narcisstic person with no emotional intelligence, this game will leave you cold because it won't be about you, but about other poeple's feelings. If you aren't, you'll enjoy a good teenie "chick-flick" story told from a very different angle. If you're a child of the nineties, it's worth it for amount of love and detail that went into the whole house alone. Rarely have I wandered through a game and felt so immersed.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												Having a hard time recommending this one.  If you really want something different and quick (1.5 hrs) then this is for you, but if you want something thats more of a traditional game then this ain't gonna cut it.  They advertise the game as being a story exploration video game and thats exactly what it is.  You come home from a long trip and you walk around the house finding clues to your family's whereabouts.  You move room to room finding notes and getting a feel for what this family is like until you reach the end of the story. There are no puzzles to solve so the story kind of just tells itself as you enter each area of the house and the story is as simple as the gameplay.The game of the year awards aren't too surprising because the game should be recognized but don't expect anythng stellar.  Although I haven't played The Stanley Parable, based on the demo, I'd recommend that over Gone Home if you want a more entertaining story exploration experience.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												A great novel for the demographic for which it is intended (the LGBT crowd), this novel is too short and too expensive to be worth buying.First off, 2 hours is the average completion time of this novel.  In my play of it, I searched every room, picked up every object, and read every readable piece of paper; all of this, I did in 2 hours.  2 hours is not worth $20.  Only the most popular of movies can get people to fork over $10 to see them on the big screen, and this novel is no blockbuster. This novel, while WELL paced, is for girls with an interest in gay/bisexual relationships--take note this is not a bad thing: Although consumers interested in the game should be aware of this fact in case this kind of topic may turn them off from playing such a novel.Linearly designed, using door keys to block ways, the novel leads you down a straight path.  Yes, there are many rooms and hallways to inspect, but inevitably you will go down specific ones required for you to beat the game.  The only choice the user has is how much time the user wishes to spend looking at things other than the story-required ones.  After examining and using story-required objects the novel opens the next branch of the map.  While this disallows replayability, it is atmospheric and immerses the user into the story well.  It does become repetitive, however.It is a walking simulator (not an inherently bad thing), which means the majority of interaction is walking and looking at things.  You will pick up things and toss them down, and that is how complex it gets, which for a lot of people is quite refreshing.  This simplicity allows the novel to remain casual and not a brain teaser.  The story is not complicated either.  It tells an easy to understand story about girls becoming curious about their sexual orientation, discovering it, and then the user learns about the struggles that come with such a life.In conclusion, It is a fantastic visual novel for those who dig the story.  Sadly, it is not long, nor replayable.  It feels more like chapter 1 of a longer novel.  For someone interested in female gay/bisexual relationships, wait until a Steam sale to buy this for about $5.  For those who are not interested in an LGBT story, this novel is not for you.  It is no GOTY because it short, expensive, and has a small demographic intended to play it.  For these reasons I cannot recommend this novel.For other interactive visual novels, I suggest looking at Dear Esther and Stanley's Parable.  Both of those are admittedly short as well, but they tell interesting stories as well.  I cannot recommend them, either, at their normal prices, but during a sale they are certainly bargains.  So if you like interactive novels you may like them too.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Gone Home is an atmospheric walking simulator that can be finished in a mere hour if you don't search through everything in this grotesquely huge house in the suburbs..Gameplay.The game is presented in first person perspective. You move with wasd and left click to pick up and examine things. You can turn objects by holding down the right mouse button or toss what you're holding by left clicking again. Going through the house, you'll read various documents and letters that explain just why the house appears to be abandoned and you'll solve rudimentary puzzles by gathering numbers for combinations to open various locks. Nothing too strenuous or difficult..Premise/Story.You are Katie, who has just returned home from a trip abroad. You need to figure out where the hell your family has gone and you do so by looting everything. Cupboards, lockers, secret panels--nothing is safe from your prying. The story of where your little sister, Sam, has gone is cute and features the taboo subject of being a lesbian. Please refrain from rolling your eyes I am aware that this was published in 2013. There are a handful of little subplots, but the game play just isn't interesting enough to even take the time to piece them together..Atmosphere. This was the game's strength. The desolate sound of rain battering the old house, creaking floorboards, and that lightning bolt or too that catches you off-guard just adds to it. For me, who hates horror, it was entirely creepy and I had to play with the lights on..Soundtrack.Unimpressive. The ambient sounds were very good. The music was quiet and just sort of faded into the background. The cassette tapes littered through the game were just plain awful..Bottom line. I can't, with a good conscience, recommend this--especially with a 20USD price tag. If you can get the bundled version, this may be good if you're looking for something short with cards.

Posted: December 30, 2015
												Alright, so the game is usually $19.99, but for the Winter 2015 sale it is $5.99. I purchased this game a while back at around $4.99 (iirc) and am now just getting to review it.It is certainly not worth $19.99. The fact the developers think that this game is worth $19.99 is baffling. In all honesty though, it's not worth $5.99 either. I have put 1.1 hours into this game and have beaten it twice. You might be thinking, "Oh, he just sped through the game and tried to beat it as fast as possible so he could dog on it." No. I literally set the mood for this game, it was night, raining and around midnight. Pretty much the same setting as the game so I had extremely high hopes for this game.Before I was about to beat it I convinced myself I wasn't about to beat it because I mean... a $20 game (bought at $5) couldn't possibly end after ONE HOUR after going through everything. Well it did, and the ending is the biggest cop out of all time. The narrative is what is praised, but its an extremely brief narrative with very shallow and thin character development. I realize this game came out two years ago, but the praise it gets boils my blood.tl;dr - game is boring, very little character development, EXTREMELY short game. Maybe buy at $0.99-1.99 to see what the hype was about, but just be warned... it's boring and just not really a good story.

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I'm not sure if I dislike this game so much because of all the glowing reviews it got, but this seems like gamings equivalent of Oscar bait. The environment of the game is just one house. I find this a very interesting and challenging design choice. However, it seems to rely way too much on nostalgia from a period I personally was not alive in. Many praise it for this, but I see it as a somewhat weak trigger.At first glance, it seems like a horror game. This means I played the game in completely the wrong mood, seeing as the shallow story that is actually underlying it really has nothing to do with horror. The story is nicely voice-overed, but seems at many times designed just to cause feelings from, again, reviewers, who have been pushing this social justice thing a lot lately. While I am all for diversity in gaming, it does not excuse lazy design and shallow storytelling. Was the game to be about a boy and a girl, which would honestly work just well, I doubt it would receive the amount of praise it did.I highly applaud the game for its experimenting in storytelling, but I cannot say that I believe it pulled it off well at all. The reviews got me in the wrong mindset, and I would probably have enjoyed it much more if it weren't for them.I'm feeling a strong 5

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												I DON’T RECOMMEND THIS GAME AT FULL PRICEBUY ONLY AT 75% OFF. Gone home is a first person exploration game. Well maybe it’s not a game but more of an experience. There are no puzzles, no challenge and nothing to put your game skills to test here. This “game” is all about exploring a house, looking at items and basically learning more about the people who live in the house and their background.  Without spoiling the story because this is the “ meat” of the game I will have to say that it tries to create an emotional connection with the user but the problem here is that THIS connection is hard to be established on all people who play the game and it depends on their own norms/values. That is also the reason that some people like the game and others don't. Furthermore this game is full of Easter eggs. If you were born in the 80’s just like me you will find a lot of references here. Some items will bring back memories from your childhood. The “game” is all about creating nostalgia but nonetheless it covers a very sensitive topic.Personally the story for ME was not very touching and to tell the truth I enjoyed exploring the house in order to find those 80’s and early 90’s easter eggs. The main story was average and predictable to say the least.Pros: beautiful environment that looks and feels like a real house, lots of Easter eggs, 80’s nostalgia is everywhere,  good voice work, the soundtrack is excellent and the music fits with the tone of the gameCons: main story it’s predictable and boring, there is no real gameplay here, no replayability, the game is only 2 hours long and it’s also very expensive for its duration.FINAL SCORE: 6.5/10I give thumps down just because there is no middle ground in the rating system and because I recommend this game only during sales just for the nostalgia.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
												Okay, I'll elaborate.I don't care if Gone Home is a "game" or not. Whether it's a game, movie, book, or whatever else, it provides a narrative that - despite some flaws - is ultimately worth your time. It suffers from Whedonesque overly-smarmy writing, at the cost of relatability to the characters at times, but it has some very smart ideas about its characters.Gone Home is ultimately "about" homophobia, and the kinds of things that may inspire someone to have that kind of mindset. Sam's character arc is a mostly well-done but pretty boilerplate love story - what's interesting is exploring the homophobia of the other people in her life and discussing the events in their lives that cause them to hold this belief despite knowing and being so close to a homosexual person. Sam's father's childhood abuse is handled particularly well - the game doesn't dwell on his uncle because his abuser doesn't deserve the attention. It's much more focused on Sam's father's survival through the events, and how this tragedy affected his views on homosexuality - which is to say, he's too scarred by his past trauma to even come close to thinking about it. He's literally too afraid to consider being more accepting.The ending is tonally unclear, but maybe it doesn't need to be specific - whether or not Sam's choices turn out the best for herself and the people around her are probably best left to interpretation. It's not the herald of a new age of ♥♥♥♥♥eo shames, and it's not even the best-written "walking simulator" game (that honor goes to The Stanley Parable) but it's an interesting experience that's ultimately well-written."But this game promotes a feminist/homosexual agenda!" "It has no gameplay!" "It's not really a gaaaaaaaaame!"Please remove yourself from my friends list effective immediately.

content:
Posted: January 2
												Gone home is part of the trend of interactive novellas rather than a game per se.  It revolves entirely around the story and keeping you wanting to know the next part of that story.  I would say in both of these regards gone home works exceptionally well.Its difficult to give too much information without spoiling some elements of the story but there are portions which you will find in the form of notes etc around the house which require reading and others which give you verbal information in the form of 'diary like' snippets.  Taking the time to search for extra bits as you go round is definately worth it as it fleshes out a side story of what is happening with other parts of the familys life. Overall I have to say that the voice acting is excellent, the artwork in the house is excellent, the atmosphere is perfect and the story keeps you wanting more.  I played this on Linux and can attest to excellent performance at least on that platform.Given I took my time to examine as much as I could and it took me approximately 2 hours it may be possible to complete this in less than an hour but if you do that you will undoubtedly miss a lot of the nuance and impact of the story.  This is certainly worth experiencing and if you enjoy interactive storytelling as a medium this is a must buy I would say.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												This will be a in depth review on Gone Home, instead of the usual one line joke because I believe the negative reviews for this game are unwarranted. This being said I want to give my personal context, and what games I personally enjoy. I do not usually like Indy titles, though have given MANY a chance. Fez, Meat Boy, ect. I understand why they are liked. But I lean towards story based gameplay.That being said I will start this review.Gone Home starts off with a odd feeling to it. You arrive after a small call home and a general backstory to literally just a empty house. After searching around for a few minutes, you begin to realize that this game is a investigation psychological thriller piece that allows you to go through the home and story at your own pace. The dialogue is well voice-acted, and the physics of the game though can be a bit clunky end up feeling completely natural. The story itself keeps you driven to read, and find more clues to the investigation.If you go hearing spoilers about the game, it will ruin the original experience this title could have delievered for you. If you are coming in to this with no spoilers, and a general idea of the investigative piece. Then you will have a AMAZING time with this game.This game is only for people that want a good story, and something that allows you to tie clues together to form a hypothesis on the plot before its final reveal. This is not Borderlands 2, Fall Out, or something that has story equal to gameplay. The gameplay is a aid towards the atmosphere of the story. Not the other way around.All this being said, it is a amazing game that I am beyond happy with. I WOULD NOT pay full price for this game. It simply is not worth 20$. However if this is on sale for even 50% off, it is a must buy. Extremely happy with the purchase.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2015
												The people complaining about this being a SJW game are completely overlooking what makes this game bad.Absolutely don't pay full price. It wasn't terrible, wasn't good. I spent a good amount of the game waiting for jump scares, or some resolution to the more occult hints throughout the game, for nearly no resolution. One thing this game does well is create an eerie atmosphere.A friend told me there was a lot of "OMG LESBIANS" from fans when it came out. I'm 100% on board with lesbians, but there wasn't much else going for the misleading setup.I had no problem with it being a walking simulator; I enjoyed the exploring and neat layout. I didn't give a damn about the characters. Not a bit. The atmosphre is completely inappropriate for the story its trying to tell.Things this game is:A love storyTelling a love story in an unexpected wayThe love story has lesbians being portrayed in a way that is normal and superfluous, like any heterosexual love story you could findThings this game is NOT:A horror gameInterestingBy the time you realize the setup for the story hasn't been for horror, it's too late. You get the end of the love story, the game still feels creepy, you have a resolution (sort of) without feeling satisfied.It's a time-waster for maybe $5 on sale. Honestly, I wouldn't have paid that much. Maybe like. $0.25.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Incredibly dissapointing.  I had heard so many good things about this game that I decided to pick it up.  In the end it's just a seriously neutered visual novel.  The story itself is OK but really short.  Unlike normal visual novels there are no branching story points.  Gone Home is really just a short novella in a first person wrapper.  Not horrible, but not worthy of the praise it has garnered.Here's what it got right: Atmosphere, the music and the sound were great.  Very fitting for the story's setting.Some places where they stumbled:  The game is going for realism, but it takes place in a silly mansion that wouldn't exist in real life.  The parents subplot is ok but the uncle/ghost subplot is just silly.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I have generally been a fan of non-game interactive stories such as Dear Esther, but Gone Home just doesn't do it for me. I think there is too much of a disconnect between the "gameplay" and the story. The interactive portion is akin to a horror adventure game (Amnesia comes to mind). You are coming home after being out of the country for some time. Upon arrival, you find that nobody is home and the house has a slight eeriness to it. Lights flicker, there's rain and thunder, you are all alone... It's a perfect setup for a creepy adventure. But this is highly contrasted by the story. The story is provided as pieces of a journal that you discover as you walk around and explore the empty house. Without giving too many spoilers, the story is about a teenage romance. Right from this moment, you can probably see my confusion with the non-game: Horror-like environment and gameplay, romance story. It just doesn't fit together. In fact, I would go as far to say that Gone Home doesn't quite know what it wants to be. With that being said, I wouldn't exactly shun Gone Home completely. I think it might be worth picking up if you happen to stumble upon it during a sale, but I don't think it's worth the $20 it's asking for. There are much better non-game interactive stories to experience: The Stanley Parable and Dear Esther are just a couple that come to mind.

It's just a short story basically, nothing mysterious about it. The game pretty much feeds you where to go and what to do, so there's not much brain power used to play it. If you want a not that great bedtime story game, go for it. Otherwise, don't bother. And definitely don't pay more than a couple dollars for it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												Incredibly dissapointing.  I had heard so many good things about this game that I decided to pick it up.  In the end it's just a seriously neutered visual novel.  The story itself is OK but really short.  Unlike normal visual novels there are no branching story points.  Gone Home is really just a short novella in a first person wrapper.  Not horrible, but not worthy of the praise it has garnered.Here's what it got right: Atmosphere, the music and the sound were great.  Very fitting for the story's setting.Some places where they stumbled:  The game is going for realism, but it takes place in a silly mansion that wouldn't exist in real life.  The parents subplot is ok but the uncle/ghost subplot is just silly.

number of helpful: 8 of 14 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												I have generally been a fan of non-game interactive stories such as Dear Esther, but Gone Home just doesn't do it for me. I think there is too much of a disconnect between the "gameplay" and the story. The interactive portion is akin to a horror adventure game (Amnesia comes to mind). You are coming home after being out of the country for some time. Upon arrival, you find that nobody is home and the house has a slight eeriness to it. Lights flicker, there's rain and thunder, you are all alone... It's a perfect setup for a creepy adventure. But this is highly contrasted by the story. The story is provided as pieces of a journal that you discover as you walk around and explore the empty house. Without giving too many spoilers, the story is about a teenage romance. Right from this moment, you can probably see my confusion with the non-game: Horror-like environment and gameplay, romance story. It just doesn't fit together. In fact, I would go as far to say that Gone Home doesn't quite know what it wants to be. With that being said, I wouldn't exactly shun Gone Home completely. I think it might be worth picking up if you happen to stumble upon it during a sale, but I don't think it's worth the $20 it's asking for. There are much better non-game interactive stories to experience: The Stanley Parable and Dear Esther are just a couple that come to mind.

												(SPOILERS AHEAD)I'm not going to critique the narrative in the game, because it's a neat concept, but not neat enough to warrant paying $20 for it (nor neat enough to warrant it being a game). This should have just been a short story instead.When it comes to gameplay (or lack there of), it's just walking and reading. Walking Simulator 2014 basically. This isn't fun in the least. There is NO replayability in the slightest. Not to mention that the game is roughly an hour and a half long. This should have either been a free game, or (like previously mentioned) a short story.Another thing, the game seemed to be playing off of the Survival Horror demographic. Yes, I know it's not Survival Horror, but it's in an empty house with flickering/moody lights. It plays to the demographic, without giving anything close to a game that demographic would enjoy.I can summarize the plot of this game in one sentence:"Your sister is a lesbian, and she left home with her girlfriend."That's it, the whole entire plot. Now, there's no problem with this story, there is a problem in putting it in a game where you can't do anything but walk. Even the Telltale Games (which are only narrative, little gameplay) give you the ability of choices to choose the outcome of the story. Those choices make you feel like you've actually acomplished something, that's a feeling that you can't get from Gone Home.Gone Home isn't a game. It's a bore.1/10

number of helpful: 9 of 16 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 9, 2014
												Gone Home is a barely a video game and is more like a student project demonstrating a bright new idea rather than an offering that should be up on the Steam Store, let alone up for twenty dollars.At its heart, Gone Home experiments with story telling through simple narration and the placement of items.  The stories focus on the protagonist's sister (Sam), her sweetheart, and their upcoming separation as one prepares for college and the other for Basic Combat Training in the US Army.  Their story is told through notes and letters, through narration from the sister, and through the occasional concert stub or band poster.  The protagonist's parents each have a less-developed narrative arc which is told entirely through the things they own and the correspondance they receive.In a way, I would love to sit down the devs of many modern games, point to Gone Home, and say, "That is how you tell narrative with setting!  That is how you write a story of attraction and romance!"  These two aspects are well done, and the level of attention and fidelity to minor details show just how much you can show about your characters just by things like the state of their rooms, the books on their desks, and the clothes they own.  You can learn more about Sam in five minutes glancing about her room than in ten hours of awkward dialog.Despite this one striking feature, ultimately the love story is not enough to support this game.  It's a well-told story, but one you will not want to hear a second or maybe third time.  Nor will you want to explore the house again; having seen the contents once, you will have seen them all.  Suddenly, the one-time trip to explore the house becomes the tedium of doing something rote.  The game advertises there's no puzzles and no combat, and while that makes for an interesting experience one time, once you've picked up a few dozen ticket stubs, high school notes, and books, there really is no reason to engage in that experience again, is there?However, the game is smart enough to realize the player can put together a story on their own.  Sam's story is inescapable, but the stories for your parents are "hidden."  Their tales come out only for a player who pays attention to the clues in the environment.  It's not a great mystery requiring Poirot-like leaps of logic to solve, but it does showcase a beautiful example of how background details can be left in the background and the player can be trusted to find them.  Nowadays, when most games feel a need to focus the player like a laser on ever aspect, it's a nice touch.  It's also a beautiful example storytelling without dialog and without words.  No one is ever seen in the house, but you can tell the awkward dynamics of your family from just a few glances through their things.  Speaking of those awkward family dynamics, great job putting in realistic family tensions.  Most narratives portray families with such operatic, almost comic bonds, while here, the dynamic is much like a real group of flesh and blood human beings.  There's no supreme dysfynction with patricide and matricide, or screaming, juvenile daddy issues, or any of that nonsense.  And it works.  Listen, writers: having an occasional normal family works.Simply put, a game needs teeth.  This does not necessarily mean every game needs to be an FPS, but with no challenge and no element of change, a game has nothing to draw the player back.  Nothing you as the player do in Gone Home matters - you stumble blindly forward, tripping over the solutions to the game until you've collected the right plot coupons and it ends.  Sam's story will be told and all you have to do with it is just keep clicking on things until the game ends.This isn't The Stanley Parable, with its metanarrative about both gaming and working.  This isn't a throwback to the old-school adventure games.  Gone Home is exactly what it says on the tin - a one hour long experience of bumbling through other people's underwear drawers.  While its cute little story is well-told, there's no commentary or larger discussion to be had.  There's nothing here which has a right to ask for twenty dollars.  There's nothing here which should ask for five dollars.  Such a short, simple, unrepeatable experience would fit in a twenty minute student film without wasting my time  opening every sock drawer in the house in case I missed a plot coupon.  Gone Home wants to charge for admission to the show, then gets up there for one good song and calls it a night.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												Gone Home is a game beckoning players to solve its mystery. The moment the player walks into the empty house he or she is drawn in by the stillness of the vacant home. So begins a search to figure out where everyone has gone. The search never leaves the house, but the house is incredibly large and tightly-packed with subtle clues and objects to flesh out the plot. Gone Home doesn't require the player to do any more than explore, so if you're looking for anything more than a story-driven exploration game I'm afraid you may be disappointed. However, Gone Home commits to what it does, and it's that commitment that makes it a wonderful game. On paper the story would seem lackluster, but it's the feeling and voice-acting of the narration of notes littered around the house that help give the game life. You begin to see that all the characters involved are deep and relatable even though you will never lay eyes on them. As you sift through all the belongings of your family you'll become closer with these people that have a lot more going on than you realize. It makes you wonder how much someone could get to know you just by going through your own home. As creepy as it sounds, Gone Home is a game that makes the player think about how these relationships are affecting each other, and ultimately affecting the end portion of the story.Honestly, it's the sound design of Gone Home that heightened the experience for me. The sounds of an empty home during a thunderstorm were oddly chilling even though I knew I had nothing to fear. The crisp dialogue is perfectly cast, and the actors did an amazing job. This is one of those cases where great writing and acting come together to create something truly great. The soundtrack, however, really hit home for me. It's beautifully done comes in at just the perfect time for emphasis to what's happening in the story. I have the soundtrack on my phone as we speak, which is only something I do with the my favorites.I love simple walking simulators that allow you to relax and enjoy a great story. Gone Home is well made, and there's a lot of love in it. If you enjoy a good story with relatable characters and a little exploration, you should pick this one up. However, be warned that Gone Home only lasts a couple hours unless you REALLY dig deep into the environment. As much as I love it, I would suggest getting it at a discount.

number of helpful: 11 of 20 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												A story-based adventure/exploration game with very little story and very little game. You are a teenage girl, coming home after a year abroad, to find the home empty. So what does a girl do in this case? She goes rummaging in the trash for notes about what could have possibly happened. It is this implausability that really detracted from the mood the game was aiming for. All you do is rummage through the house for written notes from various members of the family that conveniently allude to the plot. Interacting with some objects/notes allows the player to hear narration from the sister, a key figure to the storyline. The story is very forgettable, however, I do commend the game for effective use of multiple red herrings (some of the best I've seen in a videogame).

number of helpful: 12 of 22 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Why are you exploring this large empty house? Mostly to figure out what happened to your sister. But the story is dull and it doesn't tell what happened in the past through the environment like it's supposed to.  It's narrated to you through your sister's voice... when there is no clear way to explain why you are able to hear it (you can turn this off, but the game becomes even more boring because it feels emptier and lifeless). The biggest weakness in this game is that there are no characters to interact with and nothing for you to do with the information you find. This is a step back from other great adventure games like Blade Runner and The Last Express. Those games put you in a role where understanding the perspectives of the other characters was very useful to your end goals and would dramatically affect your actions/decisions. Thus, I actually gave a♥♥♥♥♥♥about what happened and went looking through every single piece of the environment to make sure I didn't miss anything.Not impressed at all.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This was one of the most boring burglary simulators I have ever played. There was no sneaking mechanic and the house you rob had almost no jewelry or high end electronics. The worst yet is that the game dangles the sweet carrot of a top of the line laserdisc CD player in cryptic notes which is nowhere to be found! In addition to the aforementioned missing sneak ability, you had almost no way to keep track of all your plunder. I had to pile up all my freshly stolen coffee mugs and toilet paper rolls by the front door! On the positive side, the difficulty is low since the family remains blissfully unaware of your felonious intent throughout the course of the game.I would recommend this game if you want to feel out a possible career in crime, but are afraid of going for a real score the first time.

Posted: September 13, 2015
												I went into this completely blind, only knowing that it had recieved tons of positive press and was devoloped by members of the extremely underated sequel to the original Bioshock.  After completing it I cannot understand why it has garnered the praise that it has.  I can appriciate a Dear Esther style exploration game that is simply ambient story telling, but what we have here is a poorly written, preditcable story that tries its hardest to achieve emotional resonance with the player whilst simultaneously having the (literal) depth of a high school freshman's diary.  All the while the game baits the player with red herrings that are far more interesting than what is actually there.I went in expecting great things, and came out utterly disappointed.  I hope I enjoy their next project more than I did this one.

content:
Posted: September 2, 2016
												I'd describe this as a disappointment simulator, but the disappointment I feel is very real. $20 for an hour long game that consists soley of you rummaging through shelves of junk collecting pieces of a cliche "love" story that could be told in under 2 minutes. The game had promise at the beginning when you start in a tiny world that stands out as so empty and quiet. There is potential for a good mystery story with a few elements of horror. But then you realize its so empty and quiet because the game is severely lacking in content and when the actual plot is revealed it so underwhelming that you have to stop and wonder several times if you had missed something. I can't believe it has so many positive reviews."Gone Home is the greatest video game love story ever told.” -The New York TimesSeriously who the hell wrote that about this game? The game was one hour long, how did they possibly get invested into any of the characters? Have they played a video game before?Zero replayability value. Zero depth. Don't waste your money.

number of helpful: 18 of 34 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												You know those quiet moments in, say, a Bioshock or a Fallout?  Where you get to take a break from the action and just walk around somebody's abandoned house, collecting audio diaries and figuring out what happened here?  The poingnat, sort of sad story of exctly WHY this house is abandoned and free to be rummaged through by the likes of you?  If I'm being honest, those moments are among my favorite, so one of the Bioshock devs going indie and making a game consisting of literally JUST that scratches a definite itch for me.  People tend to criticize this as a "non-game," and they're not completely incorrect.  If you rummage behind a bookcase, say, you won't find money or ammo, just a half-full bottle as a quiet indicator of how Dad is coping with his failed writing career.  It's short and on rails and there's not really anything you can do to change the outcome, but this game has so much heart and emotion going for it that I've got to recommend it.  The ending made me teary-eyed and, if it's the sort of thing you're into, it is absolutely chock-a-block with 90's nostalgia.  Get it on sale to avoid any buyer's remorse over the brevity, but do get it.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2015
												I just finished this so I want to vent.Note: If you want a 'game', don't buy this. It's not a 'game'. I'm not giving this a thumbs down because it's not a 'game', but because it's crap as an...open-story type idea (a shame; I wanted to be pleasantly surprised)The atmosphere is great. The concept is fairly good. Then it all falls down.  You walk around and interact with items which tell you parts of a story. There is supposedly some huge plot twist in this story, but you find it out in the first 15 minutes and it's really not that exciting. There is an inventory system for the maybe 3 items you find in the game. You then walk around and click on things in a house for roughly 50 minutes, then the story ends, just like that.The story is plain boring and you are never given a reason to care. There is no emotional attachment. It's also insultingly short. There's all this stuff you can find about your father, or the supposed 'psycho' house, or ANYTHING...but nope, it's 'your sister falls in love'.Pretentious and a total waste of my £1.70 other than to finally have proof that this is garbage.

Posted: December 7, 2016
												An okay interactive story that is criminally overpriced; I beat it without guides in 57 minutes. This is a complete and absolute ripoff at anything more than $5.Now, the game.This is basically an interactive story that has you wandering around a house finding items to interact with in order to unlock voiced journal entries to read. That's it. Point, click, listen, credits. There's no challenge here nor any real sense of gameplay. This is something you play for the story, plain and simple.I'm not going to say that I dislike this game because it's an interactive story; I enjoyed The 39 Steps even though it was an interactive story, but it was because it was a good story, suspenseful and exciting in some parts and well-written. Gone Home generally has none of this. I can't really say much about the story without spoiling it, but trust that this story seems to be targeted towards teenagers.This is definitely a game that can be skipped, as the asking price is absolutely ridiculous, and you could probably watch someone speedrun the story on Youtube in 15-20 minutes to view the entire experience. No reason to buy this.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												To experience a story just by discovery and reading with no violence or other characters actually around can be amazing if done right. Gone Home is one of those experiences. I wasn’t sure what to expect when starting up Gone Home. I didn’t read much on it before getting it just thought it looked cool and said why not.You are Katie Greenbriar who has just arrived home after been abroad for a year. Unfortunately no one is home to greet you but it’s not really a bad thing either. The story is told through exploration and discovery. Letters scattered throughout the house written and narrated by your sister are spoken with such emotion and feeling that just sucks you in. It was wonderful hearing her talk about how she falls in love with a girl who is her best friend and the issues that came along with that and just growing up.You can also discover the stories of you mom, dad, and an uncle who is deceased by things you pick up through the house. Dad getting some success as a writer and losing it. Mom seeming to be lonely and maybe having an affair. Uncle supposedly haunting the house you live in. It really makes you feel like you’re really there doing it in real life.Almost everything in the game is interactive to deepen the immersion. Turn lights on and off, open and close drawers, and listen to music from cassette tapes you find. Find secret passages through the house to expand on the stories. Sound in the game is fantastic with the sound of rain and thunder outside while you wander around the house. I could have sworn I even heard other sounds at times which may have been a ghost. There’s no violence or interaction with other characters, just some wonderful stories to discover all while having a nice relaxing time. Only problem I have is there’s not lots more to discover and keep me sucked into this world. So try it out when you have a few hours to spare and see if you have an experience to remember.Bear Rating: 9.5/10
