content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
Walking isn’t a GameThe walking simulator, it’s strange genre isn’t it?I mean, it doesn’t sound very appealing,  Just walking around, looking at stuff.There’s nothing to hide behind, no handily positioned crates, no half height walls, in fact there’s nothing to hide from, not a bad guy in sight (or a good guy for that matter).A game devoid of characters where you walk around and look at things....Sounds a bit dull doesn’t it?That was my attitude until I finally sat down and took the time to play, no, to experience Gone Home.It’s an ExperienceGone home isn’t a “game”, it’s an experience.It’s a journey of discovery, of piecing together fragments of a delicately woven story waiting to be told.It’s about atmosphere and contemplation; it’s makes you think.If you’re the sort of player that skips through the text in games, or hits escape to rush past all those boring cut scenes, then I suspect Gone Home isn’t going to be something you’ll enjoy.Which is fine, there’s nothing wrong in knowing what you like, grab your controller and go play another round of Call of Duty, this title isn’t for you.However, if you read through all the books inside the Elder Scrolls games to add flavour to the plot, If you enjoy the law behind the Dragon Age titles, in short, if you enjoy a good story and like to immerse yourself in the atmosphere of the tale being told then you’re missing a gem if you haven’t played Gone Home yet.A House is not a HomeThe premise is a simple one, you’ve returned home after a year of travelling only to find the family house empty.Everything is dark and quiet; the expected hustle and bustle of family is eerily absent.Where are your parents and your little sister?Why isn’t someone there to welcome you back?Standing in the hallway, travelling bag at your feet.You’re all alone, the only person in an empty house.This is where you journey starts, is that note on the door...But it is a characterYou might be the only person in the game, but you are not the only character.The house itself is your whole world whilst playing Gone Home and every nook and cranny is crammed full of character.There are notes, diaries, letters and countless other more subtle clues for you to find as you explore, each of which will help you piece together what has been happening whilst you were away.Every element of the house, every detail on the fixtures and fittings has been so lovingly crafted that you can’t help but feel completely immersed as you  journey through the various rooms.The Real WorldThe quality of the writing and voice acting is stellar.The ever present thunderstorm raging outside and the occasional flickering light all add to the eerie feeling of the place.Every inch of this title exudes atmosphere.Nothing feels over the top, or exaggerated, it all just seems so plausible, so intimate and so real.Fading CenturyIt’s also worth noting that this game is set in the mid 90’s, a time when I was a teenager myself.For me this setting carries with it such a huge sense of nostalgia, a feeling of going back to my own teenage years, it makes me want to wrap myself up in the experience like a big comfy duvet and never leave.UnspoiledGone Home is a difficult title to explain in a review, every element of the narrative beyond what I’ve already told you is a discovery to be unearthed, a jigsaw piece of the various family members’ struggles over the last year.The magic, the sense of fulfilment comes from discovering these things for yourself.The interwoven tapestry of the lives you’ll discover in Gone Home are too special to be spoiled here.You Can Go Home Again.If you’re looking for an intimate, nostalgic and engrossing journey to entertain you for a few hours then you’re unlikely to find better than Gone Home.If you like the sound of what you’ve read then why wait?It’s time to go back to ’95, open the front door, drop your travel bag on the floor and take a breath.It’s raining outside and there’s a house full of family secrets to explore.It’s time to Go Home.( To view the full review (and others) please take the time to visit http://www.review-well.com/ )

number of helpful: 32 of 62 people (52%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												Lesbians 10/10Seriously though, you can listen to a Talyor Swift song (and pretend shes singing about a girl not a boy) and get most of the story here.New girl moved to a new school and life is so hard and no one gets me! Oh turns out im a lesbian and im totally going to run away with this chick I have known for like 3 months and ♥♥♥♥ my parents they dont get me!The graphics are alright but nothing to WRITE HOME about... Ha. You would think that only having to design 1 house would mean that the devs would put more details in the game and re use less things. It would seem this family loved their dressers and bookshelves so much that they bought them same exact ones and scattered them through the house!They also have the same 'random clutter of letters and papers' that they use over and over. The clothes in the draws are downright laughable. Seriosuly. Google them. They have a few tapes and such you can put in and listen to but seeing as my taste in music isn't♥♥♥♥♥♥ I pulled them out and burned them with fire. (In my mind)There are a large number of letters/notes that are written in what I like to call 'doctor's writing'. Which means that you cant bloody read them. A very important feature is missing from this game that hurts the expirence a great deal. That would be the ability to transfer messages on letters and such to a simple typed format overlayed over the note for people that dont want to take 3 years the break the code of what these people are writting. It also suffers from to many narritives. You have about 5 stories going on at once that you are piecing together and it gets a tad confusing trying to keep names together as the diary entries only track Sam's letters and no one elses. In fact it seems you learn more about everyone else. Almost nothing is learned about the playable character other than we went on a trip to Europe and places and we are 3 years older than our sister.There are very little physics to speak of. You can pick up and throw a few items in the game but the physics are some of the worst I have seen in a while.To top of the insult we have the game bearly clocking in at an hour for someone that hasn't played it before and read most of the notes that werent complete chicken scratch. There isn't any replayability for this either. That means you are paying a Hamilton for an hour. I would say you are better off just buying a Taylor Swift album which will last longer, gets the same message accross, and at least is a nice voice to listen to. (I know that was the second time I mentioned her but this story just made me think of Taylor Swift so damn much.)For what its worth the voice actor for Samantha does a pretty good job and does bring a little emotion to an otherwise cringeworthy story. Thats about the only good I can say though.Also who just walks into their parents house and goes through all their♥♥♥♥♥♥ Wouldn't a normal person just go to bed or wait for someone to come home?...Or Go home rather... Ha....

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												Gone Home tells the story of a young woman coming home in the nineties. Her sister is supposed to be there as their parents are away but with a home in the dark, with the sister missing.... What happened? Which are the mysteries? Are you ready for the scare of your life?Well, it's just a point and click game, visiting rooms, finding the story of your sister, the music she likes, her rebellion against the society in the nineties, her friends, her hobby....The graphics are correct but the ambiance... I was really on my toes and watching my back, expecting a paranormal entity to get me.... until the end.*cough* Well, I managed to scare myself for nothing anyway *cough*The soundtrack is pretty good too. And discovering the struggling of the young woman is interesting. Because her story is still lived by millions. And that's interesting.I think I wouldn't have enjoyed Gone Home so much if I hadn't set in my mind that something will appear out of the blue and scares me. But in your house, with nobody, with locked rooms, in the dark, what do you expect? Horrible things.True, the game is overpriced: 20$ is perhaps a little much. So wait until there is a good deal, like today (-88%).

content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Gone Home is not your usual ''run-and-gun'' or ''explore, level up, evolve'' game. Many people won't give it a chance, because the gameplay is just too poor.However, I couldn't help myself but finish this game, solely because of the amazing storyline. I felt from the beginning that the story was going to be a good one, and I was right. Now, obviously, not everyone will share my opinion. I see that most voted reviews describe it as a bad game, almost everyone saying the story wasn't thrilling either.As such, I recommend you should buy this game on sale and only if you like being told a story, while you're not doing much, otherwise you might regret your purchase.I don't have much else to say about the game, as it may turn up as potential spoilers. I'll let you figure out, if you are interested.Pros: +the storyline was very interesting and kept me wanting to find out more; it's one of those ''collect all pieces of the journal and then read them in the correct order to understand the story'';+atmosphere was perfect, in my opinion; you hear the storm outside the house and the noises you're making while interacting with objects are accurate (oh dear, pickup the cassettes and put them in the radio whenever you have the chance);+ the secret passages;Cons: -the gameplay is lacking features; you can only walk around and pickup/activate notes and objects;Personal rating: 75/100 - Good

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Gone Home is a subtle, perfectly paced family home mystery that will send chills down your spine. This is one of those beautiful, smartly made games that only come along once a year. What it lacks in difficulty and length it makes up entirely for in grace, beauty and substance. You play the role of Kaitlin, a young adult who has just come home from Europe, only to find her family is missing with no further explanation, no intitial backstory, and no expository dialouge. I can't say much more about it without ruining the main premise, or any of anyone's vast intricate lives revealed through their items, but I will say everyone has a history in this family, and an intresting one at that.The simple yet stunning graphics are to be commended in a company so small, but still pale in comparison to some of it's indie big brothers, such as Dear Esther, but the original artwork and music is beautifully crafted and placed throughout the story. You can see the amount of work Fullbright has jammed into this somewhat small (two hour) game of exploration.The narration given by Sarah Robertson (Sam) is something to be commended, and generally sets the beautiful, yet creepy atmosphere, and lends to the ending being all the better (crazier and more unexpected). After seeing the attic (dark room), I guarantee you will get chills running up and down your spine for a few hours to come. Parentheses.All and all, the is a great game, even if it is a few dollars, euros, pounds, or shillings too expensive. It's simple, it's short, and it's horrifyingly beautiful, Gone Home gets a 8.5 out of 10. Hopefully Fullbright branches out into this genre, creating larger and more chilling settings and tales.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2015
												I'm happy I bought this game on sale because I was completely disappointed when I finished it.  It took me about 3-4 hours (and a few walkthrough tips) and the ending just felt so anticlimatic.  I will explain as best as I can without including any spoilers. Over the years I've played a lot of games with a storyline that requires you to explore, complete puzzles, etc. to solve the mystery and finish the game.  I'm including all the Nancy Drew mystery games I played when I was younger too.  Well...this game kinda sucked compared to those other ones.  At first though, it seems like it's going to be really cool.  The whole atmosphere of the game is this amazingly creepy mansion, in the middle of the night, with a wicked thunderstorm going on outside.  If you wear headphones while you play it really helps immerse you in the game, with all the weird noises and sounds that surround you as you investigate the house.  However, I think it's misleading because the actual storyline itself, wasn't scary or intense, and you realize this pretty early on as you begin to understand more.  It was an interesting storyline but it was predictable in the end. I felt like there was all this buildup and then...well, you know how you watch a movie and it really keeps your attention and you're enjoying it and then it ends and you think, "Really? That's it??".  Yeah, that's how I felt when I finished this game.  Who knows though, maybe I missed stuff in the story that would have amped up the creepy part (beyond the actually house itself).  Frankly though, I have no desire to play again and bother trying to find out.

content:
Posted: September 6, 2013
												A short, enjoyable tale about family, friends, and lovers. You take the place of Katie, the eldest daughter of a family of four who has returned from studying abroad in Europe for the past year. You return home to an empty house your family inherited while you were away. In an FPS discovery/journey style game, you must locate and decode clues around the enormous house to find out what exactly happened to your younger sister, and where your parents are.It is a gem of an indie game, and was enjoyable, heartfelt, and relatable from start to finish. I definitely recommend picking this game up for the unique experience, and don't be surprised if you finish it in a couple hours.

content:

												Alright, so it's time to review this highly critically acclaimed game. First of all I'm gonna say that I would probably neither give the game a thumbs up or a thumbs down but more like something in between. Since I can't do that it's gonna be a thumbs up. Im gonna give the game props for telling a sweet little love story that hits close to home, without the use of cutscenes or dialogue but through interaction with the environment. The kind of metamorphosis between gameplay and narrative that I really would like to see in more games - You can tell the inspiration these guys took from BioShock after they left 2KGames. The detail put into the game; The 90s pop cultural references to famous rock bands, tv shows, movies and books alike did well for the immersion. I'm a big fan of games like Gone Home that encourages exploration in order to provide further exposition to the overarching plot. There are so many items you can interact with in the environment and visually it looks beautiful. This is what I'd like to see in more adventures games, and horror games, alike. Bigger emphasis on exploration and interaction with the environment that made up for the game's rather short length, which ended up being almost 5 hours of game time for me. This is what drags the game down for me. It was incredibly short for an adventure game, but the developing team was small in size, nontheless, and it felt more like an experiment for something greater - Because Gone Home could be so much more! The exploration is pretty much all there is to this game, combined with the short length, it's not worth the high price it originally was set to before it went on sale. I ended up paying only 6 euros, which was fair enough for me. It was 6 euros worth my time. I hope to see more from these guys in the future.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Gone Home is a subtle, perfectly paced family home mystery that will send chills down your spine. This is one of those beautiful, smartly made games that only come along once a year. What it lacks in difficulty and length it makes up entirely for in grace, beauty and substance. You play the role of Kaitlin, a young adult who has just come home from Europe, only to find her family is missing with no further explanation, no intitial backstory, and no expository dialouge. I can't say much more about it without ruining the main premise, or any of anyone's vast intricate lives revealed through their items, but I will say everyone has a history in this family, and an intresting one at that.The simple yet stunning graphics are to be commended in a company so small, but still pale in comparison to some of it's indie big brothers, such as Dear Esther, but the original artwork and music is beautifully crafted and placed throughout the story. You can see the amount of work Fullbright has jammed into this somewhat small (two hour) game of exploration.The narration given by Sarah Robertson (Sam) is something to be commended, and generally sets the beautiful, yet creepy atmosphere, and lends to the ending being all the better (crazier and more unexpected). After seeing the attic (dark room), I guarantee you will get chills running up and down your spine for a few hours to come. Parentheses.All and all, the is a great game, even if it is a few dollars, euros, pounds, or shillings too expensive. It's simple, it's short, and it's horrifyingly beautiful, Gone Home gets a 8.5 out of 10. Hopefully Fullbright branches out into this genre, creating larger and more chilling settings and tales.

To me, as it is, Gone Home did not live up to it's hype nor reception. [3/10]

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												This game received a lot of love from critics when it came out, initially resulting in an over 90% metascore. Most critics praised it for being unconventional, experimental, emotional and unique. While some gamers agreed, a large part of the user community didn’t seem quite as excited about Gone Home, calling it “boring”, “not even a game”, “too short and still a waste of time” or simply “too expensive for the content you get”. Gone Home apparently is one of those love-it-or-hate-it games.I’m also having a hard time calling narrative-driven games actual “games”, since there is hardly any gameplay or challenge to be found. All you can do is walk around, click on objects and crouch while you figure out the story. That’s why I also understand people who call it boring, because there is just not much happening on the screen. And yes, it is short; very short. Even searching the whole house and reading every letter and scrap hardly got me two hours of gameplay with a replay value close to zero. So yes, its standard price is way too expensive for the content you get, so I waited until it was on sale. And I didn’t regret the purchase. At first I just really enjoyed that good old 90s nostalgia which made me immediately miss my own good old times. The overall atmosphere is pretty decent, although it might come along as to horror-y for a game that has absolutely no horror in it. Sometimes it gave me the impression to get jumpscared any minute, which just felt a little out of place for a love story. Since I want my review to be free of spoilers, I won’t give you too many details about the story itself. Let’s just say I found the story wasn’t as original or daring (when it comes to the topic of homosexuality) as some people said it would be. It’s just another love story in my opinion and love stories are not my cup of tea by any means. However, I still found it very touching at some moments. The monologues are very well written and the voice actress reading them with a beautiful voice and the fitting amount of emotion does a fantastic job in helping you imagine how things developed for the characters. Creating such an immersion without much actually happening on screen is something not many games can pull off.I enjoyed this game a lot and I’ll probably think about it for quite some time, but I still have to say that 20 € is just too much for two hours of gameplay. Gone Home might probably have prevented a lot of the hate it got if the price wasn’t so high in the first place. So wait until it’s on sale and have a good time if: -	You enjoy exploring an environment and unwrapping a story-	You enjoy (love story related) emotions in a story-	You enjoy reading and listening to monologues in a game-	You don’t mind the lack of actual gameplay or challenges-	You don’t mind a game being short

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I have nothing but spoilers.I have a friend whose 14-year-old got angry when she saw the PFLAG float at Pride this year because she felt that these parents were "making it about them." She's grown up in a zeitgeist in which she can take for granted that LGBT kids have widespread social support, without realizing that PFLAG exists because this hasn't always been the case, and without realizing that she has the good fortune to live in a part of the country where parents support their gay kids. This game is such an amazing summation of what it was like when I was in grade school and high school, the challenges me and my friends faced. I hope that LGBT kids play this. It's an artifact of our history, beautifully delivered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A disclaimer is in order: This is not a game. The only meaningful choice is whether you continue to explore, or stop. There are no opponents, and the only obstacles are a handful of locked doors, the keys to which appear as you progress. Rather this is a work of digital fiction, a set of character studies told through the letters and keepsakes that they have acquired, through the exploration of a virtual world and through connections in the mind of the observer.Without actually including any of them, the story presents us with several multifaceted cast members and the problems they face in life, work, love and family with a respect that feels at odds with an inherently voyeuristic aspect of the situation. The way it manages to touch on sensitive and dark issues tactfully, and with compassion even for those in the wrong, reflects a meaning of ‘mature’ that more mainstream games often overlook.There are some flaws: a bit of railroading and one illogically locked door; an overuse of some props and inconsistent decisions about what is or isn’t interactive; and an occasional disconnect between those props, and sections of the story. None of which should impede anyone who didn’t lose interest in the first paragraph.

												This is an amazingly crafted game. Coming home to an empty house, you are looking for clues as to where your parents and you sister is.The game is both tense and horrifying as you slowly uncover the secrets thorugh (voiced)diary entries which is scattered thorugh the house. The game managed managed to keep me playing the entire way through and the tension did not decline at all. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This game was excellent.   Although a bit short for the price(I recommend waiting for a sale to pick it up like I did).   But that's not why you're reading this.  The storyline is incredible.   You're Katie.  You come home from Europe to find an empty house and a letter pinned to the door from your sister saying "Don't come find me".    This starts an immersive investigative journey through the house.   It takes place in the 90s,  so the VHS tapes and cassettes are there!.   A lot of throwbacks to those days as well,  so I would recommend being old enough to "get" that time.   The main story focuses on your sister Sam and her whereabouts.   Although side-stories and plotlines involving your mother and father run concurrent to the main story as well.   There are no objectives or waypoints.   Progression in the game relies on human curiousity.   I personally just went exploring in the house and the game subtlely guides you to the next location,  you never quite feel guided but you are.   Being thorough and anal in searching each rooms turns up interesting tid-bits on the occupants of the house,  both past and present so search everything.  Atmospherically the game does well,  it's taking place in the middle of a massive thunderstorm,  so rain, thunder and lightning blanket the house,   there are creaks and eerie sounds throughout,  and some interesting moments with lights.   Playing this at night,  the atmosphere of uncertainty and the fear of basements comes into play(lights!). All in all it was an exciting journey.  I enjoyed it.   It's not for people with low attention spans,  and if you aren't enthralled by gameplay lacking action and gunplay,  this isn't for you.   But the story,  and the very subtle ways you develop bonds with the characters you are trying to find makes for an emotional trip in trying to find them.   You should all play this game at least once.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Gone Home has an engrossing story that's mildly depressing.It's a short game, but worth the extra exploration of observing objects to gather an idea of what is going on with the protagonists' family and their personal lives. The central character that you gather info on is your sister, Sam, whom is supposed to be home, but is gone...home. Get it? She's gone from her home, that's why the game is called Gone Home; that, and the house is completely empty of human life, except for you, Katie, the elder sister/female protagonist.I do commend the writing and narrative that the developers took the time to flesh out. You get a proper character examination through finding documents, how your father is a struggling writer, your mother is a newly named Forest Conservationist, and promiscuous. And your sister shares a revelation that Katie probably knew about, but shares her emotional experience through the narration.The graphics are modest and humble as they're clearly not the centerpiece of the game, it's not drooling in high resolution textures or particles like Metro 2033, but the models and lighting and textures get the job done. The audio is near perfect, from the ambient soundtrack that plays at a minimal volume, to the harrowing narration, and the 90's grunge music played by some local Portland bands. Gameplay is about as simple as it gets, walk around and click on stuff. Really, you can pick up and examine coffee mugs and ask yourself ten seconds later, "Why did I pick up that coffee mug? Is this a dream? No, this is what my life has become."8.0/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												A disclaimer is in order: This is not a game. The only meaningful choice is whether you continue to explore, or stop. There are no opponents, and the only obstacles are a handful of locked doors, the keys to which appear as you progress. Rather this is a work of digital fiction, a set of character studies told through the letters and keepsakes that they have acquired, through the exploration of a virtual world and through connections in the mind of the observer.Without actually including any of them, the story presents us with several multifaceted cast members and the problems they face in life, work, love and family with a respect that feels at odds with an inherently voyeuristic aspect of the situation. The way it manages to touch on sensitive and dark issues tactfully, and with compassion even for those in the wrong, reflects a meaning of ‘mature’ that more mainstream games often overlook.There are some flaws: a bit of railroading and one illogically locked door; an overuse of some props and inconsistent decisions about what is or isn’t interactive; and an occasional disconnect between those props, and sections of the story. None of which should impede anyone who didn’t lose interest in the first paragraph.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2016
												I have nothing but spoilers.I have a friend whose 14-year-old got angry when she saw the PFLAG float at Pride this year because she felt that these parents were "making it about them." She's grown up in a zeitgeist in which she can take for granted that LGBT kids have widespread social support, without realizing that PFLAG exists because this hasn't always been the case, and without realizing that she has the good fortune to live in a part of the country where parents support their gay kids. This game is such an amazing summation of what it was like when I was in grade school and high school, the challenges me and my friends faced. I hope that LGBT kids play this. It's an artifact of our history, beautifully delivered.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
												I know some people knock this title for being a non-game, but I loved the experience I had with this (along with my next choice, The Stanley Parable).  Some compare Gone Home to Dear Esther, but coming from someone who was incredibly disappointed with DE, I'm happy to say Gone Home gives you enough player agency that you never feel like you're just listening to a tour guide on rails.  As a teenager in the 90's, there was something magically nostalgic and familiar (and creepily voyeuristic) about the exploration of a large house that simulated the period so well.  Sure, some of the story elements are pretty contrived, but overall it was great to organically see the story come alive for me through all of the notes, receipts, diaries, etc in the house.  You could pick up pretty much any object in the house, each lovingly rendered in 3D for you to inspect and rotate, even if most of these were not impactful to the plot.  I actually found the narrative to be pretty disappointing in the end, but Gone Home was more about the journey for me than the destination.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												This is a game for GIRLS.......no really, I have two sisters and I know this was made in a female's mindset. Given, if I was a woman, I would have loved this game. It is filled with emotion and tension. A drama, if you will. Unique and rare in the gaming world, the characterization and descriptive aspects are prime. You will frantically search every inch of this amazingly detailed and eerie house. Playing as Kaitlin who soon arrives home from being away, only to find no one there. This game has a driving story that will have you looking in every inch of this house for answers. Given the unique nature of this game, I will recommend it. As I stated before, this was made for girls and many people buying it on Steam will be disappointed, should they not understand the concept of the game. Teenage girls in particular are complicated enough, and when Kaitlin starts to look more into her sister throughout the story, that is when the game really gets dramatic. Overall I would give the game a 6/10 in terms of general presentation. There is only one thing to do the whole game and that is search. Instead, this game aims to tackle the player's emotions directly and really doesnt focus on gameplay. I have no doubt that if my sisters or girlfriend had played it, they would have been brought to tears by its gripping nature. As a manly man, I cant say I have the emotional capacity, to appreciate the message it is trying to project; And for that I can only say "Try it for yourself."

content:
Posted: April 23
												Gone Home is about a story of two sisters. Samantha is stuck at home while her sister, Katie, is off traveling the world. So she writes down her every thought to share with her sister when she gets back. However when Kate arrives home the house is empty. There’s a note on the front door stating that Sam left for some unknown reason.This is a touching story. It purely represents how people can’t ever really go home again and expect life to be the exact same as when they left. It slowly, but bluntly, tells you how time changes everything and pushes people forward, or even away from each other. The game is every blatant about this with the many clues it leaves around. However it is the very definition of first world problems and is slightly riddled with stereotypical teen angst groaning you’d find in any American’s 1980s teen movies, but without any actual reason for conflict.At first I was intrigued because it gives a somewhat approving approach to letting me be a completely voyeur into someone’s family. As I wondered around I would get to read into each persons life and their problems. This ability only poked at my curiosity to go further. Even the storm outside the house made the dark hallways seem somber rather then creepy. With a few steps here and there it opens up other parts of the house and even shows you secret entrances and old remnants of the previous owner of the house. This was intriguing to only a limited extent.Then there are other parts of the story that are just completely bland. There’s multiple clues lying around that would have suggested a troubled marriage or the parents having trouble dealing with their more rebellious daughter. However I found myself not caring, because I would only be able to find 1 or 2 notes on what one parent thought about the situation. The other parent (most of the time this was the father) would be completely left out by the fact that there wouldn’t be anything of his to read or analyze.Other times the clues were handwritten notes that were completely illegible. Want to find out about the house and why it’s nicknamed? Well guess what? You probably won’t be able to read what happened since it looks like a small gerbil had a seizure while holding a pen on one of the only notes from the owner. This only left me frustrated and I ended up not caring at all about what happened. So this made it feel like half of the story was incomplete.This was followed by the continued girl-to-woman story of Sam. While this was cute and heart warming to reading about a girl finding herself, it left me wondering if I should have just read a book instead. Whatever item you pick up plays a diary page of Sam’s and it belts out over the soft music in the background and the occasional thunder. None of it was too interesting, and as said before: it is riddled with clichés. The 90’s punk and girl grunge references even come off as cliché due to the same standard writing all over the posters of ‘fighting the man’ and what not. It’s like they rebel against a establishment without any clear reason to do so.It lacks basic game play mechanics and good exploring rewards. Like with most games it might have clues as to what to do next that are clear and help continue the story. Yes, this was partly my fault, but after having such limited interaction with items I started looking less and less for items to fiddle with. It doesn’t interest me to pick up a 3d plate, or 3d tooth brush, and spin it around. The 3d books serve little to no purpose, except for one. Then the story items are so blatantly obvious they aren’t misable or they look so generic that I didn’t bother picking it up considering it was only the 900 th random piece of paper strung about in the house.In the end Gone Home is another video game experiment that doesn’t feel complete. Many gamers, including myself, will be greatly disappointed with this. This is due to the lack of just about everything that makes video games playable. Yes it’s filled with every artistic metaphors and emotional impact that would be in most video games. Although for me the story was lost due to the stereotypical storyline of the subject matter, plot holes, and illegible clues. If it went on for a few more hours and explained everyone else’s view point I would have probably enjoyed it a lot more.Either skip this or get it on the cheap (i.e. below $10). It’s only 2 hours worth of gameplay and has ZERO replay value.5.0/10

content:
Posted: March 28, 2015
												This game represents a magnificent achievement. In most games that are advertised as possessing character-depth, I feel as though I'm just learning more details given to me by the writer. In Gone Home, I felt as though I was learning more about a real individual. The house contains so many details that make it feel "lived in," which adds tremendously to the immersion. As a grown man, I often feel dismissive of the seemingly melodramatic lives of teenagers - however, Gone Home made that emotional world feel real for me again. The pain of exclusion, and the desire to be understood - this game deserves to be played.

												Not a game, more an interactive experience about the same length as a movie.  You can interact with hundreds of items in this fairly large house which has numerous hidden things to uncover.  All the set pieces are great and the game taking place in the mid 90s plays homage to many things from that time.  Also the story is mainly told besides all the notes, etc that you can read through the voice of your sister Sam's journals.  It's a wonderful emotional tale that pulls you in, although i might be biased as i myself was a teenager in the mid 90's.  It's hard to call it an adventure game as there aren't really puzzles per se that don't rely exploration, still it is an adventure and a game I can whole heartedly recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												Over the past few years, the narrative value of video games has been explored and expanded upon. No longer just a medium of just action, scifi, and fantasy, video games have evolved to adapt themselves to any genre for storytelling. Dear Esther, Ana, and countless others have paved the way for a new kind of game.Gone Home takes that endeavor and drives it home. Like a scalpel in the hands of a veteran surgeon, it cuts deep into the player, and leaves a permanent impression. The ambience of the game is magnetic, drawing you in to a world that is not defined by dragons or laser guns, but by the kind of human interaction that defines us as individuals, the kind of interaction that creates a story that does not seek to thrill or shock, but simply to touch the heart.If you can finish this game without crying, you have no soul.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I had no idea what to think about Gone Home before I played it. Will it be a horror game? I had so many questions about the game. Many critics said the game told a very good story, and they were right. Im not going to spoil anything, but you play as Katie, a girl who just got back from vacation. She goes to her family's new home, but her family is nowhere to be seen. The whole game is about exploring the house, and the story is not told to you directly. To get the full story, you need to explore everything. Gone Home is a game that takes time to complete, and is not rewarding if you decide to rush through. The game is fairly short, but the story it manages to tell is fantastic. You listen to audio logs, read notes, and find clues that piece together the story. Keep in mind, not all of the story is told directly, and there are a few subplots to follow as well. So....do I reccomend Gone Home? Yes I do reccomend it, but not at regular price. $19.99 is too steep of a price to pay for an interactive story like this, so wait until it is on sale for $4.99 and buy it. Remember, take your time when playing the game, and the game will be very rewarding. Gone Home gets a 8/10.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
 There are very few LGBT+ games at all.  Not only does that make this game a brilliant game, but also what else makes this game a great game is that it can show a story through the exploration of a single house, it can show it through tapes you find and through bits of paper. Of course some can call that style of game play a walking simulator, but I assure you, this game is much more than a walking simulator, it touches upon  LGBT+  issues, it has a really dark atomosphere, and it has a very interesting protagonist switch.This game is about  two lesbians who have fallen in love with each other and their families don't quite understand or approve  , the game perfectly shows you this story with objects found by you, diary pages, tapes, etc. There is a lot of reading to be done when playing this game, so if you can't read or are too lazy to read, you won't like this game. This game has a story that happens a lot, and it perfectly tells it, with all the sadness and misunderstanding that goes along with it.The atmosphere of the game seriously misleads you into thinking that this is a horror game, but it may not be as misleading as you would think. As the whole situation with  people misunderstanding two people's love  is quite a horrible situation in itself, and can be very dangerous. The atmosphere also really fits with the whole empty house, keeping you on your toes as you explore and try and find out what has happened.By protagonist switching, I am refering to the fact that in this game you are not really playing protagonist, this game is not about the character that you are playing, this game is about someone else, the person who left all the diary pages and such. And this can help you to understand that this game is not about you, it's about her, as you are not the important one in this situation. And this protagonist switching really helps to go along with the whole theme of the game.This game is pretty powerful, although the replay value on it is not that high, and though it's not a really 'enjoyable' game, it is a very important game.

content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
 There are very few LGBT+ games at all.  Not only does that make this game a brilliant game, but also what else makes this game a great game is that it can show a story through the exploration of a single house, it can show it through tapes you find and through bits of paper. Of course some can call that style of game play a walking simulator, but I assure you, this game is much more than a walking simulator, it touches upon  LGBT+  issues, it has a really dark atomosphere, and it has a very interesting protagonist switch.This game is about  two lesbians who have fallen in love with each other and their families don't quite understand or approve  , the game perfectly shows you this story with objects found by you, diary pages, tapes, etc. There is a lot of reading to be done when playing this game, so if you can't read or are too lazy to read, you won't like this game. This game has a story that happens a lot, and it perfectly tells it, with all the sadness and misunderstanding that goes along with it.The atmosphere of the game seriously misleads you into thinking that this is a horror game, but it may not be as misleading as you would think. As the whole situation with  people misunderstanding two people's love  is quite a horrible situation in itself, and can be very dangerous. The atmosphere also really fits with the whole empty house, keeping you on your toes as you explore and try and find out what has happened.By protagonist switching, I am refering to the fact that in this game you are not really playing protagonist, this game is not about the character that you are playing, this game is about someone else, the person who left all the diary pages and such. And this can help you to understand that this game is not about you, it's about her, as you are not the important one in this situation. And this protagonist switching really helps to go along with the whole theme of the game.This game is pretty powerful, although the replay value on it is not that high, and though it's not a really 'enjoyable' game, it is a very important game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Ow, right in my feels.It's rare that a modern video game can evoke a full range of emotions: happiness, sadness, dread, intrigue, confusion, anger.  It's almost unheard of that a game can do all of that without having any on screen characters other than the player character.  Gone Home does that very thing, and is one of the finest examples of how video games can be a form of art.The setup is beautifully simple, giving you a large, empty mansion to explore, encouraging you to examine the contents of the house, then using those items to gradually unravel the details and backstory of the Greenbriar family, and the inherent mystery surrounding their unexpected absence.  The examination of certain items is occasionally accompanied by narration from the family's younger sister, Sam, reading letters she has written to her older sister Kaitlin (the player character).  The minimalistic, at-your-own-pace approach to storytelling combined with the ambiance of being in a creaky old mansion during a strong rainstorm is VERY effective; instead of being told how you should feel before rushing you to the next setpiece, the game simply lets you soak in the information and gives you ample time to process it on your own.  The approach makes the story hit that much harder, and is the underlying reason why Gone Home is such an effective piece of storytelling.From a gameplay standpoint, Gone Home is the modern equivalent of the classic point-and-click adventures of the 90s.  Though it is first person, there is no shooting, nor is there any combat, nor are any particularly fast reflexes required.  The game is designed to be explored completely at your own pace, taking as much or as little time as you want focusing on the mansion and its contents.  What few puzzles the game presents are less logic based and more exploration based, requiring you to find codes or access numbers rather than do complex decryption.  In short, the game is wholly accessible to players of nearly any skill level, but doesn't sacrifice quality in order to be that way.In the end, Gone Home is less of a game and more of an interactive story, but in no way suffers for being such.  About the worst thing I could find with it is that it is short and not highly replayable, yet I still feel I've gotten my money's worth and then some out of it.  It manages to pack a surprisingly touching story into its brief length, along with a potent statement on what one can do with the gaming medium in general.  If you're looking for a gaming experience that tells you an engaging story which doesn't rely on explosions, supernatural elements, or combat in general, Gone Home is something you should take a look at.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												This is not going to be an in-depth review, as I don't think I can say anything about Gone Home that already hasn't been said over and over. I just wish to put my two cents on the positive side of the review scale.Gone Home is a very good story. It is well written and well presented. It's somewhat rare for me to find a story that really grips me and doesn't let go until it's over. And although I could see the plot coming from a mile away, Gone Home still managed to do just that.My only point of contention would be the price. I think Gone Home deserves all the money you can give it, but if you don't have a lot of money for throwing around, there's just not enough content in the game to justify the full price and you should probably wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: April 24
												Pros:- Decent atmosphere- Its kind of fun to explore the houseCons:- My current playtime reflects how long it takes to beat this game if you take your sweet time and look at EVERYTHING- Heavy-handed dialogue- No room for nuance in the characterization- I did not think it was possible for a story to have less than 1 dimension- 0 replay value (no multiple endings, new game+, etc.)It is obvious that this game was made with an agenda. Now an agenda is not necessarily a bad thing, but I believe it is when that agenda overpowers ALL other aspects of a game. Gone Home does not offer a powerful story, does not provide a particularly gripping environment, does not foster interesting characters, and sure as hell does not earn its pricetag.Do not pay for this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 18, 2016
												I really liked this game. I liked the story so much. It only gave you infromation piece by piece, until you could finish putting together the whole story about Sam and Lonnie. It's a love novel actually, 2 lesbian teenagers, but the story and the voice acting is just so good.PRO:+ very good voice acting+ thrilling story+ great atmosphere (storm, flashing lights, empty house)+ pretty good graphics+ lots of papers/diaries/pictures/books to explore in order to assemble the story+ some easy puzzlesCON:- no achievements- no autosaves for diary entries you find (my PC crashed after I played like 2 hours, and my progress was gone, had to start the game again from the very beginning! )- pretty short- no collectibles ( it was nice if you could collect all the postcards, casettes into your inventory and have them in one place)- no replay valueOverall it's a pretty interesting walking simulator bringing you back to the Nintendo games era (mid-90's). Definitely not for everyone. I dare to say I liked this game a lot more than I did 'Dear Esther'. The overall playtime would be somewhere between 2-3 hours for the first playthrough, really my only point in replaying it was that my PC carshed mid-game after I opened the kitchen area, so basically had to quickly replay about 75% of the game.Would I buy it? Definitely if it was on sale. I bought it in a bundle so really no regrets. I can recommend this game mostly beacuse of the story and the easy puzzles which really make it relaxing.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												I'm usually VERY forgiving and interested in new game experiences. Reviews mention two key points: the interesting story, and the "freakiness" of exploring the house.First, the story. Over half of the things you'll find or read are totally extraneous and do nothing to further any sort of interesting plot (or sub-plot). I don't want to spoil anything in case you get this on sale (DO NOT PAY FULL PRICE), but the story is a massive letdown with each plot thread that it opens up.As for the the empty house situation, it could have been extremely freaky. Instead, they throw in some really obtuse references to some of the "creepy" things that happened and give you just the SLIGHTEST glimpse of problems in the house. A few diaries from the mom, or perhaps some really depressed letters from the dad would have made the experience A LOT freakier. I'd constantly have been worried that someone had gone nuts and done something horrible around the next corner.I can not believe this game got so many 8s, 9s, and 10s. Had the story of any of these characters been told in a traditional format (movie, book, even someone speaking over a campfire) you would be bored to tears.P.S. The contents of those locked containers were so bland. If I'm hunting for secrets, you better make it worth it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 20, 2013
												Pack your bags, we're going on a feels trip.  This is a beautiful game, and not to be missed.  It has echoes of Dear Esther, but with a greater level of interactivity, and a more defined story.  You'll either fall in love with it, or pass it off due to it's brevity (2 hours) and minimal "gamey" elements.  I won't spoil anything about the story, but you play as a young woman who comes back from a year overseas to find her home empty.  You explore the house and try to piece together what happened.  This is not a horror game.  The voice acting is some of the best I've ever experienced, and the shortness of the game works in it's favour.  The price tag might seem a little high, but trust me it's worth it.Before you play, two important tips:1) Take your time to explore thoroughly, and pick up everything interesting in case there's a story behind it2) Set aside some time to play, and play it all in one sitting

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												"You arrive home after a year abroad. You expect your family to greet you, but the house is empty. Something's not right. Where is everyone? And what's happened here? Unravel the mystery for yourself in Gone Home, a story exploration game from The Fullbright Company. " That is the quote from the summary of the game on steam. I was under the impression there was some deep mystery why your family was missing. Mysteries traditionally have some dark, spooky, or noire-like overtones, which unfourtanately this game has none. Even entering the house, at night with a rainstorm outside, the house dark, quiet and spooky, one could easily determine this game to be a mystery. Did your family get kidnapped? Is there some supernatural event that happened that caused your families disappearance? SPOILER: NONE OF THAT HAPPENED. What I got instead was 4 hours of some girl talking to me about her issues and being confused in her life. I'm not against the subject matter in any way. What I am against is hearing that subject matter as the source of entertainment in a video game. I will admit I do have some bias, because I went into the game expecting some dark mystery and in-depth discovery, instead got treated to a diary of a girl talking about her day. I even took notes of key events for like an hour, in case I needed a reference to help me solve the mystery. That was a waste of time, BECAUSE THERE WAS NONE. What is this game? It is an exploration game where you get to read and hear about a family members drastic life change at a time in the game where the house, by coincidence, happens to be empty. There was no mystery. I predicted the games ending by the second hour. Would you like it? If you like Dear Esther with a narrator talking about how her day went, this game is for you. It, however, is not the game for me. I paid $10 for this game when it was on sale, i feel ripped off.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												First my grade for this game would be 3/5Grafics: 3/5Sound: 2/5 -> No background music. Just the sound of rain and occasional thunder. HORRIBLE sound in the cassets.Fun: 3/5Controls/Interface: 4/5Gameplay: 2/5 -> Over in 3 hours.When I started playing it, I knew only it was a praised game and nothing about the story. I thought it would be a horror game at first, like Alone in the Dark. Then I realized there's no RUN in the game so this takes the fighting/fleeing out of the scene and I just relaxed and started thinking it would be a detective story. I kept playing waiting to find a body, or bodies and investigate the crime(s). Every room I searched for clues and kept finding journal's pages/notes and documents where the game's story unfolded itself. It's mainly a game about reading and paying attention to the enviroment to find other pages/notes/documents until the game is over. The most difficult thing you will have to do in this game is finding locker/safe combinations that are laying around.The game is a point and click adventure game, with a good story, but with no twist, puzzles or crime or anything thrilling to discover. If you can buy it for $3-5 bucks or less it's worthy taking a look at it otherwise I wouldn't buy it because it's a really short game and there are FAR better adventures games out there.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												This game is a hit and miss depending on the style of gaming you are interested in. To tell the truth, its more of a story rather than a game itself. Walking simulator, point and click and exploring is all that is offered for this to be considered a game. How it made PC Game Of The Year is beyond me and the fact that it was awarded PC GOTY, was all the reason for me to purchase this title and see what it had to offer. Comparing this title towards my taste of what I like in video games, all I have to comment is this...Pros:- The Eerie sounds of a thunder storm in the background complemented the gloomy atmosphere of the mansion- The lighting and "creaking noises" of the mansion was enough for me to keep playing and wanting to explore more- The zoom feature was quite nice and layout of the mansion was well done- Controls are extremely simple to manage (even a map is provided to find your way)- Walking motion was well done and is well deserved of the title of Walking simulatorCons:- Extremely short (2.8 hours and thats generous due to the fact I walked away from my pc a lot)- The Story was not to my liking but I really can't bash this due to the fact that the main character being female- Way to easy to find all items and to navigate so freely. (Maybe it was luck but I would find the keys before the lock doors)- No puzzles at all however due to the story line I can understand why- I don't understand how this won PC GOTY but I really don't know what the opposition had to contest this

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												Wow... Just wow... First of all, this is quite possibly the most atmoshperically 90's story ever created. Second of all, this is easily the most beautiful and personal feeling interactive story I've ever had the pleasure of playing. It's so hard to explain what makes this work so well without just telling you exactly what happens. You'll just have to experience it for yourself. I honestly could not stop crying and/or smiling through out this. The voice acting is SUPERB. I really mean it. It puts you right into the emotions of the characters and holds you there until long after you've finished the game and gone to sleep. 12/10 easily.Also, if you are a fan of the book, "The Perks of Being a Wallflower", than you will most certainly love this as well. P.S. Don't let the atmosphere spook you out, there's nothing to worry about. This is not a horror game.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												"You arrive home after a year abroad. You expect your family to greet you, but the house is empty. Something's not right. Where is everyone? And what's happened here? Unravel the mystery for yourself in Gone Home, a story exploration game from The Fullbright Company. " That is the quote from the summary of the game on steam. I was under the impression there was some deep mystery why your family was missing. Mysteries traditionally have some dark, spooky, or noire-like overtones, which unfourtanately this game has none. Even entering the house, at night with a rainstorm outside, the house dark, quiet and spooky, one could easily determine this game to be a mystery. Did your family get kidnapped? Is there some supernatural event that happened that caused your families disappearance? SPOILER: NONE OF THAT HAPPENED. What I got instead was 4 hours of some girl talking to me about her issues and being confused in her life. I'm not against the subject matter in any way. What I am against is hearing that subject matter as the source of entertainment in a video game. I will admit I do have some bias, because I went into the game expecting some dark mystery and in-depth discovery, instead got treated to a diary of a girl talking about her day. I even took notes of key events for like an hour, in case I needed a reference to help me solve the mystery. That was a waste of time, BECAUSE THERE WAS NONE. What is this game? It is an exploration game where you get to read and hear about a family members drastic life change at a time in the game where the house, by coincidence, happens to be empty. There was no mystery. I predicted the games ending by the second hour. Would you like it? If you like Dear Esther with a narrator talking about how her day went, this game is for you. It, however, is not the game for me. I paid $10 for this game when it was on sale, i feel ripped off.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												This game sounded great when I first heard about it, and every review I read from critics and gaming websites made it sound like it was the best thing ever. I should have read the player reviews first. I have never seen a game cause such a split between gamers and critics. Critics love it, and many players hate it. I am part of the latter.This "game" is part of that genre that has you walking around, either exploring or being told a story (i.e. Dear Esther, The Stanley Parable, and to some extent Outlast, Amnesia 1 &2, and Slender: The Arrival). The problem here is that all those other games worked for the most part (excluding Slender: The Arrival). Gone Home has you exploring, opening everything in every room of the house, reading everything and trying to piece together why you are the only one in the house. There is a storm outside, so the rain, lightning, and thunder that you see and hear, as well as the fact that the lights flicker on and off repeatedly make you feel uneasy. There are several ominous notes and letters you find that make you think there is something else going on, something that you wouldn't see coming.****SPOILERS****There is simply no pay off in the story. It is predictable to the point that you can figure out at least part of what is going on in the first room if you are paying attention. There are some things that are never explained, and this includes some things that are hinted at and built up throughout the entire game. It felt as if the game was purposely trying to make you think something huge was gonna happen once you finally got into the attic, just to get up there to a huge disappointment. And it just leaves a few things hanging, and that bugged me. The ideas were great but did not work at all. Even worse, to advance the story, you have to open and look at very specific items. If you overlook one, you are forced to figure out where it was. I looked through literally every room, nook, and cranny several times before I realized I had overlooked a folder that looked like a poster. That one item was what I needed to continue on. I don't mind exploring but making the required item so subtle and easy to overlook is just irritating.Overall, this had potential but was just horrible. And it definitely is not worth the price. If people want to play it and say it's great, that's fine, everyone has their own tastes, but I will be staying away from this thing.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												This game is a brief casual explorative experience, based around examining the contents of a household in first person. Emotional dialogue lines, expressed as if read from a diary, tell a short narrative about the life and love of a young girl. Initially the game felt very eerie and mysterious, but as the plot is unwoven it becomes heartfelt and compelling; with just a few creepy touches. A casual and minimalistic game that is short and sweet. The Grrrl Punk mixtapes are also excellent.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												Gone Home is an extremely dull game.I love point and click adventures, but I hate this game.It feigns a horror aspect but doesn't deliver on it. What it does deliver is a whiny teenage love story and that just doesn't do it for me. Perhaps if it had puzzles like a normal point and click I would have at least enjoyed that bit of challenge, but no, as someone else said, it's more of an interactive story than a game.Some have said they at least appreciate the 90's flashback aspect - the music (which I didnt like either) and old electronics provide most of this, but I feel like it's just a disguised excuse as to why the girl you're playing can't just call her sister or parents via cell phone.For the Length of the game and lack of entertainment I would really like my money back. Maybe wait for a sale or price drop if you think you still might want to play because it is not worth $20.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												I'm glad I bought this game when it was on sale on the Humble Store for $5. Wait, no I wish I would have saved the $5 for a good cheeseburger. This was not at all what I was expecting, and I felt it was misleading. First the good points: The voice acting was great, and the graphics and atmosphere were awesome. Now the bad points: The atmosphere that is created gives a kind of "horror" theme that is misleading and non-existent. They hint at a possibly scary story with the "ghost" of the guy who lived in the house before. That turns out to be a bust too. My main problem with this game was its hidden agenda. There's no mention of the LGBT message that fuels this game until a while into playing it. I feel that the high ratings it is getting are simply because it touches on this politically charged issue and nobody wants to say it stinks. I have nothing against gay people, nothing against a "game" that addresses the topic, I just felt misled into buying something that I was not looking for. For those looking to buy this game: Be warned that it is about a homosexual girl and that it is way overpriced. If you really want it, wait for a sale.

But if you do for some reason buy it, you will want to get it on sale.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												**SPOILER FREE REVIEW (Unless you don't want it to be :D)**So, where to begin with Gone Home? In a nutshell, Gone Home is another entry in the "visual novel" genre of games comprised by other titles like Dear Esther, The Writer, and so on and so forth. Despite the greatness of other such games, Gone Home is terrible and not worth an ounce of your time. So here's why: Plot Strength Without spoiling anything, the basis of Gone Home's plot is that you are Katie Greenbriar; a girl just returning from a semester abroad in Europe only to find her home in Oregon, which her family recently moved into, "mysteriously" empty. Subsequently, it is your job to snoop around the house like Sherlock Homes and uncover clues as to what is happening. Then (still no spoilers) the backstory behind why the house is "abandoned" has to do with your sister Sam who is in 11th grade and experiencing her first love interest. I will not delve any further into the story just in case I can't persuade you to not buy this abhorrent piece of trash, but all I can tell you is that within 45 minutes of playing the game (about half way through in my case, and yes i did pick up every item and explore every room) you will know EXACTLY how the game will end. I kid you not; Gone Home's "surprise ending" is about as remarkable as watching an episode of Dora the Explorer (that is to say not much at all). Now, moving on, let me adress why this game is so critically aclaimed. As you can see on metacritic, Gone Home has an absurdly high (imo) average critic rating of 86, while the user rating is 5.4. The reasoning behind this is because Gone Home is one of those games that might as well say in the description (and pardon my french) "DEAR GAME CRITICS, if you do not hail me as one of the greatest games of all time and the most moving game you've every played, you will be pigeon-holed by the rest of the game-critics community and seen as an unsophisticated, uneducated, arrogant f**ktard." Let me elaborate further: Since Gone Home is protrayed by the Fullbright Company as a "moving", "artistic", and "expressive" story, game critics want to also seem "sophisticated" and "artistic" in that same respect by waxing lyrical about Gone Home and "how personally it spoke to them". Moreover, Gone Home has many (forced and annoying) references to the '90's in it and seeing as  A LOT of game reviewers today were born in the late '80's and early '90's they eat that stuff up. To finish off this section, let's examine why Gone Home is in no way whatsoever "artistic", "moving", or "sophisticated". The story is probably the most pathetic and lame thing I have ever witnesses in any medium. The writing is down right melodramatic (which is about the only thing that matches up with the '90's :-/) and fake; as if they had a 14 year old girl at The Gap pick up the nearest pencil she could find, take a napkin from the foodcourt, and write out the first love story that came to her head. There is nothing unique whatsoever about Sam's lovestory and it fully embraces every "budding relationship" cliche known to man. Moreover, despite some people who don't recommend this game saying the voice acting is exceptional, I beg to differ. The voices sound flat and fail to convey little emotion. In short, every journal, story, and note you read that has to do with Sam's love story (pretty much all of them) adds up to a pile of bad writing not even fit for a live action Nickelodeon show.  Game Structure Gone home's gamplay is flat out bad; there's no other word for it, it's just bad. Before I start ranting again, here is THE ONLY thing I will commend Gone Home for, and that is how it manages to make the house feel lived in; it's a very large house, but there's just enough furniture, books, belongings, etc. to make the house feel real and the decorating is quite realistic which probably helped cloud-headed pretentious reviewers feel more "immersed" in the game. Now, back to the bad aspects which, you guessed it, is literally everything else! The ONLY interaction you will ever have in Gone Home is picking up miscellaneous objects which sometimes  trigger Sam's "journal entries/notes for Katie", opening doors, and entering lock combonations. Believe me you, I've played many adventure games in my time so I'm very used to this type of gameplay; hell, my favorite game of all time is The Walking Dead The Game (which I played on my PS Vita so please do not respond "You don't have The Walking Dead a**hole :-/"). However, Gone Home is, simply put, boring when you are not progressing the story (that is if you even like the story which, obviously, I do not); all you do is pick up poorly textured objects, and fumble around with '90's memorabailia; rotating them around like a whirlgig (Katie would make a great chemist due to her exceptional rotating skills which you'll be doing every god-damn 10 seconds only to find that you will never find any hidden messages, images, or compartments on these objects in the entire game). In fact, taking out the ability to pick up and examine objects in Gone Home would vastly improve it seeing as the inclusion of it in the first place is a failed attempt at adding "some" interaction/gameplay to keep the player interested, but in actuallity, this ability makes the game even more drawn out than my grandpa's undies since almost every player, including myself, will take the time to pick up EVERY....FREAKIN'...OBJECT. Moreover, this would streamline the story and allow the game to do what it truly intends: rip off it's players with a truly terrible story. Other games, like Dear Esther, already realized that literally no interaction whatsoever is better than some so that the player can realize what the true nature of the game is and not be confused by being able to pick up more objects than there are milk containers in Half Life 2. Value Go ahead and look at Gone Home's store page and look for it's price. You will find it is 20 U.S. dollars, thus leading you to believe it must have a significant amount of content. I mean, by that logic, Gone Home should offer as much content as games like CS GO, FTL, Spelunky, The Walking Dead, Rust, Skyrim, Dark Souls 1 and other games that are at very similar price points on steam. Moreover, for literally under a dollar, you could buy a humle bundle with amazing games like Bioshock and Xcom: UFO Defense from the 2k Humble Bundle or Thief Gold and Hitman from the Square Enix Humble Bundle that's on sale at this point in time. Well, jokes on you if you thought anything even close to that was true, because what if I told you that you can beat Gone Home in less than a minute when you know what to do? What's more, what if I told you I've actually read forum posts/stories of people accidently finding the hidden room that holds the key which you need to finish the game within minutes of their first play through, then proceeding to finish the game when they think they're merely doing what they're supposed to, only to find out they already beat the piece of trash? Well, whether you believe these things or not, they (much like Robert Ripley's stories) are horrifyingly true. Gone Home isn't worth $20, or $3, or even $1 since that same amount of money would be better spent on ANYTHING else, hell go buy a chicken burger at McDonald's!In conclusion, Gone Home is a bad game, made by bad writers, for pretentious people, and you should NEVER buy it. Also, for those brave enough, here's the spoiler of THE WHOLE GAME (yes, it's that short),  Sam is a lesbian (which her parents dissaprove of her being) and she falls in love with a girl named Lonnie. Unfortunately, Lonnie entered the military and they must now separate. However, Sam and Lonnie decide they must be together, so Lonnie deserts the military and they run off together. Also, the only reason the parents are gone is because they are on vacation for their anniversary.

												as someone who loves story games, but gets frustrated when im constantly overwhelmed by fights or puzzles, i really liked this game.  it was immersive, and i felt really curious the entire time.  loved picking up pillows to look underneath, finding files, ect.  i think many others are judging this game unfairly...  saying it sucks because there's 'no gameplay' is like saying a movie sucks because it isnt an action movie.  this isnt a game that you play to stab or shoot an enemy, or run away from a monster, or solve a jumping puzzle.  its an interactive story.  personally, my favorite thing was the plot turnaround.  i went in thinking oooooh spoooooky ghost better get ready, theyre gonna be around ANY CORNER, but the story, as i uncover it, was really exciting and meaningful.  this is the kind of narrative lgbt kids need.  a story with a happy ending, with hope.

content:
Posted: September 16, 2014
												Gone home is a game about love, loss, life, lesbians, 90's kids, Street Fighter, walking, pack rats, and walking. You play as Katie who just came home from her trip to Europe to a home with no family. Why is the home empty you ask? Because there's crap everywhere and even the people living their couldn't handle their hoarding compulsive hide-things-everywhere nature. There is a story here and it is an okay one. The main story revolves around the development of your sister, and the story surrounding her development is interesting. Unfortunetely it isn't interesting enough to be recommended. You walk around a house discovering scraps of paper and putting together the lives of your family members through the interaction and exploration. That is the "game" part of this game. All of it. You can get the same experience opening your closet. (By the way I've seen your closet young man and I've told you twice already to clean that up.) The biggest advantage this game has is the length. It does not overstay its welcome and knows it should and ends early. Be warned it is VERY short any possible purchasers of this game. If you are in the mood for a short little story about a girl's teenage years/very small story about a father/even smaller story about a mother then this game is for you. If you don't then go play like. I don't know. Dota 2.

												There is no sense of conflict or agency.  You simply pick up the things you need to and the "game" ends.  Nothing special here.I got it in a bundle, so I figured I had to play it to see what the strange attraction was with this game.I still don't get it.  Why does a game in which you do practically nothing for about an hour and a half cost $20!?  It seems like to me for that much one could buy a story-driven game where the story appears to matter (and may even have gameplay).   I don't see the exclusion of gameplay as a feature.  If all you have is story, then it needs to be really interesting and immersive.  Allowing you to interact with every random object in the environment alone does not accomplish this task.  The narrative you receive along the way is nothing special I'm afraid.  I guess people praise this for trying something different, which is something I can respect because you won't know if something works till you try it.  However, simply being different isn't enough imo.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Another point-and-click storytelling game. I'm a huge fan of this genre, though it repeatedly seems to be not worth the money. Gone Home creates a truly believable world and realistic characters. However, the manner in which the story is told is frustratingly obvious. The first time you are given clues about certain aspects of a character's personality or problems they are facing, it is interesting to guess the subtleties of their individual situations. But any fun derived from figuring out these mysteries is shortly ruined by being bombarded with obvious hint after obvious hint until finally, you are basically slapped in the face with the all-too-obvious truth. This made me feel like it was further simplifying the story, which was already far too short and simple in my opinion.The game mechanics themselves are also a bit flawed. Almost every cabinet and drawer door is able to be opened, and there are lots of cloned objects that serve no purpose but to get in the way of certain objects that are actually important to the story. It says I have logged 2.5 hours on this game but a good 45 minutes of that was probably wasted on picking up rolls of toilet paper just to see if there was a key hidden underneath them.The graphics and objects were fairly glitchy even when I turned my graphics on maximum settings.In terms of sound, the background noises were too repetitive. The first time certain noises like thunder happened, it took me by surprise, but eventually I wanted more variety. The random cassette tapes you can play are a fun addition, but the sound was not balanced properly and the music plays WAY too loudly, to the point where I had to keep adjusting the volume every time I even saw a cassette player as I entered a room.Overall, I would say this game is worth the $2.99 I spent during the summer sale, but paying more than $5 for this would be unwise. It will last you only about 2 hours even if you take a long time and pore over every detail. I guess it's still a relatively "indie" genre and can't be compared to much else, which explains why some critics loved it. While I can't say I completely hated it, the game was too frustrating in too many ways to make it a truly enjoyable experience.
