content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												One word Review: Overpriced.Without spoiling the plot, I can say that Gone Home is a very unconventional, and unorthodox walking simulator. It's not likely that you've ever played another game like this, and while you might have your own assumptions of what to expect, Gone Home will likely fool you with it’s misdirection. What the Fullbright Company has managed to do with the Unity engine is quite impressive, creating a mansion where virtually everything can be picked up, inspected, read, or examined, even if it's completely irrelevant to the story. The deluge of seemingly insignificant items may fluster you into thinking you've missed something useful, but trust me, you haven't.The game's atmosphere is mostly horror based, although I'm tempted to reuse the word: misdirection. The downpour of rain, accompanied by thunder and flickering lights creates a very tense, suspenseful abience. Played at night, with a headset, and you’ll find yourself jumping at shadows and fearing the dark.When it comes to the story itself, Gone Home is very short, allowing for just over an hour of gameplay, possibly two if you take your time. For this reason, I highly recommend you buy the game on sale, just to avoid being burned.For what the game offers, and the experience as a whole, I enjoyed it. I just don't agree with the twenty dollar price tag.

content:
Posted: March 12, 2016
Gone HomeI had completed this game when this review was writtenShort ReviewAn excellent, short, heavily story based mystery adventure where you play in the first person and try to understand why your parents house is empty when you return from a year out.Long ReviewYou arrive back at your parents house after a year away travelling to find a note pinned to the front door and the house empty. The purpose of the adventure is to try and figure out why no one is at home.You do this by wandering around the house, examining objects and slowly piece together the clues. In the process you find out the background of the characters who live in the house and what they have been up to whilst you have been away and indeed before you went away tooYou will not necessarily pick up the clues in sequential order and so must piece the clues together to make sense of the events. This is very enjoyable and the clues offer insights into each of the inhabitants of the house and their lives.The ending is excellent with your discovery of what has happened.I can't see any replay value in this game.ProsShort, it took me around 3 hours to completeIntriguing story line. The main storyline is excellent as well as several of the side story lines.Thought provokingCan be played through at your own paceConsIf I was going to be picky I'd say some of the clues were left in bizarre places that logically made no sense to meI can understand why there are adverse comments about the game, particularly about the price considering the shortness of the game play but I've paid much more for decent games with much longer play times that I've not enjoyed anywhere near as muchThis really was an excellent game which I can thoroughly recommend. Marks Out Of 55) Must have - stop whatever you're playing now and play this4) Worth the asking price and considering as your next purchase3) Maybe purchase if you're stuck for choosing your next game or mildly discounted2) Only purchase if it is heavily discounted1) Not worth getting even if given away freeWhere I got the game fromI won this game from  [www.steamgifts.com]Platform Played OnIntel Pentium G3258 Anniversary Edition, 8Gb RAM, Palit GTX 750, Windows 10, EasyAcc Mouse & Steelseries MERC keyboard. Played at windowed 1440x900 resolutionMy best guess for a PEGI ratingUsing  PEGI Ratings [www.pegi.info] I would rate this game as a 7

content:
Posted: August 18, 2013
												What a giant waste of money.  This is one of those 'games as art' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t with an unpleasantly boring and down to earth story that has this red herring of a plot present itself at the beginning, with things such as noises around the house leading you to believe this plotline might be true, only to open into some teen angsty sexual discovery drama ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.Look, I'm all for melodrama and depth in writing but...  So much about this game, from its music to its trailer and the writers attached are SO misleading.  This is an example of a poorly marketed game.  This is not a Game of the Year, this is not 'Games as Art', this is the pinnacle of pretentious hipster 'I'm gonna use this entertainment outlet as my personal canvas' ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t.  The Fullbright Company and anyone who praises this as being a 'game' need to get their heads checked.  I really REALLY wanted to like this, but NOTHING has been so dull in such a long time that I have to put my foot down and say 'Stop, don't buy into this, you don't know what you're doing'.I'm all for activism of the downtrodden, I'm all for equality, I'm all for games being taken SOMEWHAT more seriously but please, gaming community, do NOT accept this as our BEST FOOT FORWARD.  This will NOT get us taken seriously, this will just make us look like a bunch of egotistical art snobs.  This game lacks wit, good pacing, clever design and a meaningful message and boils down to the rantings of a mid nineties whining of an angsty teenager whose parents and the world just don't understand.If I wanted to read that, I'd go hit up a livejournal page from the early 2000's, not pay 20 bucks for someone's overglorified piece of garbage.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Gone Home is a very interesting game that is more like a story than anything. The gameplay is very slow paced, as the whole game revolves around figuring out what happened to your family. The atmosphere of the game itself had me expecting something horrifying to happen every step of the way. It is interesting piecing together what's happened to your sister and parents, finding notes, papers or items that trigger a new entry in Samatha's diary.. You have to use your empathy to connect to the character, or you'll likely just be bored. The story itself may leave you happy, sad or full of twisted emotions from what the story brings up, and from which character you are connecting more with, Kate or Sam. I found it a bit easier connecting to the older sister, and so the story was almost depressing, worrying but sweet at the same time.This game is SHORT, and has basicly zero replayiblity as there is no branching paths, and after the two to four hours has passed, you'll likely just want to uninstall the game to gain back the tiny download space. Overall the game has a very touching story and creepy atmosphere as you travel through the big, empty, mansion like house in search of clues to your families wereabouts. However the miniscule game-time, basicly non-existant replayabilty and $20 price point is a bit to much for a game like this where a majority of your adventure is slowly moving through the house in hopes of triggering maybe thirty second journal entries. I can't recommend this game for it's normal price. If the game drops to $5 or below, I'd recommend it IF and only IF you have interest in stories, like romance and exploration, and don't care about gameplay itself.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												4/10Basically a short story, in a digital format.A short story where the traditional flipping of the pages of a book has been replaced by clicking on objects, thus invoking a paragraph in the short story, but in a familiar setting for gamers, in a first person view in a 3D rendered world, accompanied by a voice-over.And that's it.Hence, the story should be the key. But...If I compare Gone Home with traditional short stories, unfortunately the story itself deals with outdated and uninteresting topics, and the writing is mediocre at best. As a digital experience, or art - the story, and storytelling is nowhere near the quality of, for example - the point-and-click classics, such as The Secret of Monkey Island or Grim Fandango, which Gone Home as a product slightly resembles, and I guess purposefully, in a way, reminisces on. Basically, the lack of puzzles, and feeling of actual interaction within the world of Gone Home, emphasizes the obvious shortcomings of the actual story, and the writing.Hence, I wouldn't go as far as describing Gone Home as an interactive experience, as interacting with objects flipping the pages on a book, cannot really be called interactive per se.The technical aspects of Gone Home are also rather bland an unimaginative, as the gameplay, the graphics, the sound acting and the sound effects lack wow-factors. Obviously they're not there to distract the player from the experience, but in their own, they neither add to nor enhance the experience in a positive way either.But don't get me wrong, the quality of the textures, or the quality of "level design" is rather fine, but oddly enough, Gone Home feels like an outdated technology demo, with a short story wrapped on top.Additionally, the length and value for money of Gone Home is rather questionable. It actually took me longer to write this review than "play through" Gone Home. As a curiosity, and as a new form of a digital experience, perhaps Gone Home might be worth a few bucks, or an hour or two of your time.However, consider yourself warned. It won't be spectacular.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												Gone Home is an interactive exploration game that is set in 1995. You play as a girl named Kaitlin 'Katie' Greenbriar, who has just returned home from a year-trip to Europe to find her family "missing," and your main objective is to figure out where they've gone. You play by walking around an enormous mansion examing objects by clicking on them, which I did really enjoy. As you click on objects, you'll begin to learn more about your family and where they are. The developers did a fantastic job of recreating a nostalgic 90s era house. There are many pop-culture references throughout the game, including the X-Flies, Super Nintendo, Street Fighter, Pulf Fiction, etc. The main focal point is on your sister, Sam, and as you advance through the house, you'll learn about her rebellious attitude and where she has gone. You learn of her and her lesbian lover/girlfriend, Lonnie. It's a decent story and I was actually really excited to see how things ended with them. I won't spoil it, but I was kind of disappointed in the ending and its abrupt finish. Before giving my review of it, I want to say that this is not a game for everyone.After playing through Gone Home, I can honestly say, I don't see what all the hype is about. Critics praise this game for it's story and many have even gone as far as giving it the title of "Game of the Year." Don't get me wrong, I did enjoy my playthrough of this game, but I don't believe it comes close to deserving that title. Many people complain about its length. It can be completed in roughly 2-3 hours, if you take your time and look at everything there is to see. I beat it in 1 hour and 10 minutes. I don't really have a problem with that, I did rush myself a bit. The game gives you a very eerie atmosphere. You learn of a story about your "psycho" uncle and how his ghost is still living in the house. There's even a hidden room where Sam and Lonnie were performing a seance/exorcism. The entire time, I thought something was going to jump out at me at any moment. I was very wrong. Aside from random light flickers and lightning outside, there are no jump scares. There are no twists. I was a little disappointed by that, honestly. The house is pretty big and fun to explore. There's all kinds of secret passageways hidden behind bookcases/walls. You can definitely tell it's an indie game, just by the graphics. Not that I have a problem with that, I actually thought it looked quite nice. There's all sorts of objects to pick up and look at. One mechanic I really enjoyed was the ability to fully rotate each object to see it from every angle.All-in-all, I did enjoy Gone Home, but I don't think it deserves all the praise it gets. It is a nice game to play and to enjoy an interesting story. Exploring the house itself and viewing all the objects was quite enjoyable. The narration is also done very well. One thing I don't really like about the game is the price tag; $20. It is nowhere near worth that. Thankfully, I was able to play it through Steam Family Sharing, so I didn't have to pay a dime. If you like interactive exlporation games such as Dear Esther or Dream, then this game is for you. If you go in expecting this to be something like Bioshock Infinite, then you're going to be hugely disappointed. It was on sale for about $3 earlier this week. If it goes on sale again, I would recommend picking it up and giving it a chance.7/10

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Gone Home is an interesting experience. I say experience because there are no puzzles or action of any kind, it's more an interactive story or a very simple point-and-click adventure. The design and atmosphere are quite nice and the voice acting is also great, but the core of the game - the story - just doesn't hold up once you've reached the end. The entire story is told through what could be called "audio logs", or in this case, diary entries. While this does help move the story forward as you explore the house, it ends up being a disservice to the game when it wraps up the main story line. The main story has a very small arc and the other sub-narratives that you discover over time never really get completed. This game feels like chapter 1 to a larger story. The experience can be completed in about 60 - 80 minutes, even when going slowly and trying to discover everything. What you’re left with is a “that’s it”? feeling when the credits begin to roll. The hyperbole from critics about how amazing this game is are a little suspect, I imagine it’s because of the main theme’s subject matter. Overall, it was a fun hour or so - but not something I would want to spend any more that $5 to enjoy.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												The pitch for Gone Home is that you’re a college aged kid coming home from a long study abroad trip. It’s the early 90s, before cell phones or the internet, so your only recent communication with your family has been mainly letters and postcards. When you arrive home, your house is empty and your family is missing, so you have to explore the house for clues as to where they may be. When I heard this pitch, I was super excited to play the game because it sounded narrative focused, which I always like, and it was also interesting to me to design a game purely around the mechanic of searching a house. Unfortunately, I was a bit dissapointed in the execution of this mechanic after playing the game. My main disappointment with this game is that, every time you find a clue as to where your family is, the game starts a voice over clip and spells out to you exactly what the game wants you to know after discovering the clue. I think it would have been way more powerful to let the player examine each object and determine for themselves whether the object is relevant to the story and let the player construct the narrative for themselves. I think it would give a sense of discovery and accomplishment that isn't really present in the game as it stands now. You kind of click through each object in each room until you find one that triggers an audio clip, and then just repeat the process for each room. The developers could have still saved the audio clips for the end of the game for a bigger impact. Right now, when the player reaches the end of the game, it just kind of ends unceremoniously and awkwardly. It’s a bit difficult to talk about this game without spoiling anything, but people who have already played this game should know what I mean. I’m a bit torn on Gone Home because I recognize that it’s a very important and progressive game, but at the same time I feel that there are a lot of execution flaws with this game. Gone Home is starting to get a lot of attention and win some awards, which is all good, but I feel like some of the love this game is getting has to do with the subject matter in the game and not necessarily the game itself. Again, people who have already played this game will know what I mean. The writing in the game is mostly solid for a video game, but that unfortunately doesn't say much. But there were a few gripes I had with the storytelling. It’s probably pretty hard to write solid and well defined characters around the mechanic of discovering objects in a house, but I found that I never got a really good sense of the player’s parent’s characters. They felt flat and undeveloped. Maybe this was on purpose, but I think it would have helped the overall narrative to flesh out these characters a bit more. As negative as I sound about this game, I would still recommend this to people who like narrative focused games. Just be aware that it’s very short; I finished it in one sitting. It’s also a very personal and intimate game from a storytelling point of view, so don’t expect something light or humorous or action packed. Your enjoyment of this game will probably depend on how much this game “works” for you. I don’t think this game really “worked” for me, but I really hope more games like Gone Home get made soon, if that makes any senseFor more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												So... Gone Home. Heard about probably 20 times over the past six months and finally got a chance to play it through. Now, outside of gameplay --which is just your average, run-of-the-mill narrative-game gameplay-- the story, which is supposedly (it's a Narrative Game... it has to be) the driving force behind this title, it is... lackluster. Without spoiling the ending for anyone, I have to note there are two sub-plots left almost completely unanswered; one of which could have been entirely left ouf of the game without losing any appeal or atmosphere as it had absolutely nothing to do with anything and didn't hold its own very well. I was also confused by the MAIN story and or plot. What exactly was the point behind all of this? Well, no one really knows. I'll tell you one thing, though, you should play this game if for no other reason than how perfectly it captures the 90s. The "dreary-emptiness," grundge, the stereotypes and prejudices, the kind of "everyone's family has these problems" issues it handled (or rather, didn't really handle) and the main one; how none of us seemed to have a purpose or know what the hell we were doing with our lives. I don't mean to knock the game entirely, though, it was immersive (especially being set 18 years ago) but its plot was all over the place. A lot of senseless rabbit trails that took you nowhere and did nothing to progress the main plot. I have to say, I was very surprised and a bit disappointed after all of the praise this game got over the course of last year, to find it falling so short of said praise. But alas, what are you gonna do, right? Spend your time -and money- on something else.

												I just want to start off by saying, even though it doesn't show record on Steam, I played through the entire game. I got the DRM free version off of the Gone Home Website. I bought this game because I really like the art work and story telling done by Emily Carroll. Her wife, Kate Craig, has also done some pretty amazing stuff. I head she was one of the main graphics artists for the game. I had to give her my support by checking out this game.First the positives. Kate, the artistry in this game was AMAZING. I loved the graphics. I also felt the game engine was exceptional for what you were trying to accomplish. But I can't recommend this game, definitely not for the full $20. Maybe I didn't do my research, but when I bought this game, I thought it was going to have a completely different direction with the story. Emily Carroll's work (and the little I've seen of her wife's) was suspense and horror, but the kind that makes you think. The kind that keeps you thinking up late at night. For the longest time, it seemed like this game was headed in that direction. "Oh my gosh! What happened to the family?! What horrors will I find in the attic?!!" The atmosphere, with the thunder, downed cable, darkened rooms, secret passages... I expected something different. I wanted to have the same kind of experience I have when reading one of Emily or Kate's stories. That was a let down.And while the story was very descriptive and well written, and I realize the struggle the LGBT has gone through, seeking to be understood and accepted, it just wasn't... done right. I'm going to add some spoilers to explain myseld, so if you don't want the suprise ruined, I'd skip the rest. But the story is this:You've come back from a study abroad to find your home completely deserted. You have no idea where your parents and sister have gone. And so you scour the house looking for clues. As you piece things together and find "journal fragments" you discover your sister's story: Your parents moved into a house. This house is known by the students as the psycho house, as it was formally owned by your deceased, derranged uncle. At her new school, your sister, Sam, feels judged by her classmates, as they come to call her "That Psycho House Girl". She is befriended by this other girl named Lonnie, and they go through a teenage, rebellious phase, and fall in love. Events of their love story are recounted. At the same time, your Christian parent's marriage is falling apart, and your mother is toying with a relationship with a guy from work. They don't understand Sam's homosexual relationship, and tell her those stereotypical things that drive the LGBT community nuts. "It's a phase, you'll grow out of it", etc, etc. Sam and Lonnie in the end run away, madly in love, and your parents go to a couple's counselling retreat in order to try and fix their marriage.The plot outline, though pretty well written, was pretty awful. It reminded me of a teenage, drama novel. It was about a teenage girl who, like every other teenager, feels like their parents are "the worst" controlling freaks out to ruin their life, who goes on a rebellious streak and makes some pretty rash decisions. It's about how those rebellious, dangerous decisions lead to something "wonderful" (depending on perspective). It was about how lesbians can have a strong, passionate, romantic loving relationship, while the hypocritical, heterosexual Christian prudes can fail in their holy marriages. It honestly made me feel the same way as when black people get upset at me over racism and the white man oppression. I'm a mid-twenties young man, straight, single, and also a firm Christian to my very core. It upsets me that other Christians would rather place judgement our homosexual brothers and sisters, rather than seeking for understanding. It's a tough road they're on, and I know God has a plan. But the propoganda I found in this game was more frustrating than helpful to their cause. It came across just as whiney and judgemental as I'm sure the LGBT community feels about those who are against them. There are better ways to say what you want to say.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I can't believe I didn't already write this, so I have to get it out of my system.This game is well made but, as many say, highly focused on narrative with very little in terms of traditional gameplay. That's ok, it's still very much more a game than something like 'The 39 Steps' or a visual novel.For a game focused entirely on allowing the player to develop the narrative, I wish the narrative had been a little more developed. Your sister fell in love with another girl classmate and, feeling dejected, they ran away together. That's where the story ends. The details of your sister's process of realizing her feelings and becoming frustrated are fleshed out through diary entries and the like.I wish those log entries - which make up the game's story - had grabbed me a little more. As it is they feel like a rather bubbly and cliched impersonation of high school romance. If these parts had been brilliant instead of just passble, it might have worked a lot better. I don't mean to sound harsh, but when your entire game is moving through a house and reading scraps of paper, then one or both of those parts should be excellent.As it is, those parts feel polished and workable, but there just isn't much there. This feels like chapter one of a ten part story. The romantic plot is sweet, but not exactly literature. Don't play this game unless you're sure you want to pay for an  exploration game formed around basic character development. Even then, it might come across as a little boring.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												Gone Home is a very interesting game that is more like a story than anything. The gameplay is very slow paced, as the whole game revolves around figuring out what happened to your family. The atmosphere of the game itself had me expecting something horrifying to happen every step of the way. It is interesting piecing together what's happened to your sister and parents, finding notes, papers or items that trigger a new entry in Samatha's diary.. You have to use your empathy to connect to the character, or you'll likely just be bored. The story itself may leave you happy, sad or full of twisted emotions from what the story brings up, and from which character you are connecting more with, Kate or Sam. I found it a bit easier connecting to the older sister, and so the story was almost depressing, worrying but sweet at the same time.This game is SHORT, and has basicly zero replayiblity as there is no branching paths, and after the two to four hours has passed, you'll likely just want to uninstall the game to gain back the tiny download space. Overall the game has a very touching story and creepy atmosphere as you travel through the big, empty, mansion like house in search of clues to your families wereabouts. However the miniscule game-time, basicly non-existant replayabilty and $20 price point is a bit to much for a game like this where a majority of your adventure is slowly moving through the house in hopes of triggering maybe thirty second journal entries. I can't recommend this game for it's normal price. If the game drops to $5 or below, I'd recommend it IF and only IF you have interest in stories, like romance and exploration, and don't care about gameplay itself.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												When I first heard of Gone Home it got my attention very easily. I love exploration/story based games, and the level of detail gave it a definite appeal to me. So a few weeks later I bought it and played it.Almost right from the start the game creates a dark atmosphere and sets the game up to be an interesting horror story. Unfortunately though, this isnt a horror game. The graphics, and audio aspects are great and overall the game runs smoothly. The gameplay is very minimal; only moving and interacting with objects.The real aspect of the game comes from the journal entries you find after interacting with certain objects. Like I said earlier the story at first appears to be horror themed, but about half way through the story becomes very easy to figure out and for me was a very big let down. Maybe they were trying to avoid horror cliches by going in another direction. But in doing so they follwed several other cliches that you would expect to see on a soap opera. Though in the end, despite my opinions of the way they took the story I have to admit it was rather well written.I only have a few remaining comments. There really isn't any replay value and in addition with it's current base price of $20 I would not recommend Gone Home. It was a game that had so much potential that ultimately fell short of being a truly memorable experience.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												SPOILERSIt's very unfortunate how I cannot recommend this game. First, the good:  It starts off as a promising adventure game, very reminiscent of those made in the past, just with an updated engine.   Objectively, and without considering a large and very important part of the story, the game is a fantastic adventure/exploration experience.  It reminds me a bit of "Scratches" and similar titles.  The graphics are nice and the attention to detail is really quite breath-taking.  It was also nice to have a female lead for a change, that wasn't just an eye-candy dress-up to sell more copies.  The game runs well and its pace is just right.  You have an entire mansion to explore.  Think "the original Resident Evil, but without the zombies" and you'll get a pretty good idea of what kind of laid-back adventure this game is...  on the surface...The Bad:  They took the great oppertunity they had to make a serious game with a female lead, and threw all of its credibility and likability into the furnace.  Because of the story, this game is nothing more than homosexual, feminist propaganda.  That's seriously it.  You play this game to uncover more story, and that's all the story is, thus, that's all the game is.  Now, I say this as an Agnostic who supports gay rights and has participated in marches and protests for the cause.  There is a love story (actually more than one if you really pay attention, though the additional story(s) show how terrible straight couples are at relationships) and it's a deep and caring one.  I enjoyed the story for what it was, but I also noticed how entirely preachy it was.  Make no mistake; this is a gay/fem struggle/rights message disguised as a video game.  You could tell me this game was created by Pu$$y Riot, and I'd believe you.  My gripe isn't entirely with the game itself, as some of it lies with the views of the development studio representatives.  Their decision to not exhibit at PAX due to a group panel that would be there who pinpointed a real issue in society today (quote from source: "Any titillation gets called out as sexist or misogynistic, and involve any antagonist race aside from Anglo-Saxon and you’re called a racist. It’s gone too far and when will it all end?") completely floored me, as it showed their blindness to such an issue.  The developers showed that they only care about their own interests and willfully turned a blind eye to an ever-growing fact of modern society (not just games) in the process.  You can't be liberal while only pushing for your own interests.  The goal is equality across the board (as opposed to punishing white males), and that panel was bringing up a valid point for discussion.  For a company to decide to cut loose and decide to not show up, simply because another viewpoint was being brought into the light, shows exactly how closed-minded they are.  At that point it's not about their principle, it's all about blind, uneducated stubbornness.  This is detrimental to gay rights and feminism as a whole, as it makes them look just as bigoted as those who would oppose them.  They’re essentially closing their eyes, plugging their ears, and yelling “la la la la.”Again, the game is designed well, and really, the love story is quite good to an extent (albeit quite cliche and young-angst at parts).  It’s just far too preachy, and far too obvious, so much so that it gets to a point where you’ll find yourself rolling your eyes at every “journal entry.”  The story unfolds in a really interesting way as there’s actually multiple narratives going on.  For many, there will be a lot of guessing going on to the very end; for the more experienced adventure gamer (who pays very close attention to detail), you’ll have it figured out pretty quickly.Final verdict:  If you’re a hardcore feminist lesbian who believes that your rights are the only ones that matter and every single white male on the planet owes you respect beyond words, this game will be #2 on your “top games of all time” list, just under "Castrate the White Privilage Patriarchy" (especially if you like “riot grrrl” music).  If you’re a seasoned adventure gamer with mild to strong supportive views on gay rights, you’ll be able to enjoy this game for what it is, while appreciating the modernist aspects it brings to the genre.  Additionally if you’re level-headed and not a complete libtard, you’ll be able to see its flaws and point them out accordingly.  If you’re an absolute conservative♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you’ll most likely have an adrenaline rush by the end of the game and have an urge to go out and kill every homosexual you can find, especially if you’re Christian (yep they throw that at you too, subtly, so they think).  I liked the game, but I would have liked it more without the preachy aspect.  It is for this reason that I cannot recommend it.  I believe only a small minority of steam users would actually enjoy this game, preachyness included.  I believe the description of the game is left so vague for exactly these reasons, and it's going to catch quite a few gamers off guard.  It's to the point of being quite misleading.  Yes you do what's described in the write-up, but that's more of a mechanism for the game's actual story to vomit all over you.  For some, it will be good to take them out of their comfort zone, but to many (who can look at it, taking a step outside the box), it will appear as nothing more than dressed-up politics, and certainly not the kind of adventure they signed up for.You may find that you like it and if so, please don't view this review as being against you.  Just try to step outside the box and look at this "game" with a clear head.  I can't recommend this game because I believe the majority of Steam users would not enjoy it.  While I enjoyed it for its atmosphere and classic adventure gameplay value, only a minority of gamers enjoy those kind of games, and fewer enjoy blatantly forced politics.4/10

content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
												This game completely blew me away.   I was expecting a 'boogedy-boogedy haunted scawwwwwy house' game and was instead drawn into a complex world that kept me riveted long after I realized that I wouldn't be fighting any ghosts, leveling up, or rescuing any wayward princesses.  The story development here is top-notch, and the rather simple gameplay works perfectly within this title.  This game is to the 2010s what Myst was to the early days of PC gaming.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who has ever wondered where games can go, or anyone who wants a completely new and different gaming experience.  This title is well-thought out, has an excellent story, and is definitely pushing the boundaries of gaming in general.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Let me say that the criticisms against Gone Home are valid: it's too short, and too pricey for what it offers. DO NOT buy it at full price. I'd say half price is good.Having followed it during development, I knew what to expect and so I didn't have the wrong expectations: it's a game based on exploring one intricate space, absorbing the story through the detailed objects you come across. It's a very focused experience.In that regard, Gone Home succeeds. For the two hours (ugh so short) I was in that house, I really was immersed. It felt really lived in, like a real home.You get to know the characters - your player character and her family - through various items strewn around, and while it's all very in your face and void of subtlety, it's still well made, and endearing. Especially the little sister; I want a kid sister like that.I've been looking for a game like this. Ever since Tex Murphy: The Pandora Directive, I've been waiting for another game that lets me search premises and detailed rooms in first person, examining objects and looking for clues.So, how does GH fare? It's... a start. Everything's too easily found, the path through the house is pretty linear. The main story is too simple, and boring. It was the side stories that were more interesting, the ones about the secondary characters, the history of the house... all that.I really hope more games come out that are like GH, but more advanced, more complex, more "game-like", with more developed stories and a challenging, non-linear experience. But GH is definitely worth experiencing, and for that I give it a thumbs-up.PS. Oh right, there's developer commentary! Always a plus. Gonna have to check that out before I forget.

Anyway, this game was f****** amazing, 10/10, if you don't like story then stay away.

												“Gone Home is the greatest video game love story ever told.” No it's not. And it's not worth 20 dollars unless you have excess spending money to blow or really want to support indie developers. There's about 2 hours of game here, plus or minus a few minutes depending on how literate you are. Or if you're an idiot like me and can't read maps.Aside from the 90's kitsch and the fact that the main storyline is based off of teenagers and the adolescent rage that goes with it, the three stories (daughter, father, mother) found here are told well. There are no cutscenes or other video game mechanics to pull you out of the gameplay. Instead, you are free to explore and uncover clues and evidence at your own pace. The game designers did a great job of following the writing goal of "show, don't tell." There is no hand holding here and the player is forced to construct their own narrative about their screwed up family. The stories diverge and converge throughout, and the game teases you with classic horror tropes as you creep through this desolate house. The game is deeply personal, and shows the complexities of families and relationships.

Posted: June 30, 2015
												This isn't a game for everyone, that's for sure. Some will find the gameplay as appealing as a root canal. But for gamers with open minds that are willing to play a game that does something different in an industry that has arguably been making the same games for the past 10 years, you will more than enjoy the breif but engaging game that is Gone Home.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 14, 2014
												Let me say that the criticisms against Gone Home are valid: it's too short, and too pricey for what it offers. DO NOT buy it at full price. I'd say half price is good.Having followed it during development, I knew what to expect and so I didn't have the wrong expectations: it's a game based on exploring one intricate space, absorbing the story through the detailed objects you come across. It's a very focused experience.In that regard, Gone Home succeeds. For the two hours (ugh so short) I was in that house, I really was immersed. It felt really lived in, like a real home.You get to know the characters - your player character and her family - through various items strewn around, and while it's all very in your face and void of subtlety, it's still well made, and endearing. Especially the little sister; I want a kid sister like that.I've been looking for a game like this. Ever since Tex Murphy: The Pandora Directive, I've been waiting for another game that lets me search premises and detailed rooms in first person, examining objects and looking for clues.So, how does GH fare? It's... a start. Everything's too easily found, the path through the house is pretty linear. The main story is too simple, and boring. It was the side stories that were more interesting, the ones about the secondary characters, the history of the house... all that.I really hope more games come out that are like GH, but more advanced, more complex, more "game-like", with more developed stories and a challenging, non-linear experience. But GH is definitely worth experiencing, and for that I give it a thumbs-up.PS. Oh right, there's developer commentary! Always a plus. Gonna have to check that out before I forget.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												This story is beautiful. If you are looking for an action packed combat game, stop here, Gone Home is not for you. It isn't a long game, (4 hours-ish for a VERY in depth play through,) and despite its beginnings as an Amnesia mod, it is not a horror game. It is, however, a gorgeously engrossing story and a refreshing change to the energetic reflex-testers that are in abundance today.You play as Kaitlyn Greenbriar, arriving back to your family home after a long trip abroad, only the house is empty. As you explore the house, you will discover clues about where they have gone, as well as about the nature of their personalities and the struggles every member of the family have been facing. The main plot revolves around your sister, and is told through excerpts of her diary that you uncover by examining particular items around the house.The pacing is spot on, and although you won't be uncovering parts of the main plot every minute, you will always be finding little clues about your family and the people they are. The main plot is somewhat cliched, but that can be forgiven for the sheer stellar way it is told, and the detail of everything you see. You will care about your family pretty quickly into playing, and that is what keeps you hooked early on.For me, this was the best game I have played in a long time. It was short, but incredibly sweet, and the characters will stay with me for a long time.

Instead, Gone Home is nothing more then a story of forbidden love, told through a point and click adventure. At nearly an hour in length, don't bother with this waste of potential.  Decent story writing, just hindered by being labeled a "game".

I think the first thing I said when the credits rolled was, "Wait, what?". I get why this game has received so many accolades; it's a good story. When games have a plot that you are able to sink your teeth into, it makes it that much more enjoyable to open every drawer and turn over every paint can in the garage to see if you can find more secrets, clues and storyline. But with "Gone Home", there's too much smoke and mirrors and not enough beef.Really wanted to love this game, after all the amazing reviews, but it fell short. If you're like me and ignore people who say negative things about something you know you're going to try no matter what, at least do yourself a favor and wait until it's on sale.

number of helpful: 58 of 114 people (51%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												        Gone Home is what one would call an "Interactive Story" more so than a game. Gone Home is about a girl by the name of Kaitlin Greenbriar as she arrives home from a trip in Amsterdam only to arrive home and find the house completely empty. It's up to you to find out why.        There isn't much to the gameplay per se, this, like Dear Esther, is a game you "experience" rather than play. You go around the house picking up on clues (much like an adventure game) to progress on the story. These "clues" are in the form of journals that you encounter through the game that explains the overall story through the eyes of Kaitlin's sister, Samantha. You do, however, have to pay close attention the cues all around the house to find out what was going on with the entire family as well in addition to Sam's story.        The game has a multitude of items that you can pick up and even view up close. The devs for the game went all out on the graphics, a lot of the items you can pick up have very minute details to them which I really enjoyed seeing as well as them looking really authentic - from books you can pick up, to memos, to notices, etc, it's all presented in fine detail bar a few minor inconsistencies here and there with some texture work, but nothing that really detracts from the authenticity of the house. At the beginning, when there's nothing lit up, you have the option of turning on all the lights on every room to track the progress you've made within the house, as well as pick up cassettes and leave em playing music while you go explore or sit and listen to them, it's also very truthful to the times it takes place in aswell, giving nods to old idols like Kurt Cobain and even games like Street Fighter 2 (This includes Mock up SNES cartridges found in the game). I was impressed how much attention to detail the devs paid to the game.         The story itself is a very sad and dreary one that deserves to be experienced atleast once. It's about very realistic issues that take place in real life and are seen pretty commonplace and it's very sad to come home from a trip to what you find out in this game.          Now the game itself, admitedly, is hard to recommend due to the fact that, yes it is, at max a 3 hour game that's honestly not worth a second playthru unless you're looking to see how authentic an experience it really is and to find every speck of detail the developers poured their heart and soul into, very much like Dear Esther. It's not a game in the traditional sense because there's no real way you can fail, and the game itself is fairly linear (you find this to do this to find this and do that, etc) it's an experience. One that I personally am willing to recommend if you enjoy games like Dear Esther, Journey,  The Stanley Parable and so forth.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												So I headed into this thinking it would be another artsy-deep indie creation. I'm glad to be mostly wrong.The game puts you in the shoes of Katie, who has just arrived home from Europe. The family's new house is empty, you don't know what's going on, so all you can do is look for clues of the events that lead to this situation.Most of the time you'll be reading notes and listening to journals. It might sound boring, but it is anything but. Even though this  story will last only a few hours, the characters are interesting, the atmosphere is immersive and the whole thing is packaged tight enough not to feel like a drag.As I mentioned, Gone Home is all about exploration and going through the numerous tidbits of information you can find. There are no real puzzles or challenges. If you find yourself stuck, you should probably just check to see if you have missed a few rooms to rummage through. I don't feel like I can call this a game, an interactive experience seems more accurate. Likewise, I don't feel it is worth the current full price (20 usd), but it is totally worth it when on sale.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I picked up Gone Home on the Steam sale and had no idea what to expect. While playing I kept waiting for something to happen so I could fit it into one of those mental boxes where you classify games (shooter, rpg, horror, etc.). I kept expecting to turn a corner and encounter something frightening. Or open a door and find a body. An hour later, I was still waiting. When I finished thirty minutes after that, I realized that this was it - nothing really does happen. It's simply a game of exploration, where you learn a story about your slightly eccentric, but largely identifiable, family. I've never played anything like it.So, yes, I guess I would have to say I liked it. But I still would have a hard time recommending it.

You will care about your family pretty quickly into playing, and that is what keeps you hooked early on.For me, this was the best game I have played in a long time. It was short, but incredibly sweet, and the characters will stay with me for a long time.

												I went into this game knowing the critic hype and the user disappointment, I was fully expecting a 'bait and switch' from a horror game to a love story walking sim, I went into it this way so as not to be disappointed.I was still disappointed. While interesting, even intriguing at times, the ending is so terrible, so obnoxiously bad that it makes you feel as if the last two hours spent inside that house were a complete waste of time - because it was.Do NOT buy this "game." I personally enjoy walking sims, I thought Dear Esther was great, but this is just so...pretentious and boring. Even the elements of horror that are sometimes there are few and far between, and I guessed the ending as soon as the game opened, though held out hope that maybe in the attic there would be something more shocking. Not necessarily a ghost but SPOILER ALERT : I had hoped the girl maybe hung herself in the attic, lending some impact and tragedy to the end of a story that seemed to be going in such a direction, but instead everything turned out fine and I was left with essentially the game version of blue balls. Expectations were minimal, the game delivered even less than I thought it would. Go for Vanishing of Ethan Carter instead if you want a walking sim with minor gameplay elements and a somewhat supernatural story - that game is phenomenal.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 30, 2014
												Alright, first let me clarify that I do not object to the gameplay of this game. So many people are accusing this game of not being a "real" game because it's a narrative that you explore. They're wrong. This game brings to mind the world of Myst, which was a game released in 1993 that single-handedly made the CD-ROM format popular. Anyone who claims that Gone Home isn't a game doesn't know what a game is.Gone Home puts you in the shoes of Kaitlin, a girl who has just returned home from college to find her parents new home completely empty. Her sister, Sam, has left a very spooky note on the door telling Kate that she has left. This early narrative and the overall atmosphere of the game (night setting, thunderstorm and heavy rain, etc.) leads the player to believe that there is a supernatural element at work here. In fact, through various notes and diaries that you find throughout the house, you are further encouraged to foster the idea that Sam and her "friend", Lonnie, have been hunting and speaking to the ghost of the former tenant of the home, Oscar. Among items in the house, you find a Ouji board, a safe filled with old pharmacy equipment from the days before Oscar died, and a particularly creepy crucifix that is scripted to shut off the lights when you look at it. Other than these things there is zero horror or suspense in this game. There is an obvious bait and switch tacked onto the surface of this game from the screenshots to the art style and early themes of the game. After the initial mentioning of Oscar, he isn't mentioned again at all until the very end, after you have endured countless audio diaries of Sam moaning on about her girlfriend, Lonnie. It's almost as if the game was created to draw in players wanting a driving suspenseful story only to let them down with a lesbian romance that is mind-numbingly boring. Putting aside the annoying Riot Grrl and Feminist trash littered throughout Sam and Lonnie's hang out spots, there are some interesting items that help you put together the story of the Greenbriar family. This gameplay mechanic was actually pretty fun and reminded me of Myst. Since this was the best part of the game to me, I won't spoil it, but be sure to savor it, for it does not last long.At the end, after it is revealed that Sam and Lonnie have kissed, Kaitlin discovers that her sister has left, not to escape any poltergeists or demons, but to participate in one of the oldest cliches in romantic fiction. She's left to go after Lonnie. And that's it. Sam mentions in one of her audio diaries that she and Lonnie went up to the attic to say goodbye to Oscar, but other than that and the early hints at ghostly activity, there are no other paranormal elements to this game. The game never attempts to explain why there is a ghost, a noticeably unrealistic plot device, in a seemingly normal and mundane game setting. It doesn't explain what Sam and Lonnie did to make peace with the ghost. It's a meaningless story element that seems to exist only as a decorational gimmick to draw in players.The above fact added to the price tag of TWENTY dollars serves to imply that this game was thrown together to make a quick buck. The story is unimaginative and the the playing time is a mere two hours. I played through with the developer's commentary tracks on a second play through, so I spend a little over four hours playing the game. It's probably the shortest game that I've ever bought on Steam. It MIGHT be worth $5 at the most, which is what I paid for it. But honestly, even at that price, the story is lackluster and relies on shady bait and switch tactics to draw you in. It CERTAINLY isn't worth $20. DO NOT pay that kind of money for this game. Wait till it goes on sale or play a friend's copy to test it out first. Don't reward these kind of business tactics with a full $20. I would have felt robbed if I had paid that much money for this game. Steam doesn't give refunds, so you should put your money to better use.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Is this a game? Is it art? What is a game, anyway? Years ago, Greg Costikyan made an early stab at defining "game", by distinguishing between games, puzzles, toys, and stories. By way of example, point-and-click adventures are mostly "puzzles" (they are solved, rather than "won"), Sim City is a "toy" (it has no inherent goal, beyond what fun you make with it), and something like Civilization is a "game" proper (it involves struggling toward a goal, almost certainly in competition with one or more opponents). The categories are somewhat fluid; any given work may have elements of any/all of them. But by those definitions: No, Gone Home is a "story", not a "game". All of these are forms of "art" (whether good or bad art is a separate question).But those categories can all exist in different media: Civilization is a game, but so is, say, Agricola. One is in the medium of "video games" and the other in the medium of "board games". It is unfortunate that we are saddled with the term "video games" for the medium, when in fact the medium is not limited to games, per se. Myst is a puzzle, Sim City is a toy, yet both are within the medium of "video games". I think trying to radically re-name the medium is not really possible at this point, so for this reason, I personally have taken to compoundizing the word to "videogames", in an attempt to de-emphasize the "game" aspect. So what is Gone Home, then? It is not a game; it is not a puzzle; it is not a toy. It is a story, told in the medium of "videogames". Is that the best use of the medium? Probably not. Every medium has its own unique strengths and weaknesses. As a narrative medium, videogames' primary strength is probably the audience's empathy with the protagonist. Getting the audience to identify with and care about the protagonist takes effort in most media, while in videogames, because the audience is literally in the protagonist's shoes and controlling their actions, that identification happens virtually for free, and can be much stronger than in most other media. Something like Amnesia: The Dark Descent uses this fact to great effect. Gone Home arguably does not make full use of it, except in a couple of scenes. Personally, overall, I found the story in Gone Home stronger than many of the other reviewers here, but possibly that's down to expectations: I basically knew going in that this was a "story", not a "game". There are hints at a supernatural occurence that never materializes, but I never found these hints to be distracting, or even particularly emphasized. In the final analysis, Gone Home seems to me to at least be a worthwhile experiment: Can you use the videogame medium to tell a story, with essentially no "gameplay" elements whatsoever? Yes, you can. Is that a good idea? Probably not, but it was worth attempting in order to answer those questions. And the story told in this particular videogame is decent enough; I'm glad I played it, didn't feel my time was wasted. As a videogame, it is absolutely worth playing if you are interested in videogames as an art form, if for no other reason than that it does something that has maybe not been done since the 1986 interactive novel "Portal".

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 3, 2015
												(May contain spoilers, nothing specific)First, the pleasantries. The gameplay was fun, each room holding a "Where's Waldo?" game for me (Waldo being interactable objects). This may sound odd but my favorite parts of the game were the sounds of rain on the windows and roof and of thunder with its flashes of lightning. Not only were they great in terms of graphics and sound quality, they really fostered a beautiful atmosphere and sounded lovely. The rain blurring the windows was a great idea for obscuring the house's surroundings, so even from the beginning the focus is on the house and its contents.Now, the reason why I can't reccomend the game. The story, and Sam, disappointed me but not for the reason easiest to assume. I have no issues whatsoever with Sam's sexuality, only with the journey she took to discover it. I am Katie's age and I have two younger sisters. If I came home from a year abroad and found evidence all over the house that my sister(s) had felt so alone during the transition period to the new house and school, that she had eventually started smoking, lying to our parents and sneaking out, reading graphic magazines (portraying either gender), and having sex with a kid from her high school? I would have been very, very concerned. Actually, that's an understatement; I'd have been devastated that my sister(s)--whom I love dearly--had gone through so much loneliness and then so much change and I hadn't even been there for it. And the fact that my sister(s) had run away with aforementioned sex partner, without a even a plan or idea of how to support themselves, would worry me to no end. Nevermind any kind of censure for her actions, I'd be worried about her safety and wellbeing!The story is driven entirely on emotion, but in my experience, emotion is only a component of finding happiness. Sometimes emotion is too restrained and opportunities escape, and other times common sense is abandoned because of (even quite genuine) feelings. The story was unbalanced and Sam and Lonnie both were acting almost solely on their emotions throughout the story.The stale parents were a part of the problem. Katie's absence was a part of the problem. Sam's heart doing all of the talking without any input from her head was part of the problem. She grew up on swashbuckling adventures and her story in the game is a pure romance, but nothing in life is purely romantic.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2013
												Gone Home is the first video game I've played that tells a very good story, needs to be a game, and does not require mastery of complex controls.The story is not very good for a game. It is very good for a book or film. But Gone Home couldn't be a book or a film. The quality of its story is indebted to its characterization as a game. However, you don't have to know how to play video games to experience this story. You move around with the keyboard and click on things with the mouse.It's a little trite, but it's a teenage love story, it's practically impossible for one not to be. The third act drags a bit, but it sticks the ending perfectly, so that doesn't really matter.Ultimately, Gone Home is a video game that tells a beautiful love story that can be played by anyone that can browse the Internet. It should go down as a watershed moment in the history of video games as an art form and I highly recommend that you play it.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Gone Home, what can I say about this game. It is not at all what I expected it to be and that's not a good thing. Basically the entire game is you unraveling a tiny mystery of where your family is when you get home from abroad. I knew it was a walking simulator, I knew it wasn't going to have any enemies or fighting. But man is this a slow paced game. It's also very short, like 2-3 hours depending how much you explore. There is little to no reason to ever play it again either. The story, like I said, is you coming home from being at college abroad. There is a note on the door from your sister saying not to come find her and don't try to find her. Yeah right, so basically you try to figure out where your family is. It seems more mysterious than it really is. In the end, the game basically tells a long drawn out Lesbian love story. Which I did not care for at all. Sorry, my personal preference. I felt I was duped with this game, thank God I only paid like $4-5 for it on sale. It certainly isn't worth more than that. I will say this, the voice acting is pretty well done and the controls are ok for what they are, I played with a PS4 controller. Beyond that, I didn't care for the story at all. And that's all there really is to this game, a story. So I simply cannot recommend it. If you like a long drawn out lesbian tale of love then by all means, play this game. But if you prefer to have a hetrosexual love story then pass on this one.

content:
Posted: May 12, 2014
												This game is a walking simulator that lacks a compelling story. Every attempt at exposition in this game is incidental and disjointed, with many story moments being delivered as voiced narrations and 'clues'. These plot devices are sparsely placed throughout the environment, which contributes to the feeling that the developers lazily threw together a scavenger hunt instead of an interesting story. The only reason game journalists love this game is its niche socio-political agenda (sorry, no spoilers). From a pedestrian perspective, Gone Home is a monstrosity, rife of any immediately relatable story elements. Unless you enjoy preachy games, games that can  be completed in under two hours, or games with no definitive objectives, you should not spend a cent on Gone Home.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2014
												Nostalgia is very heavy in this game.Probably the shortest game I have ever played and that was with me taking my time. That statement alone may make you think my review will be a negative one; you would be so wrong. This game was brilliant from the environment, lighting and sound all the way to a very interesting story. I spent most of the game terrified that something was going to jump out and scare the heck out of me. I won't go into the story as it's something that you really should experience for yourself blindly. There is no shooting, killing, fast pace movement or timing that takes place in this game; it's a detective type game with some open-endedness. I'm typically not a fan of short games, but this game was well worth my money; but only if you buy it during a sale.+ Amazing sound and lighting+ Atmosphere is very engrossing+ Very enjoyable and spoken story- Short game- Lacking direction at timesScore:  8.5 out of 10

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												I went into this knowing only that the music in the game was some pretty bad 90s rock. My opinion anyway. Still I heard it was supposed to be a really engaging game.It was tolerable. Any longer and I probably wouldn't agree with that statement. You spend your couple of hours exploring your home, all alone. It's creepy... moody... you're trying to figure out why nobody is home. It's deeper and there's a story to piece together. The main story you learn is kind of interesting. Still I find that calling it a walking-sim is kind of accurate. You walk around, picking up objects, examining them, and... that's it. Your greatest choices will be whether or not to put that can of soda back where you found it or to toss it away like yesterday's garbage. Also, why the hell is every can of soda around there closed?Anyway, again, I liked the story the character kind of pieced together but it was not entertaining enough. Nor was it mysterious enough to be worthwhile. I honestly would have rather someone told me the storyline behind it all. I say this because while I understand the game is trying to do something different... be more like an interactive movie perhaps... I felt it was severly lacking because my character had no actual actions in the game. Yes you pick stuff up and read stuff, but in terms of the plot and what's happening to the other characters (the important stuff), none of it you have any influence on. You play as the daughter/sister of the family, but you could literally be a pizza delivery guy who noticed the door was unlocked and you'll get the same experience. The fact that Sam writes to you means very little in the context.I'm glad I played it because I was able to experience an obvious experiment in video game design and culture... but I would not at all recommend anyone else play it. Your time is more precious than that.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												While immersive, coupled with wonderful voice acting and an ominious atmosphere driven to lure the player into questioning as to whether the game will deviate into the survival horror realm, it falls short in providing a satisfying storyline. Throughout the game, the story builds at a good pace but ends prematurely, which left me thinking, "Wait, that's it?" The main plot was predictable, but the voice acting compensated for its lack of a surprise element and kept me engaged. I just felt that the developers had ample opportunity to create a more interesting and original storyline on par with the detailed, interactive elements placed around the house; they could have delved further into the sub-plots surrounding the family and their issues, which I found very intriguing, and tied it in better with the main story. However, lots of the items around the house did not contribute to the story line or any puzzle elements (not that the game truly had any at all, anyways) whatsover, and seemed to be there only to keep the player clicking longer (e.g., shot glasses, soda cans, toothpaste). In conclusion, the game is filled with potential but ultimately fails to reach it. For a price of $20, it is not worth the purchase whatsoever. Only consider purchasing on sale, but even the price there seems steep at $6-$10 for only an hour or two of gameplay with a highly cliched storyline with no replay value. However, if you're big on ambience, it is well worth it. Even though description stated that the gameplay is non-violent, there were numerous times where I felt extremely on edge or tense from the thunder, creaks, lighting, and darkness after finding several items in the game that seemed to suggest horror elements.

Life Is Strange's Older SisterYou play an older sister coming home from college but the real showstopper was her sister. The game is very relaxing and gives a sense of serenity at times. Other moments, the somewhat eerie environment kept me on edge, expecting jump scares that never came. content:
Posted: October 5, 2015
												I've been going through trying out games I've bought over the years.  This one (Gone Home) had very good reviews at the time, but for me, it simply doesn't work.  All I can do on the start screen is use the arrow keys to navigate between "New Game", Options, and Exit.  I can't select them.  Space, return, esc, none of that has any effect.  The mouse does nothing.I googled around a bit and found this is a known problem.  For some reason this basic, fundamental issue has not been fixed in the years since the game came out.  Supposedly if I disconnected all USB devices from my computer, it has a chance of working, but that just isn't an option for me and isn't reasonable to expect.  I have a variety of devices attached, some game controllers, some not, as I use this computer for other things than playing games.  No game gets to modify my hardware configuration.  Not Reasonable.  Not to mention, lame!If I could get my money back, I would.  But I'm sure it's aged in my library too long.  Still, be warned!Bonus lameness - Steam won't let you review a product until you have used it for at least 5 minutes.  But I can't use it.  If you see this review, it means I sat at the non-responsive start screen until Steam decided I had suffered enough.

content:
Posted: July 15, 2014
												Gone Home, what can I say about this game. It is not at all what I expected it to be and that's not a good thing. Basically the entire game is you unraveling a tiny mystery of where your family is when you get home from abroad. I knew it was a walking simulator, I knew it wasn't going to have any enemies or fighting. But man is this a slow paced game. It's also very short, like 2-3 hours depending how much you explore. There is little to no reason to ever play it again either. The story, like I said, is you coming home from being at college abroad. There is a note on the door from your sister saying not to come find her and don't try to find her. Yeah right, so basically you try to figure out where your family is. It seems more mysterious than it really is. In the end, the game basically tells a long drawn out Lesbian love story. Which I did not care for at all. Sorry, my personal preference. I felt I was duped with this game, thank God I only paid like $4-5 for it on sale. It certainly isn't worth more than that. I will say this, the voice acting is pretty well done and the controls are ok for what they are, I played with a PS4 controller. Beyond that, I didn't care for the story at all. And that's all there really is to this game, a story. So I simply cannot recommend it. If you like a long drawn out lesbian tale of love then by all means, play this game. But if you prefer to have a hetrosexual love story then pass on this one.

content:
Posted: September 9, 2015
												Go get Life is Strange instead. It deals with the same issues and is an actually complete game, not a tech demo.Gone Home is a tease of a game. It is far shorter than it should be, it has no replay value, and the all of the interesting elements are presented, then ignored, in favor of a banal conclusion.TO be clear, this could have been a good game. The writing is there, and a lot more depth which was presented to the player could have been explored. Instead, only the most trivial element of the story is resolved. At best, it is an introduction to a game, not a game in and of itself.As to how it functions as a short story, it doesn't work well there, either. Maybe, maybe, twenty or thirty years ago the prime storyline would have been sufficient, but the focus is something that should be an element of the background and all of the background elements are much more interesting and actually display more conflict.As a former writing professor, I would give this a C, and only for the quality of the prose.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												A lot of people get up in arms about whether or not this thing is a "game" or "interactive fiction" or a "walking simulator". The point is: There are plenty of games with equal or less mechanics and objectives than Gone Home. Gome Home is a game that thives on "environmental storytelling", which means using the surroundings of the player to give the player narrative information without with dialogue or a cutscene. The developers of the game last worked on DLC to Bioshock 2 (a series known for this stuff), so it's no suprise that they use the same tricks. Notes left around, rooms in various states to give clues to what happened in the past, and voice over narration while you play. The problem is that even if the way the story is presented is okay, the story it's telling has to be good, especially when there are no engaging mechanics or interesting gameplay scenarios. The game is basically a teenage romance novel in interactive form. You run around a house alone uncovering a dysfunctional family's deepest secrets through notes laid out in the open in convienient chronologic order. The primary story (and only narrated one) is of a troubled lonely teenage girl who finds friendship and love through a super special awesome young woman and has to deal with a her dissaproving christian parents. While the subplots with the parents were kind of interesting, I just feel the story is kind of trite and mediocre. It just plays out like a teenage wishfufillment novel. There's nothing wrong with a grounded, realistic story,  but it's so predictable and leaves plenty of headscratching plot holes at the end. And the way the house is set up in such an absurd fashion with the notes and the arbitrary key hunt doesn't aid in the believability. The only other appeal to this game if you aren't into shoddy gay love stories would I guess be nostalgia factor, considering the house is plastered in gratuitous 90's iconography.

content:
Posted: February 15, 2015
												I'm not really sure I liked this game.  I am the type of player to take my time and look at every detail.  But the whole set up for the game was misleading.  I really thought this was going to be a horror story.  And if it were, then it would be set up to be a great one.  The on going storm in the background and creaky house noises, along with a blown out light bulb all set me up for a gruesome ending.  But at its core, this is just a narrative about love.  What people enjoy about this is the ability to openly explore and look at nearly every object.  Even the sound track is not bad.  But I was on edge the whole time waiting for a horror storyline to play out, and at the end I kind of felt robbed.  There were just so many elements that were brought up in the story and never realy explored.  Not to mention that this isn't the type of game that is worth replaying.  However, I did get this during a decent sale, and while it holds no significance to me, it was nice to experience this type of game for the first time and be able to critique it like a novel.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2015
												A wonderful exploration of what kinds of stories games that games rarely tell, told in a way only games can. The story of the house is a very human one, with subplots for you to investigate or ignore at your leasure. While few the interactive elements are on the "main quest line", the precence adds texture and a sense or realness to the world, while the diary entries reveal the story at a relaxed pace to match your exploration. Hopefully, one day this will be viewed as one of the popularizers of a new genre of environmental narative games. The game is very short, only a few hours, so pick it up on sale if this is a concern. The is also no challenge, but expecting such is missing the point. The creators wanted to guide you though the story, not try to trick and frustrate you. Clearly not for everyone, but a must try for fans of story and exploration.

number of helpful: 6 of 11 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												A fantastic exploration-based story game. You play as a young woman named Katie who just arrived home from a year-long tour of Europe. You come home to an empty house that your family had moved to while you were away. As you begin looking around, you slowly uncover what has happened in the lives of your mother, your father, and most importantly your younger sister, Sam, while you were away.While another form of media may have been more appropriate to convey this story, the use of a video game still does the story  justice with its ability to evoke a range of emotions. Since the player unfolds the story at their own pace from the first-person point of view of Katie, the story comes across in a much more personal manner.

												This game... well, if we want to call it a game, is a joke. Certainly not worth twenty dollars, and absolutely not worth all the awards it's getting. You are able to interact with the most of the items, though most of them are worthless. It's super short, even when you haven't played it before. And the story itself is nothing more than something you'd find on Lifetime or ABC Family. Everyone talks about the ending being amazing, and how you should play it. Not only was I disappointed by the build up that it couldn't have possibly lived up to, but I felt cheated out of all the time I gave to it. I was gifted this game, and the best thing I got from it was a foil card I could sell for money, so I could say I was paid to play this. And even then, it's not worth it.

I did not rush through the story but I had guessed the ending long before the finale (rather shortly after opening sequence). I really like what the devs tried to do here (the atmosphere was great!) and I hope in the future they expand on it but in this case, I'm almost sorry that I bit the hook.Given that this title will give you roughly 2 hours of gameplay at most with little point of replay it hardly earns its pricetag compared to other games in the genre.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												The Fullbright Companies' understanding of what is is like to be a young dumb kid who is considered weird for the dumbest reasons is astounding. In one of the most realistic/accurate narrative games I have ever played Gone Home has you exploring a house you have been away from for quite some time, but your mother,father, and sister Sam have all left plenty of hints of what life has been like while you were away. It's smart, mature, witty, and a time capsule of the mid 90s. While the game's $20 price tag may seem on the high side, it is a priceless experience. Go into the game with an open mind.
