content:
Posted: November 17, 2014
												I bought Gone Home on its release day after following the Fullbright Company's blog for several weeks. Early 1990s aesthetics with queer themes and a riot grrl soundtrack? Of course I’m in!It's been more than a year since then and I still count Gone Home as one of my favorite games.Backstory:Gone Home came out at the beginning of my Junior year of college. I'd just moved into my own apartment (as opposed to the cramped dorms of the two previous years) and I was reveling in my newfound adulthood with utility bills, cramped bus stops, and a probable case of scurvy.Gone Home also came out in the same period that I did. Blah blah blah. Long story short: It was a challenging time in my life that I’ve navigated through slowly and with much consideration on what’s truly important -- not unlike in Gone Home.(Slight Spoiler Alert) I won’t say my circumstances mirrored Sam’s. I wasn’t a teenager in the 1990s -- Hell, I was still wearing neon stirrup leggings and plastic animal barrettes by the time Y2K was supposed to bring the world to its glorious robot-driven end (or something like that). But in listening to Sam’s audio diaries and sorting through her notes throughout the game I was overcome with this intense nostalgia and sadness that I’m sure all kids who have ever struggled with familial approval will recognize.I’m not quite sure I can put into words what Gone Home did for me on an affective level. Playing it was like coming home early after middle school and sneaking into my parents’ room to search through their bedside drawers for proof of vulnerability. It was humanizing and wonderful and very, very uncomfortable at some points (I’m referring to the game here mostly -- my own explorations were more a lesson in the “better left unknown” category).After the game ended (no spoilers I swear!) I curled up on my couch and cried for a good 20 minutes. Partly for the Greenbriar family. Partly for my own family. Partly because it was 3AM and I had a legal studies power lecture in four hours. Mostly because I found something special in Gone Home that I’d been looking for -- a LITERAL exploration of what it means to make a family out of individuals.Despite what I’ve said about my own personal connection to Gone Home, I truly don't believe you have to identify as LGBTQ and/or female in order to enjoy the game.  I'd actually really encourage people to try and broaden their horizens with narratives that may not be familiar to them. Spice of life, amiright?The narrative itself explores relationships among individuals with secrets and flaws (like in real life!) which is certainly a universal theme and as such can be appreciated by many. (((Though I will admit that having a queer female major character is, imho, awesome and definitely something I'd like to see more of.))) On a purely visual level, the graphics and the continuity of the mid-1990s aesthetic are outstanding. Like, EVERYTHING is so much fun to look at.Gameplay itself is intuitive and smooth with regular WASD movement controls and left/right clicking for further exploration/picking up/putting down objects. ALTHOUGH it should be noted that this game doesn't play particularly well with integrated graphics -- specifically on Windows 8 for reasons?The soundtrack is hands-down one of my all-time favorites as far as video games go (I even put it above Schyman’s Bioshock score) with Bratmobile, Heavens to Betsy, and The Youngins providing most of the Riot Grrrl ambiance. Even if punk or Riot Grrrl music isn’t your thing it just goes SO WELL with the narrative that you’ll find yourself bouncing along with it.All in all, I honestly believe Gone Home more than deserves its critical and public acclaim.THAT BEING SAID -- it should be noted that Gone Home has suffered majorly from certain segments of the gaming population who have specifically sought to discredit/negatively warp public reviews both on Steam and other public gaming review sites. This is most clearly visible in that while there are an overwhelming number of positive reviews versus negative reviews, the "most helpful" review section has been bombarded with massive numbers of thumbs up on the minority negative reviews. People who don't own/haven't played the game come to the Gone Home store page for the single purpose of voting down the positve reviews and voting up the negative. That's just a fact.Why?It's messy.And childish.And ultimately irrelevent to the fact that Gone Home is an excellent experience for those who are open to taking it as such.If the price is a bit steep (the one criticism I can agree with) then I suggest picking it up during a sale or borrowing a friend's library.And have fun for frack's sake.

												I haven't enjoyed many point and click type adventures before - this is something different though.  The graphics are mediocre, not bad, but that's not the point.  The audio, is however good.  The sense of adventure is majestic.The game is a story.  And its not one I even want to talk about.  This game is touching.  At the end I feel like I have grown in my understanding and empathy for people.  I feel like I have a new friend.  Its quite odd.  I don't know how a bunch of nerdy game developers came up with this, but I am impressed.  I highly recommend this game, it is excellent.  I have only one complaint, its short.  Its like a good but short book.  Its over, you feel like you've said goodbye to a good friend forever, and that's that.  Too bad.  So play it, buy it, enjoy it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												You arrive home after a year abroad in the middle of the night, only to find that your family is gone. Confused as to what happened, you begin to explore your family's house, hoping to find answers. However, while exploring the house's twisting hallways, you will not find a game that was worth purchasing. Gone Home is one of the most disappointing games I've ever played. I read through critic scores and hypothesized that it must be an amazing game. "An amazing story!" "Such superb design!" "I loved every moment of it!" After an hour of wandering halls, reading through papers, finding keys and unlocking doors, I finally finished the game... and that's it. No flash, no bang, just a story that was pieced together through exploring a home. If anything, this game feels like BioShock if all it consisted of was listening to audio logs and exploring Rapture for a 60 minutes. Gone Home is far from boring. Piecing together the story and exploring the large home is quite enjoyable. The stories sprawled throughout the home will probably intrigue you. However, Gone Home is also far from being worth its $19.99 price tag. I finished the game in about an hour and I have absolutely no urge to replay it. I would not recommend this game unless its price tag goes down to under $10. It's just not worth what it's priced at. Not worth it at all.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
												I'm honestly a little confused about this game. Gone Home got a lot of media attention, so I figured it must be a good game, especially since it is short. The masses let me down in this case.At the start of the game, I actually thought Gone Home was going to be a horror game. It's not, so you can breathe easy. At several points I still expected the story to take a dark turn. That might actually have been better than the ill-fitting ending that is given. It's not that the ending is bad, it is just too far removed from the tone set at the beginning of the game. The gameplay is at best unoriginal, and at worst boring. That'd be fine if the story was amazing, but it's not. The story, like the gameplay, ranges from unoriginal to boring. Yes, technically, if you combine all the game elements, this is a unique adventure game. But unique does not equate to good.If you must play this for yourself to appease your pop culture sensibilities, it is a short enough game to do so. But if you can ignore the bizarre amount of hype around Gone Home, pass on it. You're not missing much.

If you're tryin to be a macho man, this game isn't for you.Secondly, I got this practically for free since i recieved it in a Humble Bundle package with the game i was actually paying for, Prison Archetect. That may cause my review to be a little off center because i'm not considering price. I'd probably never have played it otherwise. Also All i see is people feeling ripped off cause they payed full price. Well Why the hell would you just blindly buy a game with out researching it, ya dingus? If you got money to throw away on impulse buys, check out my wishlist and help a brotha out. I knew nothing about Gone Home other than that GamerGate stuff. I dont know about that, i couldn't care less. I like making up my own mind about things before bashing them; hell, i've read the first Twilight book (and only the first, yuck) because i'm stubborn like that. That said, I had a great time playing this game and it hit me right in the feels.Anyway, there really isn't a whole lot to this game. Explore your home and try to peice together why your family isn't home. I almost didn't play it at first because i'm a wimp and can't make it through scary games. I mean, you start off in a mansion where no one is home on a stormy night; thats pretty much how every ghost story ever starts. But it turns out that it's only scary on the surface. I mean, there are a few sound effects and stuff that are unnesesarily creepy and it's like they used them to intentially create a creepy vibe, even though its not a scary game. Still, we've all been at home alone at night before and that can get creepy sometimes. I know we've probably all turned the televison on as background noise to scare away the ghosts, There are a few red herrings that make it seem like things are about to get scary, but the game explains them away almost instantly. It's actually funny. Once i got over my fear and saw that this wasnt a haunted house, i began digging around. I'm pretty good at this stuff as i'm a nosey ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. When i was a child I used to dig around in every drawer and closet i could so it was all very natural. Also like my childhood, it's set in 1995 so there's tons of references both large and small. My favorite in particular was when a young boy's mother called video game cartridges "tapes". That one took me wayy back. POSSIBLE SPOILERS AHEAD:After much digging around, several stories began to unfold. you really begin to feel for these characters you never actually meet. I found myself rooting for the dad, wishing for the mom to cut dat♥♥♥♥♥♥out and for Sam to find true love. As the story unfolds there is kind of a sad sweetness to how sam is discovering who she is and what she really wants. despite sexual orientation, theres a lot of truth to that in all of our days growing up.in the end, this game does something that really makes me love it. It made me feel. Cliche, right? I mean it-- i haven't played a game or watched a movie in a long while that has made me stop and reflect upon my own life and also feel for fictional people.Sure, it was slightly predictible that Sam was leaning toward the homosexual side from the first few letters you find and once you realize lonnie has interest in the military, you'll know where your sister ran off to. That didn't stop the ending from being beautiful and bitter sweet and causing me to  shed a few tears. Only two and a half though because i'm a macho man.Also, that ♥♥♥♥♥ Sam owes me 40 bucks for pizza.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												(I'm going to attempt to keep this as spoiler-free as possible, but that's kind of hard, since some of the reasons I love this game so much are kinda spoiler-y.)     Where do I even start with this? I was pretty skeptical because of all the negative reviews this got, but I picked it up on sale anyways. I was already pretty aware of how part of the story goes, thanks to some spoiler-y things online, so that was a bit of an incentive. What I wasn't aware of, though, was the actual ending. Watching this entire story unfold was great! No, this is definitely not the game for you if you're expecting enemies, combat, bosses, or jumpscares. This isn't a horror game. It's definitely got a spooky feel to it, though, which is really nice.     On the topic of the story, I really saw a lot of my friends and myself in this game. The strong teenage emotions, the parents that just don't understand, the feeling of needing to rebel against how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ society is. You basically get to unfold how the sister, Sam, dealt with all of this. It's hard to be more descriptive without giving away a huge plot point.Okay, I'll just come out and say it, if you're in the LGBT+ community, you'll probably at least somewhat appreciate the story in this game. Even if you're not, there's still a good chance that you'll enjoy the story.     The main reason I see people♥♥♥♥♥♥talking this lovely game is because of how the media handled it. Apparently it was overplayed, oversold, given reviews that were "too good." Honestly, if you're just bitter because of politics and/or "game journalism," you need to get that♥♥♥♥♥♥outta here. Let people praise this game if they want to.     Do I think it's worth $20? Ehh, that's debateable, which is why I played it safe and picked it up while it was on sale. If you happen to catch this for like ten dollars or less, I'd say go for it. Give it a try. Just don't go in expecting hardcore action or anything spooky happening or whatever. This is a game about exploration. It's a 3D interactive storybook. If you know that before getting into it, you'll be much more satisfied.TL;DR: Good exploration game with a lovely story that gave me butterflies. Price is meh, so you might wanna grab it on sale.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												You know the phrase "Don't start something unless you intend to finish it"?  Well clearly the makers of this so called "game" didn't heed those words.  This "game" is not really a game at all.  The entire time you are playing, all you do is walk through a really big house looking for notes your sister left laying around.  Each time you find a note it plays an audio version of the main character's sister's journal.  The gameplay, such as it is, is just fine in and of itself.  I'm fine with walking around clicking on things, looking at them, and putting them back.  I turn on lights, open doors, open cabinets, flush the toilet, turn on a noisy fan, and that's about it. Sure there are a couple of casette tapes you can put into tape players to play some music, but don't expect more than one song to play from them.  That really is the entire game, and like I said I'm fine with that.  Interaction is a good thing.  What I'm not fine with is the story in the game.  And it's not even lame cliched controversial subject matter of the story that irks me.  What irks me is the ending, or lack there of.  Seriously it's like you are reading a book with 10 chapters.  You get to chapter 10 and instead of summing things up for an ending, there is nothing.  Um... did the makers of this game forget something?  Like, I don't know, maybe putting an ending to the story at the end of the story?  And IGN gave this game the PC Game of the Year award?  Wow...

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												Gone Home is a lot different than what I was expecting, There are many who have, and will, play this game and not find it at all amusing. The story is not telling anything new, the gamplay is lacking for a videogame, and you can complete it in about 2 hours with probably very little incentive to ever go back. It's no wonder why there are a ton of metacritic user reviews who abhor this title.And yet I found myself fascinated with it when I was done. Sure, it is short, and its focus is the story over gameplay, but I was immersed in the experience. I don't want to give too much away about Gone Home and its story. As you may have read from the game's description, it is about a young girl named Katie who has returned from a one year trip in Europe. It's around one in the morning on June 7th, 1995, and no one is home. You'll learn why by exploring your home and figuring out the pieces. Gone Home is not a title for everyone, and you need to understand that it is trying to tell a short story through an interactive experience. If that is something that does not interest you, then you will want to pass on this. The gameplay is very simple; you walk around using either the arrow keys or w,a,s,d, and you pick things up and examine items with your left and right mouse buttons. There are other commands for checking your items, map, and journal entries, but not much of anything else. Overall, by the time I was done playing this game it did leave me with a strong impression. It definitely reminds me of Dear Esther, except the fact that I actually wanted to finish Gone Home. (Nothing against Dear Esther, but it didn't hold my attention for too long). Perhaps my reason behind enjoying this game was due to the fact that, with an industry overwhelmed with a lot of violent and action oriented titles, it's sort of neat to find one that takes several steps back to just being plain, not over the top, and very leveled. It showed me a different type of way to experience a videogame. A lot of players have given this game a very negative response, which is sad because I think that most of that resentment comes from the fact that this game didn't conform to what they define a videogame to normally be. (To be fair, the gameplay is very minimal in its design and execution.)When I was done this game, I wanted to share this title with a few of my other friends to get their perspectives on it, so with that logic I have to say I did, and do recommand Gone Home, but very catiously. First, this game is more of an experience than anything else, and second of all I have to admit that the $20 price tag is a bit steep, especially considering the fact that most people will probably only get 2 hours out of the whole experience. So I recommand it, but only when it's on sale.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												Putting aside the fame/infamy of this game and going into it skeptical and with an open mind, with the sneaking suspicion that I probably wouldn't care for it, I actually got engrossed immediately and couldn't put it down once I started. I see that all the reviews on the store page are negative, but yes, I really rather enjoyed this game. I didn't even think I would, but I did. I feel like the press made a bigger deal of this game than it probably deserved, and that the reviews I see here seem to be backlashing against that. People should just take it for what it is. Nothing more, nothing less. And what it is is an enjoyable little game. So with that said, here's why I like it:It's a personal and touching story presented in an interesting way. I myself like to examine every little object in every little room in whatever game I play, so the gameplay happens to tailor to me in that way. I found it appealing to be alone in this empty house examining every little thing and getting some little details into the story, a glimpse into this family's lives and personalities and flaws and desires. It's all pretty intricate, and there's a lot that can be missed. I think it was pretty cool to see the story of this family unfold before my eyes without any of them actually being there. It's a personal experience for you, and the character you play as, since you are the only one there in this empty house, and to figure out what the ♥♥♥♥ happened here you just have to poke around and look at all the ordinary little objects in each room. Just about every mudane little thing in the house tells some sort of story, and that's what was so fascinating about this whole game. That, and the lonley atmosphere and realism. Although, the ineraction of the characters via notes may be a little strange.And on that note, I feel like it would have worked more in the game's favor if there weren't voiceover journals. I think you should have just read them; that really would have drove home the whole indirect, subtle storytelling thing. Granted, the voiceover brings you closer to the character, makes her more relatable and adds some dramatic flair. But it would kind of take me out of it when it happened. Like, how am I hearing this right now? And it breaks the silence.But anyway, even though I liked the game and am recommending it, $20 is honestly perhaps asking a little too much for it, considering that it's pretty short. It's worth experiencing though, and I enjoyed what I played. I got it in a Humble Bundle, so I certainly feel like I got my money's worth. And I feel like $20 might actually kind of be worth it anyway, considering a new DVD costs around $20 and typically takes like half the time to complete. In terms of sheer quantity of entertainment by length of time, I think $20 is fair. That is, if you think buying a new DVD is (and this has the added benefit of being interactive, and thus more personal to you). Maybe you don't. Maybe you should wait for a sale. Or maybe you shouldn't buy it at all. As for me, I liked it. Maybe you will too. ♥♥♥♥ all these other ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, be openminded and judge it for yourself if you really are curious. I mean, $20 isn't even that much money anyway, and I happened to like it. There are worse things you can spend $20 on. I thought this was pretty good. Sue me, ♥♥♥♥♥es. I ain't a part of yo system.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												Revised and full review.Mentioned several times during 2013’s Game of the Year award, this indie-title tries a different approach to storytelling than most games.In Gone Home, you play a family member that enters the home returning from a longer trip. Things have happened while you were gone. You discover what exactly by exploring the house and picking up various items that are scattered in the rooms. Every time you do, you learn something about your family or yourself, like puzzle pieces slowly coming together.Wandering through the house worked extremely well for me as my curiosity took over. It feels almost like reading a forbidden diary. That being said, this game does not feature a lot of other typical game mechanics: There are no puzzles, no challenges - except searching and picking up stuff - that is practically the only game mechanic. Gone Home’s main focus clearly lies on telling the player a story and using the game environment as a tool to do so - and that works excellent. It is an example that interactive media can offer mature and sensitive entertainment and does not have to feature traditional game mechanics to be an immersive experience.But with the games nature come a few things to take into consideration:I found that I best enjoyed and comprehended the story while finishing the game in one sitting, basically instead of watching a movie.This also tells you that the game is not very long: As there is hardly any challenge you can basically walk through the game, and once you know the story, thats it. As the asking price for the game is around 20,- US$, you feel like you don’t get your moneys worth. If it would cost as much as a movie ticket, it would be fairer in my opinion, as it offers around the same value of entertainment. The overall length, the overall theme and the lack of typical challenge based mechanics also means that Gone Home is a very approachable game for people who usually don’t play games or don’t see their appeal. Taking this into account Gone Home offers an excellent stepping stone into interactive entertainment for people who never thought games could be interesting to them.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Really short? Yes.Not a lot of gameplay? Yes.Graphics are nothing special? Definitely.Worth every minute? Absolutely.Gone Home is the story of Katie Greenbriar, who's just come home to a new house and missing little sister. You need to help Katie figure out what exactly happened, and where her sister has gone.This is an amazing story of discovery and hardship. The discovery of the truth flows forth so naturally with the gameplay that I often caught myself getting personally wrapped up in the story's conclusion, which is something I can't say for many games.Gone Home is probably one of the best story games I've ever played. Yeah, it was short, but the story was so well written I didn't care. It was much like playing a truely interactive movie. A unique experience that no one should pass up.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Gone Home is a beautifully-crafted story that slowly unfolds as you explore this empty house. The voice acting work is superb, and the details you can discover can really start to make you feel like this is your family, and they're gone. What happened?The gameplay may be limited to exploration, but I think it serves as a gentle reminder that we are not always the protagonists, even in our own lives. We have to stop and piece together other people's stories, too. This story is a very strong and moving one. Highly recommended, especially on sale.

number of helpful: 6 of 12 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2016
												Gone Home is a first-person interactive story adventure set in 1995. The premise is that you have 'gone home' on a stormy night to a new house that your family have moved into whilst you have been away travelling. You arrive home to discover that the house is empty, and you must try and find out why no-one is there.This story gives off a bit of a creepy vibe initially, and I have to say that I found it a little off-putting. I played this game through recommendation, and I don't like playing psychological thrillers which is where I thought this game was going to go. Thankfully, that is not what this game is - even though it has its creepy moments, and does hint at something sinister going on around the house, this just isn't the case in terms of the overall story.Ultimately the story is about family, and how you unravel the details about your family from finding 'clues' around the house - audio narrated journals, letters, books, brochures, etc. The audio journals are beautifully voice acted by Sarah Grayson, and really draw you into the story.If the story hadn't have been so engrossing (purely because of the audio journals), I think I would have been a little bored playing this. Objects that you could look at around the house weren't frequent or interesting enough to keep my attention. Certainly the house had a nice nostalgic feel to it, but it would have been better if you could have interacted with far more around the house. After opening drawers and cupboard doors to find the same 'absolutely nothing' over and over, it did often feel like a bit of a chore.This game is available on Steam at a cost of £14.99, and as far as I'm concerned this price is absolutely extortionate. Though I enjoyed the game, I completed it in less than 90 minutes having looked, I feel, quite thoroughly at the objects the game gave me to look at. Having bought games on Steam for £6.99 that I've played for more than 20 times longer, I don't really see how they can justify this price.If there had been more to interact with around the house, even if it was being able to look at clothes in cupboards, or being able to flick through channels on TV, or to play more music in the house, anything at all, maybe then it would have been worth a higher price-tag as it would have kept you involved in the environment for much longer. I understand the house was bare because your family hadn't long since moved in there, but it just felt far too under-developed. I appreciate that the game is about the story, and not the house, but if more time had been invested in making the house more realistic and accessible, it would have made it a much more well-rounded package overall.Ultimately, if you're after a short game to get your teeth into with a very well delivered story-line, this will be one that you want to try out, though I heartily recommend you wait until it's on sale because I think you'll be disappointed at paying full price for such a short experience, however well it delivers that experience.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												(I'm going to attempt to keep this as spoiler-free as possible, but that's kind of hard, since some of the reasons I love this game so much are kinda spoiler-y.)     Where do I even start with this? I was pretty skeptical because of all the negative reviews this got, but I picked it up on sale anyways. I was already pretty aware of how part of the story goes, thanks to some spoiler-y things online, so that was a bit of an incentive. What I wasn't aware of, though, was the actual ending. Watching this entire story unfold was great! No, this is definitely not the game for you if you're expecting enemies, combat, bosses, or jumpscares. This isn't a horror game. It's definitely got a spooky feel to it, though, which is really nice.     On the topic of the story, I really saw a lot of my friends and myself in this game. The strong teenage emotions, the parents that just don't understand, the feeling of needing to rebel against how ♥♥♥♥♥♥ society is. You basically get to unfold how the sister, Sam, dealt with all of this. It's hard to be more descriptive without giving away a huge plot point.Okay, I'll just come out and say it, if you're in the LGBT+ community, you'll probably at least somewhat appreciate the story in this game. Even if you're not, there's still a good chance that you'll enjoy the story.     The main reason I see people♥♥♥♥♥♥talking this lovely game is because of how the media handled it. Apparently it was overplayed, oversold, given reviews that were "too good." Honestly, if you're just bitter because of politics and/or "game journalism," you need to get that♥♥♥♥♥♥outta here. Let people praise this game if they want to.     Do I think it's worth $20? Ehh, that's debateable, which is why I played it safe and picked it up while it was on sale. If you happen to catch this for like ten dollars or less, I'd say go for it. Give it a try. Just don't go in expecting hardcore action or anything spooky happening or whatever. This is a game about exploration. It's a 3D interactive storybook. If you know that before getting into it, you'll be much more satisfied.TL;DR: Good exploration game with a lovely story that gave me butterflies. Price is meh, so you might wanna grab it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 1
												Gone Home is one of the best examples of the walking simulator genre. It has a single story it wants to tell, and it tells it well. More importantly, however, it sets up an atmosphere and a world that is worth exploring every nook and cranny to get as many details as possible. While there's one overarching story, there are plenty of side stories that all add depth to these characters and their relationships with each other. These character moments cover the whole emotional spectrum: I often found myself laughing one minute at a silly detail that made the characters very real in my mind, only to feel heartbroken minutes later by one of the background stories and the context it brings to the whole venture. I won't bring up any particular story moments since this game is best explored without any knowledge of what to expect, but I will say that every additional detail you find is rewarding. Completionists will find an extra level of depth that makes the experience feel satisfying.When I played this game, I was living abroad in Scotland for University. The story of our protagonist coming home from school only to find the house empty and having to put together the details for herself...yeah, that hit me. I carried myself into the game, and I was rewarded for it with a story I still remember years later. If you enjoy this style of game, do yourself a favor and get it already. It's absolutely worth it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												*What is Gone Home? - a bread-crumb trail simulator!*Is Gone Home scary? - No....the only thing scary is the atmosphere (empty house, middle of the night, no lights on, & heavy storm outside), suspicious notes, and your own imagination of the unknown...*How long of a game is Gone Home? - short, my personal playthrough clocked in at a little over 2 hours.*What does Gone Home try to accomplish? - tell a story to the player...that's about it!*Do you recommend Gone Home? - Yes....when it's on sale...Gone Home would be best descrided as a vitural installation piece (much like Thirty Flights of Loving or Dear Esther) that tells a story via a trail of notes and pages littered throughout the house you walk through (the bread-crumb trail).  As you follow the trail, searching for notes, pages, photos, etc. you'll discover where and what happened to your family.  From time to time, narration from your sister will play as key notes are found thourghout the house.  The house is full of 90's memorabilia, intended for nostalgia, which I can't deny being a nice touch (since the story takes place in 1995).  The focus of Gone Home is a story through and through.  I found the story to be solid in what The Fullbright Company were trying to accomplish (a bit campy at some parts, but solid).  The voice acting is solid and believable, invoking suspicion early on, and later going down the romantic route (think more the ending/last episode of Friends; 90's referrance, see what I did there? :P).Gone Home is not a game for everyone.  If you take it for what it is, you will find an enjoyable (if short, with very little replayablity) story to be told here.  The story is not placed directly in front of the player's face, but chopped up and scattered in little pieces giving it a unique story-telling method (this being the most-likely cause for Gone Home's critical reviews).I would recommend trying Gone Home... when it goes on sale.  It is a very difficult to recommend this virtual installation at full price, under the basis of the story alone and evaulating the "consumer's playtime versus game cost."  I personally enjoyed it, it was short, but I found myself going through it, wanting to know what would come next in the story and continued to the follow the bread-crumb trail.  It has an interesting story-telling mechanic, that does what it attempts to accomplish well.-Try it-Play it-Enjoy

number of helpful: 9 of 18 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2016
												I've seen some negative reviews for this game, but mine won't be one. Those saying that the walking&touching game is a waste of money are just missing out a new trend in game industry, which is the walking simulator. In "Dear Esther" you take in the gorgeous island landscape with its ocean, sunset, hidden caves and waterfalls. In "Gone Home" you have a grand old house all for yourself to explore, really creepy and squeaky at times, and at some points you almost expect the old uncle ghost to jump out at you. This is not a puzzle game, nor an action or a scaretale. There's no dialogue. It's all a story, threading from room to room while you're collecting dots and trying to find where your parents and sister have gone. The story is more about the sister, though, who we get to know through her notes, books and schoolbooks, horrid music tapes, tales she wrote, her photos and feminist brochures. It's a game to relax and think, reflect on the characters' fates and the issues they raise, deduct their past and present and accept it. It's like visiting a friend's home when he or she is away and only things can tell stories. So yes, I do recommend this game, and I thank the developers for a beautiful, very 90s, Twin Peaks-ish, Walt Whitman-ish and Life Is Strange-ish ride. I got this game during a promotion, so no regrets here either. We do pay to go watch a movie, don't we? So here's a good one!

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												Gone Home is much less of what I would call a "game" but more of an example of completely immersive interactive storytelling.   Wandering though an empty house, Rumaging through drawers for scraps of paper and consequencely discovering information about Katie's absent family feels very "just so". From the little bits of information and the occasional voiced journal from Katie's sister Sam, you get taken on an emotional journey of struggle, love, adolescences, and at the same time an emotional journey of your very own. I don't think this game is for everyone. There are very few puzzles to be solved, no monsters to fight and no achievements to be won. The whole game depends on your personal curiosity to find out about the family, and if you don't have the patience or will to spend hours picking up every darn tissuebox in the house then this game is not for you. But if you do manage to go through it like I did. You find the good in one or two hours spent looking around in the nostalgic 1995 setting the spookyness of walking alone in a dark hallway, some very real characters (especially Katie's sister Sam), and a great love story.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 25, 2013
												It's basically a young adult short story translated into a game-like medium, something a little like Dear Esther. There is one core narrative that drives exploration in the game, but there are a couple of other side stories inferred by documents and objects that can be found here and there, and some non-interactive objects offer mute testimony that would be heavy-handed in a written story.Don't go into it expecting a horror story, unless you're a parent. There are elements there, but ultimately they're the same kind you could find in your own darkened, empty home.Gone Home isn't without flaws, however. Even ignoring the voiceovers that interrupt now and then, the main story is about as subtle as a tack-hammer to the head, and there's no real closure on any of the satellite stories. The 'search everywhere' approach that the game encourages and an odd design choice makes it possible to short-circuit the whole thing by examining the front hall too thoroughly.I enjoyed it. It does funny things with the interface on occasion, the stories were engaging, and I have a -thing- for exploring. It -is- short though: roughly two hours, if you're digging through every cupboard, so if you're a stickler for some kind of time:money ratio, wait for a sale.

content:
Posted: April 9
												I want to give a concise, effective, and interesting review of Gone Home, but I'm not sure I can do it.Do I like it? Yes. Why? Well, that's not so simple.Technically, this game is fairly unremarkable. The graphics are fine, the controls are so simple that it would have been a feat to screw them up, the music does its job properly but doesn't amaze. To be honest, that's by and large how it goes - every component of the game is perfectly sufficient to do its job but fails to go above and beyond what is expected.The sole exception to that, from a technical standpoint, is the level design. While it all takes place in one "level," the house that is the setting is masterfully designed to direct the player towards the next step of the journey while never feeling too restrictive. It directs the player in a linear experience while feeling like it is the player themself who is deciding where to go next (with a few notable, but natural exceptions).Of course, this is a story-driven game, so the technical aspects might be considered secondary for its appeal, but even there I am not as completely and utterly amazed as some reviewers have been. The story itself is good, and the way its told is interesting and novel. It is this narrative delivery (something that is inextricably tied to the aforementioend level design) that deserves the most praise. Unfortunately, a narrative delivery mechanism alone is not enough to carry a game, and while the narrative it delivers is good, it left me wanting. I got the sense that when I reached the end of the game, what I had really reached was the end of the first act of a bigger story. I appreciate the attempt for an open-ended narrative, but I felt that much of the most interesting content in the story was what happened next. This disappointed me.Of course, when the biggest quibble is that there isn't enough of something, obviously whatever is happening, it's doing something right. So, overall, yes, I would recommend this game. Specifically, I recommend it to people who enjoy exploration narratives with a heavy character focus, clever design, and impressive atmosphere. If you're looking for engaging gameplay, epic story, massive worlds, or anything besides an interesting, small story, do not look here, because you will be left wanting. If however, you come to this seeking a small piece of beautiful, understandable, relatable humanity, give Gone Home a try.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2016
												In Gone Home, you play as an older sibling returning home after a year abroad. During your absence, your family has inherited and moved into an old manor.The entire game consists of exploring the house and discovering the story at your own pace. Gone Home lets you enter one family's personal space and uncover their lives. This may sound boring, and that would be true if this were your average video game house, but the environment is so damn detailed and, well, real. Each corner contains stuff to examine. You'll find notes, drawings, or various objects in drawers, underneath beds, everywhere.This unprecedented realism is also present in the story. Things that would seem boring in your typical bro game, like childhood friendship, coming of age, or marital problems, are abundant in Gone Home. This game has some top notch character development despite the fact that all you do is rummage around a house. You can’t help but be interested in the lives of this family. It’s so much more real than any other game.This game is one of the best in terms of environmental storytelling. It delivers a bold, expertly executed experience unlike anything else. The fact that each player pieces the plot together in his or her own way encourages discussion. I've easily spent more time discussing the game than playing it.

												Gone Home creates a great atmosphere that encourages you to explore and uncover a story, all without worrying about combat.  I thoroughly enjoyed experiencing its story.It is a short game (~2hrs), but I actually didn't mind that. content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I was 18 and involved in the same counterculture (zines/alternative music/etc...) in 1995 as the protagonist's sister in this game, so to say that the atmosphere and story told strike a certain chord with me would be an understatement. Having lived in Portland and Seattle as well, many of the posters and venues described were more than familiar to me and kept me wanting to know more about Sam's life.Yeah, it's a short game, but hell, I spend more than its full price when I go to see a movie which lasts about the same amount of time and which I garner the same amount of entertainment out of.Look, if you're a homphobic neckbeard who haunts chan boards, or a teenage Call of Duty player, this game isn't for you. But for some of us, it's a wonderful piece of art and nostalgia. For fans of games like Dear Esther or The Longest Journey, that wrap you up in the story of the inhabitants of their worlds and leave you wanting more when they're over , its a must buy.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												I haven't enjoyed many point and click type adventures before - this is something different though.  The graphics are mediocre, not bad, but that's not the point.  The audio, is however good.  The sense of adventure is majestic.The game is a story.  And its not one I even want to talk about.  This game is touching.  At the end I feel like I have grown in my understanding and empathy for people.  I feel like I have a new friend.  Its quite odd.  I don't know how a bunch of nerdy game developers came up with this, but I am impressed.  I highly recommend this game, it is excellent.  I have only one complaint, its short.  Its like a good but short book.  Its over, you feel like you've said goodbye to a good friend forever, and that's that.  Too bad.  So play it, buy it, enjoy it.

												SPOILERS AHEAD!SPOILERS AHEAD!SPOILERS AHEAD!Now with that out of the way I can start with the review so you can't tell me I didn't say there'll be spoilers here. Thank God I didn't pay full price and got this game as a part of some bundle for a few dollars.So here are the spoilers and "shocking twists" that will save you spending 20$ on this trash:1) You find out that your sister is some angsty teen lesbian who ran away with her feminazi girlfriend.2) Your mom is cheating your dad.3) Your dad has been sexually abused when he was a child by your uncle. The writing and story in this game are so lame, shallow and unoriginal that the quality of it can be compared with twilight movies. Cringeworthy angsty teen trash. Voice acting is pretty decent though. Gameplay is lame and boring, you just interact with various notes, tapes and objects around the empty house, that’s literally all you do. The tag "Psychological Horror" in the tag section of this game is insulting to the genre and it's false advertising. The only reason why this game gets all those positive reviews from critics is because it's a love story about lesbians and nobody wants to be labeled as "homophobe" (whatever that means) if they didn't like the game. That's it, no other reason. Also 20$ for this 2-3 hour long walking BS with lame story and writing is just beyond absurd. There are way better and longer games for that kind of money on Steam.I also laughed when I saw this on the store page of this game:“Gone Home is the greatest video game love story ever told.” The New York Times No, the greatest video game love story ever told is To the Moon as far as I'm concerned and it's way more cheaper than this overhyped and pretentious hipster bulls.hit gay propaganda. Stay away from it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Even more than most games, whether or not I'd recommend Gone Home depends upon your taste and preferences.Mostly that's because of the kind of game this is.  Gone Home reminds me of some of the adventure games of my youth.  (Yes, I'm old.)  You're dropped into a situation that is quite unexpected for your character and left to explore your environment (the titular home) while slowly uncovering the story of what happened to lead to the current situation.There are no enemies or combat.  The puzzles you encounter, if they can even be called puzzles, revolve entirely around gaining access to more areas of the house.  They're "solved" through simple exploration and really serve as a device to keep the story discovery in order rather than as any kind of challenge.  And that story, as you'll quickly realize, is mainly a coming of age story.  Whether any or all of that is good, bad, or indifferent is completely in the eye of the beholder.Which leads to the other part of why I would or wouldn't recommend Gone Home.  In the interest of avoiding spoilers I'll simply say that the main story involves a topic that has been one of the primary fronts for the past decade or two in the ongoing culture war in the US.  If you strongly identify as either progressive or conservative on social issues you may be either elated or disgusted, respectively, by that aspect of the story.  On the other hand, if you're somewhere between those two extremes your enjoyment of the game probably won't hinge on the matter.Personally I enjoyed Gone Home.  The environment is just a little bit creepy, which befits the situation perfectly and helped highlight the inflection points in the story where I genuinely feared what I was going to find next.  And I don't mean feared in the horror movie sense.  I mean the story drew me in enough that I was concerned about the fate of the characters.  To call the game a "walking simulator" sells it short.  While there may be exploration involved in taking a walk, there usually isn't much of a story to be revealed, at least in my experience.  I suppose your milage may vary if you commonly take walks in your friends' or family's homes when you arrive and unexpectely find them gone, with a cryptic note addressed to you tacked on the front door.If you choose to play Gone Home I would recommend doing so at a time when you have several hours available, so you can play through in a single session.  I would also recommend taking your time and exploring the house throughly rather than trying to rush through.  Much of Gone Home is in the details and I imagine it would be something of a thin experience if you bypass most of that in favor of pushing to reach the story's conclusion as swiftly as possible.  Case in point, in reading through some of the discussion threads here on Steam after playing the game through, I saw reference to some things I didn't find even though I thought I had explored completely.  So I'm looking forward to playing through again at some point with an eye toward figuring out where I missed those bits.Finally, to address a point that is commonly mentioned in reviews, I have to agree that the regular price feels a bit steep for the amount of content Gone Home offers and its fairly limited replayability, especially this long after release.  But it goes on sale fairly often and is a decent to very good value at the common sale prices.So, can you enjoy a game that's about exploration and story, without any guns, explosions, platforming, crafting, or zombies involved?  If you are socially/religously conservative, can you still enjoy a story even though it casts a generally positive light on a topic with which you may personally disagree?  Then yes, I do indeed recommend Gone Home.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This game is a definitely a departure from most of the titles out there. As has been said before, there are no guns, no monsters, no jump scares or twisted secrets, no puzzles or deadly rooms that fill with gas unless things are done just so. It's a game where a girl goes home and explores the empty house that should have been full of welcoming family.It's a mystery, set on a dark rainy night in the mid-nineties with lots of atmosphere and loads of character. You learn about the people involved and, in the end, probably something about yourself. It's worth the play to anyone who likes a story and has an open mind.That all being said, it's short. Taking my sweet time it ran me about 3 hours, I played it start to finish in a sitting and may ruin through it one more time. It's more like a short book than a game really in terms or replay. If you like the story you read it again to see if you missed anything the first go 'round. There's a couple journals that are tricky to find and an easter egg buried in there but it's a game without set achievements and the only goal is simply to listen.The controls are basic but solid, I did find it frustrating at first when I found there were things I could interact with and things that couldn't, things I could read and things I can't For example you can pick up bibles but not most other books and you can't open the books. Feels like a little more time could have been spend allowing you to open things, even if it doesn’t really add anything to the gameplay per-se it would add to the feeling and the mood of the game (which is all the game actually is). You'll also encounter a lot of drawers that are filled with papers and junk but you can't actually pick all of it up or read all of it and even more oddly you can't take most things with you in your backpack. All of that is really beside the point. It's not about collecting loot, or picking up items that might be useful later it's about exploring and learning and not just the house and the characters but yourself as well.Lastly, as much as I enjoyed it it's not worth full price, catch it on half or more off sale and you won't be disappointed but for $20 it's not worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game is about as indie as it gets: it fills all of your wat jar and overflows enough to make your shoes wet. My disdain for this sad existence of an 'experience' makes me cry at night.I was never a fan of the artsy hipster better-than-mainstream feeling that early indie titles had (mainly Braid and Limbo) but those games were at least fun, challenging enough to keep playing, and worth their price tag. Gone Home is only one of these things, and it's definitely not fun or challenging or worth the price in any sense of the terms.I guess if you were a huge fan of Fez then you won't mind searching every inch of this mansion to unlock the secrets, small, bland, short, and boring though they are. I will admit my favorite thing about this game was how you could zoom in on papers and posters and see visibly clear text with an actual message instead of a low resolution scribble to give the impression of writing (mainly like in Mass Effect 2). That's the only thing I appreciated, everything else made me want to uninstall. But how could I? I already spent $20, I had to see it through.The atmosphere was also good. In fact some parts were creepier than Amnesia.If you don't like romances, don't buy this game. I hate romances. If there's a grand story with lots of characters in an epic setting, then a romance between two characters is fine. That's natural. A story, movie, or book that is only and foremost a romance is not what I like in my media. Had I know this game was just a romance, I wouldn't have bought it, but unfortunately you don't realize this until the end of the game and by then it's too late. Did I mention the end comes within two hours? I beat this game in less than the time it takes me to watch a good movie, and I could have rented one for a lot less than I paid for this. Video games are not movies, the experience has to be directly related to the cost of the game, and $20 is way too much.Would I recommend it for $5? No, I wouldn't, but if you want to see what all the craze is about then I guess the only time I would say you should buy it is for 99 cents. Better yet make your brother buy it and play it off Steam Family Sharing, at least then you won't have to stare at it in your own library.

												A fantastic game/story... it kept me right on the edge of my seat. Completely brilliant.Some people complain that it isn't a game - there's a degree of truth in that (although on a philosophical level many of today's most popular "games" have more in common with a hamster-wheel than a game).I thought the voice acting was very good, maybe excellent. There was enough extraneous stuff to rummage through that there was some (albeit small) sense of effort on progressing the story. There were one or two surprises - at least in that the story could have gone in a couple very different directions, and a small number of somewhat-developed sub-plots.In the end, I thought it was a really lovely way to tell a story.(I cracked through it in about an hour and a half. It felt like much longer in that I was completely immersed for that period).

Posted: May 19, 2015
												I absolutely loved this game.It has clever writing and narrative design, which provided me with amusement and endearment, and excellent voice acting to support it. It successfully put me in the place of an older sister who is learning and empathizing about her teenage sister's personal life.The mechanics rely entirely on exploration, so that the pace never feels rushed by adversity to react to, or slowed down by puzzle-solving. In that regard, I felt like my experience with this game was truly my own, progressing in a way that felt free of constraint.If you like being immersed in a very personal story and enjoy exploring virtual environments in great detail, this is definitely a great game for you.

												Gone Home is a warm coming-of-age story told in a point-and-click adventure style. number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2015
												This game is a definitely a departure from most of the titles out there. As has been said before, there are no guns, no monsters, no jump scares or twisted secrets, no puzzles or deadly rooms that fill with gas unless things are done just so. It's a game where a girl goes home and explores the empty house that should have been full of welcoming family.It's a mystery, set on a dark rainy night in the mid-nineties with lots of atmosphere and loads of character. You learn about the people involved and, in the end, probably something about yourself. It's worth the play to anyone who likes a story and has an open mind.That all being said, it's short. Taking my sweet time it ran me about 3 hours, I played it start to finish in a sitting and may ruin through it one more time. It's more like a short book than a game really in terms or replay. If you like the story you read it again to see if you missed anything the first go 'round. There's a couple journals that are tricky to find and an easter egg buried in there but it's a game without set achievements and the only goal is simply to listen.The controls are basic but solid, I did find it frustrating at first when I found there were things I could interact with and things that couldn't, things I could read and things I can't For example you can pick up bibles but not most other books and you can't open the books. Feels like a little more time could have been spend allowing you to open things, even if it doesn’t really add anything to the gameplay per-se it would add to the feeling and the mood of the game (which is all the game actually is). You'll also encounter a lot of drawers that are filled with papers and junk but you can't actually pick all of it up or read all of it and even more oddly you can't take most things with you in your backpack. All of that is really beside the point. It's not about collecting loot, or picking up items that might be useful later it's about exploring and learning and not just the house and the characters but yourself as well.Lastly, as much as I enjoyed it it's not worth full price, catch it on half or more off sale and you won't be disappointed but for $20 it's not worth the price of admission.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2016
												Picked this game up for 75 or 80% off on sale. Good music (Chris Remo is a good composer), and good atmosphere. That's about it. The story is extremely cliched and even despite this, it will manage to hold your interest for a while until you realize it doesn't go anywhere. The ending that they build up to the whole game (it's heavily implied that something very bad happens to Sam, your sister in the game) does not even come to fruition, the side story with the father and mother is interesting for a while as well until that also turns out that it doesn't go anywhere. The journey is somewhat engaging for a little while, but there is no conclusion whatsoever. I suppose it's somewhat like real life in this sense, that the events just sort of happen and keep happening, and keep happening, but eventually you look back on the whole game and ask yourself: what the hell is the point? If the story went in an interesting direction and had a meaningful conclusion, I would have enjoyed this game so much more, as then the several hours you spend playing would actually lead to something. In terms of gameplay, there's nothing here. It's very much like Dear Esther in the sense that you sort of just walk around and the story is revealed to you. Yes you have to look for clues and hints to move the story along, but this mostly just consists of opening up drawers to find letters and diaries and such. There is nothing challenging whatsoever about this game, and the gameplay does not change or evolve one iota during the entire playthrough. TL;DR - Bad game, meh story that goes nowhere, good soundtrack (the score, not the in game music). Very short and unrewarding. Even if you enjoy coming of age stories about homosexuality (the game's main theme), don't spend money on this, just watch a playthrough on youtube. You will get the exact same level of enjoyment out of just watching.

content:
Posted: February 15
												I didn't really think the theme of the game was something I would enjoy but the story turned out to be pretty good (It does a great job at creating suspense). I liked the ambience - the amount of detail in the house and the sound direction (probably the backbone of all walking simulators).  But the actual gameplay I think was too monotonous. A lot of reading is involved. They decided to actually scan real life letters and drawings and handwriting in general, so some of the text is actually pretty unreadable. Not that it matters, because most of it is not what you’d call interesting or essential to the story. Also there are a lot of pointless interactive objects in the house. Things that again don't contribute anything to the story or immersion, in my opinion. And whilst the developers made a good job recreating a realistic 90s house in a video game, it’s still just that. One might even describe it as overwhelmingly mundane, but not in a nostalgic, cool kind of way, but just plain boring and predictable. And when you can complete the entire game in under a minute (whilst speedrunning) the 20 euro price tag seems utterly ludicrous. Now, this is the point where I was going to end my review saying ''Don't buy it'', but I went back and played the game once more, but this time with the developer commentary enabled. I mean the creative process of creating a game is very interesting. And building the game from nothing takes huge amount of time and skill, especially if there are only a few people working on it. The developers highlighted some things that I had missed on my first playthrough or rather took for granted. These insights reminded me of the time I made a 10 page newspaper for my english class assignment (smth like 8th grade). It took me roughly 5 months to produce six pages of content I was kind of happy with. It was an enormous chore to think out what was going to be in the newspaper: the attitude of the newspaper, the individual stories, the proportions, the layout, the overall design, the writing style, the pictures, the ads - everything had to be perfect (since it was WAY past the hand in deadline and I wanted to salvage a good grade and of course make the teacher feel bad for ever doubting my abilities). Anyway, after that much effort put into a project, it sure would be nice to be rewarded (*high price tag*). But we still have to look at everything objectively. Yes the teacher was very impressed by my efforts (so much so, that she decided to take it as a keepsake),but I still got an F. And so, while I did enjoy the game, no way should it get away with costing twice the money it’s worth. Snatch it on a sale though.

												I sincerely wish I would have looked at the PLAYER reviews for this game before I bought it.  I'm glad I only wasted a few dollars on this when it was on sale.  As an exploration game, I did like walking through the rooms and looking at everything.  But, I wasted a LOT of time picking everything up and trying to see if it would work with or combine with other objects (like matches with candles).  WTH is the point of being able to pick up hundreds of objects, but (barring lightswitches and cassette tapes) only a couple of them in the entire game actual DO something???  I did not realize this is some teen coming of age storyline.  (UGH - again, I should have read the player reviews...)  I did know it's not a horror game, but I really thought there might be a little more creepy stuff in the game, particularly concerning the uncle that had recently passed. I also don't understand why the VCRs and game consoles were gone, but the TVs and stereos were left there.  Yes, it's so you can play the cassettes, but come on.   Money is money and they would have taken more of that stuff to pawn off...  The only really believable part of the story is the parents saying they went camping, but actually going to a marriage counseling workshop/retreat thing for the weekend...

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2016
												Even more than most games, whether or not I'd recommend Gone Home depends upon your taste and preferences.Mostly that's because of the kind of game this is.  Gone Home reminds me of some of the adventure games of my youth.  (Yes, I'm old.)  You're dropped into a situation that is quite unexpected for your character and left to explore your environment (the titular home) while slowly uncovering the story of what happened to lead to the current situation.There are no enemies or combat.  The puzzles you encounter, if they can even be called puzzles, revolve entirely around gaining access to more areas of the house.  They're "solved" through simple exploration and really serve as a device to keep the story discovery in order rather than as any kind of challenge.  And that story, as you'll quickly realize, is mainly a coming of age story.  Whether any or all of that is good, bad, or indifferent is completely in the eye of the beholder.Which leads to the other part of why I would or wouldn't recommend Gone Home.  In the interest of avoiding spoilers I'll simply say that the main story involves a topic that has been one of the primary fronts for the past decade or two in the ongoing culture war in the US.  If you strongly identify as either progressive or conservative on social issues you may be either elated or disgusted, respectively, by that aspect of the story.  On the other hand, if you're somewhere between those two extremes your enjoyment of the game probably won't hinge on the matter.Personally I enjoyed Gone Home.  The environment is just a little bit creepy, which befits the situation perfectly and helped highlight the inflection points in the story where I genuinely feared what I was going to find next.  And I don't mean feared in the horror movie sense.  I mean the story drew me in enough that I was concerned about the fate of the characters.  To call the game a "walking simulator" sells it short.  While there may be exploration involved in taking a walk, there usually isn't much of a story to be revealed, at least in my experience.  I suppose your milage may vary if you commonly take walks in your friends' or family's homes when you arrive and unexpectely find them gone, with a cryptic note addressed to you tacked on the front door.If you choose to play Gone Home I would recommend doing so at a time when you have several hours available, so you can play through in a single session.  I would also recommend taking your time and exploring the house throughly rather than trying to rush through.  Much of Gone Home is in the details and I imagine it would be something of a thin experience if you bypass most of that in favor of pushing to reach the story's conclusion as swiftly as possible.  Case in point, in reading through some of the discussion threads here on Steam after playing the game through, I saw reference to some things I didn't find even though I thought I had explored completely.  So I'm looking forward to playing through again at some point with an eye toward figuring out where I missed those bits.Finally, to address a point that is commonly mentioned in reviews, I have to agree that the regular price feels a bit steep for the amount of content Gone Home offers and its fairly limited replayability, especially this long after release.  But it goes on sale fairly often and is a decent to very good value at the common sale prices.So, can you enjoy a game that's about exploration and story, without any guns, explosions, platforming, crafting, or zombies involved?  If you are socially/religously conservative, can you still enjoy a story even though it casts a generally positive light on a topic with which you may personally disagree?  Then yes, I do indeed recommend Gone Home.

content:
Posted: September 14, 2016
												It's a "walking simulator", and contrary to many gamers I have nothing against them, I actually enjoy the occasional walking simulator. I enjoy being able to walk all relaxed through a gaming environment, not having to worry about monsters, getting stuck at puzzles, or annoying platform sections, and just explore. But even I found this one underwhelming. It's a  lesbian  (I don't really think it's a spoiler, just the theme of the game, something you should know if you're going to waste money and an hour of two of your life on this, but hid it anyway as it doesn't seem to be in the official store page description) teenage love story, which you unravel while exploring the house. Unlike some walking simulators this one has about the depth of a pop song, there is no great mystery, no plot twist, no deeper meaning, just two  female  kids falling in love. WHO THE F*CK CARES??! Maybe I'm just not the target audience, but whatever :p let's not judge, except that little bit when writing the Steam review that is. I do like the nostalgic 1995 setting, nice to be reminded of cassette tapes and stuff.Gone Home, my first impression video, and as it happens also a full walkthrough, so yeah obvious spoiler alert:

content:
Posted: December 25, 2013
												An absolutely stunning experience that uses every facet of games as a medium to its fullest extent, Gone Home is, with all brevity, a game that games as a medium need. Hidden Object games have long since been underestimated for their simplicity and lack of apparent engagement, and while I would praise them before for presenting an advanced storytelling platform, this genre-defining work of art has pushed the boundaries of its own kind, and created an experience with emotional charge, plot and character development and atmosphere (among other things) that blows many others completely out of the water.Gone Home, without a doubt, has yielded for myself the most intensive physical, mental and emotional response I've ever experienced when playing a game. Even if other games do not manage to match the caliber of this one, the impact is lasting and unforgettable, and if the question 'What is a game?' is ever raised,I will be in utter shock if such works as this are ever barred from our medium.The entirety of games as an artistic medium wears Gone Home proudly as one of its most radiant and semantically endowed gems, I feel.Oh but the price is a little high, honestly--20 USD is a bit steep, and I would the artist behind this would realise the importance of making art as available to others as it can be ...

content:
Posted: October 10, 2015
												This game was gifted to me a long while ago. The person who gave it to me kept encouraging me to give it a shot, so today I played it. I'm glad I did. It was worth it. The eeriness of coming home to an empty but lived in house was unsettling, but in a clever way. It felt like home but with something slightly off. It felt right but wrong at the same time. The developers/programmers did an excellent job of creating an immersive environment. The story telling is wonderfully eloquant. The plot devices used to move it forward are creative and encourage you to explore your surroundings. Of course, it also means you can move random items into the bathrooms and leave the facuets running while the serious plot unfolds around you.I appreciate that the developers leave you a lovely bread crumb trail for you to follow that encourages you to determine what happened. It's brilliant.

And the story is absolutely amazing.If you can get this cheaply, I mean... it's not worth nearly the asking price of €19.99, more like €2-3 AT MOST. But if you can get it for that price, do buy it, enjoy the story. After all, it's no longer than two hours.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2015
												A few months ago i played Metal Gear Solid Ground Zeroes. Now, the game was great, albeit not very long, but the thing i want to emphasize on are the Paz tapes (supposedly from Peace Walker). 


YouTube™ Video: Metal Gear Solid 5 Ground Zeroes MGSV - Cassette Tape (Paz's Diary - All Entries) HD 1080p 

			Views: 21,938		

			Subscribe to us: http://www.youtube.com/subscription_center?add_user=gameoxotv Follow us: Facebook: http://www.facebook.com/gameoxo Twitter: http://twitter.com/gameoxo Twitch:...		

That was quite an emotional story, and it hits you even harder once you finish Ground Zeroes.This is pretty much what Gone Home is - they created about 20 min long set of tapes and decided to use the walking simulator genre, as a way to tell their story.The story did get me. Though, after finishing it, i went on youtube and looked for the audio logs, and turns out they make quite a cohesive story by themselves. I don't know, but i think that it would have been much better as a movie. The gameplay is shallow - cut the audio logs and you can forget about all those 9/10's and 10/10's. Yes, it's all about the audio in all honesty, which is quite a shame. Even the soundtrack composed for the game - all of it can only be heard during the audio logs themselves.Beware though - there is no horror and mystery. It's simply a teenage love story, and i myself personally finished the game in 106 minutes.Overall, i just want you to know what you are getting into before buying it. Sure - it short, the gameplay is shallow, but saying that i didn't enjoy the game would be lying. It may not be worth 20$, but it's certainly not a bad game.
